Collin Chipetine
March 22, 2017
AIG recently revealed its fourth quarter earnings, which reported losses totaling approximately $3.04 billion, a loss marked as “the worst performance by the New York City-based firm since its near-collapse in 2008 at the height of the financial crisis.” In response, AIG and its Chief Executive made a drastic decision in allowing the current CEO, Peter Hancock, to step down.

Source: Investopedia

Although he was CEO of AIG for less than three years, Hancock had lofty plans from the start of his time with the firm. One of these plans included returning $25 billion to shareholders through a combined effort of share buybacks and a consistent dividend stream for two years. This goal was ahead of schedule with returns of $13.1 billion to its shareholders by the end of 2016. Despite these efforts, after a couple of days of trading at a plunge of almost 9% prior to the Q4 results an at only 85% of AIG’s entire stated assets value, Hancock wasn’t the only one concerned about his position at AIG. In times such as these for companies as large as AIG, it is easy to turn to the leadership as the main cause of such a crash. This of course is not always the case, but nevertheless, begins to make people question whether a change should be made to preserve the progress of the company. This was exactly the case for Hancock, claiming even without the full support of AIG’s shareholders, he felt it was both in his own self-interest and in the interest of the greater organization to not further undermine the growth of the firm. While the CEO succeeding Hancock will be the sixth in just 12 years for AIG, many investors and shareholders do agree that it is in fact the best solution for the organization as a whole. Carl Ichan, the fourth largest investor in AIG, stood fully behind this change of leadership. As expected, shareholders are skeptical of a new leader’s ability to progress the company as needed. At the point, AIG’s goal is to decrease the volume of its balance sheet through several deals to shrink or sell parts of the company. Hancock himself had even had a combined 17 deals to shrink the company overall to just over $498 billion half of its value in 2007, when it took such a devastating blow following the recession. With almost a 5% stake in the company, Ichan frequently states his ideas for a more regulated supervision of the company, even if that means taking on more capital. In order to take all of these ideas and goals and put them into action, AIG must be diligent in who they choose to succeed Hancock. Hancock has agreed to stay on until his successor is chosen, in hopes of avoiding any damage that can be dealt to its shareholders’ interests resulting from such uncertainty. Regardless of whom AIG chooses to fill the shoes of Hancock, the firm’s main priority will be to continue shedding assets and reducing risk in order to avoid repetition of the 2007-2008 crisis. Much is unknown, but one thing that is a definite for AIG is that these next few upcoming weeks will be crucial to the future of the company. Sources:

Avi Goldman March 8, 2017 With professional sports around the world reaching the height of their popularity, team valuations have begun to explode. In July 2016, Forbes published an article listing the most valuable sports franchises in the world, which was led by the Dallas Cowboys football team at $4 billion. That’s $1.37B more than your friendly-neighborhood GameStop (NYSE:GME). So what is it about sports teams that makes them so valuable? Let’s examine one specific NBA team, the New York Knicks, for example. The Knicks make money from their portion of the television deals the league has with Turner Sports and ESPN ($240M), their huge market ($1.456B), the money generated by MSG (ticket sales, non-basketball events, premium attractions, etc.) ($907M) and their specific brand ($447 M). All of those add up to a team valuation of ~$3 Billion. Reading that Forbes article got me thinking: why don’t sports teams offer shares on the public markets?

Source: espn.com

As we just saw, buying a sports franchise is an expensive endeavor, one usually reserved for billionaires and the ultra-connected, but need that be the case? Why can’t franchise-owners, like CEOs that IPO their companies, look to the public markets to raise funds for a new stadium or to go after a highly-coveted free agent? What sports fan wouldn’t be interested in becoming a part-owner of their favorite team, even if they only owned a fraction of a percent? If they are worried about inexperienced outsiders ruining their team, the ownership group could set up the public shares in such a way that they do not allow the holders to vote on team matters, similar to how Snap, Inc. (NYSE:SNAP) offered theirs. While there have been instances in the past when teams have offered shares and underperformed the market, I believe that an equitable arrangement that allows investors to share in the financial gains and appreciation of the teams will solve this problem. In 2012, Business Insider published a piece titled “The Fastest Growing Sports Franchises Since 2000.” In it, they detailed teams that grew by over 200% over the 12-year period, a period in which the S&P 500 had growth of less than 50%. A team’s valuation would undoubtedly be highly cyclical based on its recent performance (which would without a doubt impact all aspects of its revenue stream), but in the same way that value investors find the neglected stocks bound to soar, the smart money would see past the struggles of today and buy into the bright future. While there are, without a doubt, still issues that need to be resolved with this idea, I believe that such an offering would be attractive to both fans seeking to join in their team’s success and investors seeking above-market returns.   Sources:

by Chandrapaul Latchman

Ebay meets Amazon meets PayPal. That’s what pundits are calling China’s hottest technology company, Alibaba. With just days away from its Initial Public Offering (IPO), Alibaba is slated to draw in $24.3bn, according to the Wall St. Journal.

For those of you who aren’t so finance savvy, an IPO is essentially taking a private company public. The company, in this case Alibaba, hires an investment bank, which seeks investors to buy shares, or ownership, of the company. The investment bankers are responsible for pricing the shares and use a variety of methods to come up with that price. The shares are then issued to the public and traded on the secondary market (this is what we call the stock market).
So what does Alibaba actually do? Well, they are a Chinese e-commerce company with a twist. You can literally buy anything under the sun, from fresh fruit to electric tools to automobiles. The service is B2B (business to business) transactions, as most of the products are sold in bulk. If that’s the Amazon part, then the eBay element is that there are literally thousands upon thousands of suppliers from all over the world and you can negotiate the price on goods if you buy enough items.

The element that most resembles PayPal is Alipay. This is possibly the most telling of exactly how large Alibaba is. Average daily transaction volume of Alipay is $298mm, that’s every day of the year people! In comparison, PayPal has a daily transaction volume of $397mm, so it looks like Alibaba still has some ways to grow before it can catch this giant.

Alibaba is set to IPO on the NYSE under the ticker symbol “BABA” and as of September 5th, 2014 share price is expected to be $60-$66. Personally, I think it’s great to have some more competition in the tech space because more competition always means better prices and more differentiated service for the customer.

Would you buy in? I have to say I’m bullish on Alibaba, due primarily to their 43% operating margin. In comparison, Amazon’s operating margin is 0%. How do you feel about this Chinese company IPO-ing in NYC? Does it make you feel uneasy that a Chinese company serves as a legitimate threat to our beloved Amazon, Ebay, and PayPal?

It is not uncommon to hear discussion about oil and gas prices, as they strongly impact the daily lives of most. The resource that heats homes and fuels cars fluctuates with global supply/demand, government regulation, and the condition of many major drilling corporations. Although oil recently dipped to a two week low to $53 a barrel, it is still near a yearly high. So, what is driving it?

Source:oilprice.com

In November, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Companies (OPEC) announced they plan to cut oil production by as much as 1.8 million barrels a day. Despite this major regulation, because OPEC is such a global organization consisting of 13 countries, the implementation of these production cuts is lagging. Specifically, Iraq and Venezuela are failing to comply with new regulation. Simply put, prices are high because available oil to buy has decreased. In comparison, the stocks of many oil drilling companies have risen to keep up with a high demand. Russia, the largest producer of oil outside the OPEC, has also announced its plan to consistently reduce oil production. As economies expand and resources for energy are needed more than ever, it is becoming obvious that the dependency on non-renewable resources can lead to long term issues. There is still lots of uncertainty in the midst of a strong bull market and a new administration, but at the very least, the issue regarding our most important non-renewable resource is becoming globally noticed. Sources:
  • Puko, Timothy. "Oil Prices Rise on Expectation of OPEC Production Cut Extension." The Wall Street Journal. Dow Jones & Company, 21 Feb. 2017. Web. 07 Mar. 2017

Katherine Virgino
  Earlier this week, technology giants Qualcomm Inc. (NASDAQ: QCOM) and longstanding partner, BlackBerry (NASDAQ: BBRY) agreed to a binding arbitration to settle a yearlong dispute in regard to a pre-arranged cap concerning licensing payments, which ultimately awarded BlackBerry $815 million.

Source: Android Authority

Qualcomm, self-described as a ‘world leader in 3G and next-generation mobile technologies,’ is an American multinational semiconductor and telecommunications company, and licenses patents necessary for mobile communication, thus collecting royalties on nearly every smartphone in the market. The company charges its licensing fees based on a percentage up to 5% of the average selling price of a device, but its agreement with BlackBerry prior to the arbitration decision included a cap on such fees. After recently reporting a second-quarter profit of $749 million on total sales of $5.02 billion, this arbitration decision cut greatly into Qualcomm’s top line, decreasing revenue in its patent licensing segment by 40% to $1.33 billion. Although this particular case has had no impact on Qualcomm’s licensing agreements with other partners and notable clients, the company has faced a very recent $1 billion lawsuit with Cupertino-based giant, Apple, concerning similar ‘inordinately high’ prices for its technologies. Likewise, Qualcomm has also faced legal action from the Federal Trade Commission in addition to South Korea and China’s regulatory authorities regarding anti-competitive practices. As this chipmaker is under attack, how much can it continue to profit from its seemingly monopolistic intellectual property? On the other hand, what does this mean for BlackBerry? After reporting unusually large adjusted earnings in its last quarter, the company has begun an expansion of its licensing strategy into other technology components – including wearables, tablets, appliances, medical devices, and possibly automobile software. Immediately after its $815 million arbitration agreement, BBRY stocks shot up 16%, as BlackBerry stockholders are aware of the additional cushion to its balance sheet. Although the company has been lagging behind competitors such as Apple and Samsung for quite some time, BlackBerry Chief Executive John Chen has since stated that he expects BlackBerry’s software business to continue to grow 13% to 15% in the next fiscal year. This legal dispute between BlackBerry and Qualcomm Inc. bring into light anti-competitive practices that continue to exist past the Rockefeller Age and into the ‘Age of the Smartphone.’ With several regulatory authorities recognizing Qualcomm’s control of the mobile technology realm, Qualcomm’s mobile technology competitors – including Huahei, HTC, Nokia, and Samsung – have more leverage now than ever to rise, improve product potential, and maximize revenue. Sources:
  • Brugger, T. (2017, April 13). BlackBerry Wins Round 1 in Legal Fight vs Qualcomm. Retrieved April 22, 2017, from http://www.investopedia.com/-/blackberry-wins-round-1-legal-fight-vs-qualcomm/
  • Licensing Fees in Technology Agreements. (n.d.). Retrieved April 22, 2017, from http://www.acc.com/legalresources/quickcounsel/lfita.cfm
  • Moise, I. (2017, April 12). BlackBerry Awarded $814.9 Million in Arbitration Against Qualcomm. Retrieved April 22, 2017, from https://www.wsj.com/articles/blackberry-awarded-814-9-million-in-arbitration-against-qualcomm-1492000724?mg=id-wsj

By: Jaehan Jeong

September 7, 2014

Everyone should have heard about the slumping European economy for the past few years. Unemployment rate is high, businesses aren’t doing too well, and money is simply not circulating enough. To ameliorate current disaster, European Union (E.U) is experimenting with various methods. Past Thursday September 4th, Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank (ECB)’s president announced their new approach to revitalizing the helpless European economy: cutting down interest rates to near zero.

One might think, “cutting down interest rates” sounds somewhat familiar. And yes, it should sound familiar because that’s what U.S government has been doing for quite some time. Even though cutting down interest rates may seem trivial, it’s a huge deal in macro-economics. The obvious goal is to boost the economy and here’s how that goes. First, low interest rates encourage businesses to borrow more money at ease, trying out more ideas at a lower risk. When some of those businesses flourish, that will aid money circulation while providing more work for the unemployed. Secondly, lower interest rates reduce the value of their currency (Euros), and you might wonder, “How is lowering your currency going to help your economy?” And the answer is, lower interest rates allows European traders to export more because for the foreign traders, Euro is more affordable. Therefore, the fundamental idea of this approach is correct when viewed from macroeconomic theories.

What’s interesting to me is that U.S has done this for the past decade, and European Union has joined in this move to ‘delete’ interest rates. What would happen if all countries tried to lower their currency? Who would be most profitable? Some food for thought.

By Josh Solomowitz

September 16, 2014

Minecraft, one of the world’s most popular games, is now owned by Microsoft. The Swedish developer, Mojang, is being purchased by the giant for about $2.5 billion this coming Monday, September 15th. With 100 million players, Mojang is the best paid app with Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android system. Minecraft, which started five years ago as a PC game, now has about 54 million sales, 40% of which are played on mobile devices.

This acquisition may not seem like a big deal, but in the technology sector, it is significant. These large deals don’t come around too often. Microsoft paid eight times Mojang’s sales last year. A deal of similar magnitude occurred last year when Japan’s SoftBank paid 3.5 times projected annual sales of Supercell, a Finnish game maker. Electronic Arts actually paid 11 times the sales of PopCap only three years ago, at a $750 million price tag!

Microsoft only holds 2.5% of the smartphone market, which could mean that they are desperate for more consumers. The acquisition may sway millions of users to now buy Microsoft phones, which could add more benefits to Microsoft smartphone owners.

Joost van Dreunen, Chief Executive of research firm SuperData, said he doubts that the addition of Minecraft will have any lasting effects of Microsoft’s share in the smartphone market.

Was Minecraft worth the $2.5 billion cost? I think it was a good move on their part. Considering that they have $86 billion in cash and short-term investments, Microsoft has some cash to play around with. With Microsoft’s move comes assumptions and high hopes – the loyal fans of Minecraft may just play into their hands — and phones.

By: Jonathan Spilky

September 16, 2014

This past Monday, hedge fund trader Matthew Martoma was sentenced to 9 years in prison by a federal court judge for insider trading during his time working for the once-vaunted hedge fund SAC Capital. SAC Capital, an extremely profitable hedge fund ran by billionaire Steven A. Cohen, shuttered its doors last year amid the conclusion of a seven-year investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the federal watchdog organization that regulates the industry, which barred the firm from managing outside investors’ money. Mr. Martoma is the eighth trader or analyst who worked for SAC Capital to be convicted of insider trading, or executing a trade based on inside information – knowledge that is not available to the general public and is illegal to use under SEC regulations.

Matthew Martoma’s nine-year jail sentence marks a noticeable desire by the US government to mete out increasingly harsher punishments to deter future misdealing. Earlier this year, Fabrice Tourre, an ex-Goldman Sachs trader who was found liable for defrauding investors was only required to pay fines upwards of $825,000– something Mr. Martoma was required to do in addition to his lengthy prison term. It appears that the government is attempting to crack down on so-called white-collar crimes that often involve sums that are multiples larger than any grand larceny case. In Mr. Martoma’s case, profits of over 500 million dollars were earned in addition to the losses avoided as a result of actions taken the inside information utilized.

By Lisa Huang

September 23, 2014

Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen spoke on September 17 following the Fed’s policy meeting. The focus of this press conference was centered on the issue of short-term interest rates. Would these rates continue to remain low, or will the Fed finally raise them?

The immediate answer to this question was not revealed, although the Fed has pointed to two monetary policy measures that will advance the pace of this change. First is the decision to end the bond-buying program, also known as quantitative easing, after October. Second is the release of a detailed technical plan on how to raise interest rates. These two measures will preface the eventual end of the near zero federal-funds rate.

An exact time frame as to when the Fed expects to begin raising interest rates is still under speculation. Chairwomen Yellen has deliberately avoided releasing a specific date in order to prevent falsely leading on the markets. Although frustrating, this open-endedness is a better alternative considering the Fed’s tendency of pushing back the expected rise in interest rates. In March 2014, Yellen used the phrase “in considerable time” to estimate the Fed’s expected policy change. Since then, that phrase has been used to reflect the cautious attitude of the Fed.

As JP Morgan Funds global markets strategist David Lebovitz says, “After five years and the biggest monetary policy experiment we’ve ever seen, the last thing the Fed is going to do is tighten [monetary policy] prematurely.” This brings to question what economic precursors the Fed is looking for before raising interest rates. Gathering from Wednesday’s press release, the decisions are mostly likely going to depend on data from financial markets and economic growth.

Responses to the press release have been positive. At the close of Wednesday, the Dow Jones, NASDAQ and S&P were all up– 25 points, 8 points and 3 points, respectively. Granted it has taken some time to reach this point. However, the current steps toward winding down the monetary policy involve striking the right note towards future action.

By: Layanah Nsouli

September 23, 2014

On September 17, 2014, Harman International launched a partnership with the National Basketball Association, in which it would be the official provider of all audio related merchandise for the NBA. Harman International, an American Audio and Infotainment equipment company, has established its presence in the entertainment industry by providing quality audio equipment for over sixty years. Generally, the company focuses on providing sound systems for car stereos, concerts, and other large audience events. According to

Dinesh Paliwal, CEO of Harman International, the audio corporation now aims “to elevate the NBA basketball experience for fans around the world wherever they enjoy the sounds of the game – at the arena, in their homes, in their cars, or on the go.” This NBA partnership will allow the company to become more involved in the headphone industry. With plans of creating team and player branded headphones, as well as providing NBA teams and coaches with equipment, Harman will garner widespread recognition.

By focusing on the headphone industry, Harman is entering a lucrative market. Demand for high quality headphones is exploding in response to the ever-increasing use of mobile devices. While the headphones will initially appeal to NBA fans, this move will ultimately allow Harman to penetrate the general headphone market.

It seems that Harman is imitating its competitor Beats by Dre. Recently acquired by Apple for $3 billion, Beats by Dre took similar steps back in 2008 when it partnered with Lebron James. The company has since been endorsed and used by prominent athletes, such as Serena Williams, Dwight Howard, and Kobe Bryant. By emulating Beats’ celebrity endorsed marketing, Harman is successfully combining technology and culture. That being said, is it possible for Harman to replace Beats by Dre as the top luxury headphone brand?

By Max Fruchter

September 21, 2014

For weeks, investors and firms alike have anticipated the momentous IPO of Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce giant. As of this past Friday, the future appears bright as far numbers are concerned; what began as an opening price of $68 a share soared nearly 40% to $93.89 per share. This impressive increase in price seems to validate the high value attributed to Alibaba these past few weeks. The company, commonly referred to as having a “higher market value than Ebay and Amazon combined,” seems to have lived up to widespread expectations. Yet, after all of this ostensible success, one must wonder: what exactly does the future of this massive online marketplace hold? And why are so many still reluctant to invest in what seems to be a surefire way to profit from a rapidly expanding company?

Now that Alibaba is officially registered on the NYSE, the rapidly expanding Chinese company plans on using the capital raised to continue investing in established companies as well as start-ups. Although most commonly referred to as “the e-commerce giant”, Alibaba has placed large sums of money into companies such as Lyft, a major player in the transportation market, and Quixey, the online search engine for apps. In addition, Alibaba founder Jack Ma proposed an expansion of the e-commerce company into growing markets around the world in attempt to perpetuate its rising value. If all of these goals point to a future of success and continued economic prosperity, then our earlier question regarding the hesitancy for some to invest in Alibaba is all the more perplexing.

Despite what appears to be a safe investment with a high return, there are many legitimate concerns regarding Alibaba. Firstly, one must wonder what is inherently proprietary about the company. More practically, what is preventing a group in China, or even America, from mimicking the techniques used by Alibaba? Surely the established customer relationship they have can quickly shift if some group can offer the same services in a more efficient manner. Secondly, in a world where technological innovations are constant, what promise is there that Alibaba can maintain its online appeal? Who’s to say the Chinese company can adapt to the technological advances that will undoubtedly arise in the future? Lastly, many potential investors view the handful of companies Alibaba has invested in as a negative sign- what is the significance of putting money into what seems to be a random grab-bag of corporations? Moreover, what relevance do these various companies have with regard to the services Alibaba offers?

Evidently, both sides to the “Alibaba dilemma” exist. What began as a profitable first day of trading may or may not continue in the future. Perhaps the cluster of companies Alibaba holds shares in may grow, but perhaps not. Realistically, the concerns mentioned above are valid but not definite. At the end of the day it is up to you, the investor to decide- can BABA stay on the road to high profits or is it doomed to fail?

By: Mahum Khan

September 16, 2014

Santander, Spain’s largest bank by market value, has chosen Ana Botin as its chairwoman after the death of the bank’s longtime head Emilio Botin. Ana Botin is the daughter of Emilio Botin and was in charge of the U.K. operations of the bank. The move represents a continuation of the Botin line as head of the bank since the early 20th century. Ana Botin is regarded as a capable successor and is credited with turning around the U.K. operations of Santander.

Santander has grown rapidly and transformed itself from a regional lender to one of the biggest banks in Spain through savvy deal making, cost cutting and an aggressive marketing campaign. Emilio Botin, in particular, was credited with having a global vision by expanding the bank globally and reducing its reliance on Spain as a source of profits. With the acquisitions of ABN Amro, Sovereign and others, Santander was able to diversify its risks and suffered less than its peers from Spain’s financial downturn and continuing problems. It remains to be seen whether Ana Botin can bring the same kind of vision to her role that her father did.

Many financial institutions are synonymous with the names of their chief executives and Santander was no exception. Emilio was a legendary banker who took over the reins of the bank from his father and remained at the head for the greater part of half a century. However, it is important to note that he was not as involved in the day-to-day operations of the bank’s many units and allowed his managers to execute strategies as they saw fit. This should allay fears that his death will prove to be detrimental to the bank. Over the years, Emilio nurtured and positioned capable executives at the head of the bank’s many units and allowed them the opportunity to govern without too much meddling. This has resulted in Santander having a strong and deep bench of executives that can aid Ana Botina as she acclimatizes herself at the head of the bank.

By: Rafat Miah

September 7, 2014

As technology plays an increasingly large role in our lives, it is important to take precaution in regards to safety. Private data is always sought out by hackers and fraudsters looking to use that information for their own gain.

Apple was in the spotlight when this past weekend hackers were able to find and release nude photos of several celebrities to the public. These photos were stored on Apple’s iCloud, which is their cloud-based information sharing platform. Investigation into the matter showed that the hackers found a bug allowing them to guess the account passwords and the answers to the security questions an unlimited number of times. Normally, the account would be locked after a specific number of failures. It has also been concluded that this was a targeted attack, meaning that the hackers were specifically trying to target the accounts of these celebrities.

Although the hackers only broke into those targeted accounts, and not Apple’s servers, it brings up the issue of information security and the steps that both providers and users can take to protect accounts. Apple will begin sending notifications to users when someone tries to change their password or access their data using an unidentified device. This will allow users to notify Apple’s security team or change their password as soon as a potential attack occurs.

Tim Cook, Apple’s CEO, stated that it is also important that users take steps to protect their accounts. Apple already has a “two-factor authentication” system which, as the name suggests, requires two factors when trying to access an account (such as a password and a pin number). Although more secure, this practice is not followed by many Apple users. Tim Cook stated he will try to build more awareness of and encourage account safety practices in order to prevent future attacks, or at least make them more difficult to carry out.

Despite this negative news, Apple’s share price has been gradually rising as the release of their new iPhone approaches.
data.post_title: Apple’s iCloud Leak Calls for Better Security Practices

By: Waqas Tahir

September 16, 2014

The Wall Street Journal reported in a recent article (“Federal Reserve Creates Financial Stability Committee”) that the Federal Reserve announced the creation of a high-level financial stability committee overseen by Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer, second in command of the Fed after Chairwoman Janet Yellen, along with Governors Daniel Tarullo and Lael Brainard. The committee was created in response to claims that the Fed can only resolve issues after they have occurred instead of being able to identify and curbing hazardous financial situations. Bubbles and excessive risk will be the major areas the committee investigates and suggests ways in which the Fed should respond.

The committee will most likely be limited to only an advisory role. Other countries have created committees as well, but with more authority. One such example is the United Kingdom’s financial policy committee. The Financial Services Act of 2012 backs the U.K. committee by law and incorporates financial stability mandates into the central bank’s mission. Conversely, under current U.S. Law, regulators have been told to merely watch over the safety of banks and protect investors. Fischer has suggested that congress should make an explicit mandate regarding financial stability for all U.S. financial regulators, much like what their counterparts in Parliament have done.

The financial stability committee may be a way for the Fed to delegate responsibilities. However, it may just add on to the long list of committees that the Fed already possesses only creating dialogue without much, if any, action. This is partly due to the nature of committees in the Fed. One might also question as to why the Federal Reserve, and not the Securities and Exchange Commission created such a committee. It is understandable that the Fed wants to prevent another crisis, nonetheless is it worth creating a committee that possibly may not have any implementation power? What do you think would be a better way to regulate the prevention of bubbles?

By: Chandrapaul Latchman

October 27, 2014

I’m sure you’ve all heard about the term Big Data. It is essentially a means of making sense of large amount of information. You probably recognize the Cisco commercials about connecting the world together. Well, that’s the goal of big data. In an ideal world, you would walk outside, yawn, and a coffee vendor would appear from around the corner. Creepy, right? Big data means big contracts for companies that want to put up data collectors on public property. Cities and municipalities are gaining a growing amount of revenue from companies like Cisco, IBM, and Microsoft that are eager to put up sensors to track people traffic and noise. They even want to install infrared cameras to detect pollution. Many of these advances can lead to better governance of cities and can affect items such as property values (ie apartment selling for more because it’s in a quieter part of town) and public safety.

Big data has largely been successful for the technology companies previously mentioned because they tend to track your purchases and online behaviors, and bombard us with ads of things that we probably don’t need but end up buying anyways because… well, why not? Okay, now this might not be you, but that’s how Silicon Valley thinks. If they can get in your head and come up with a “profile” for you, then they can milk— er better serve you.

But what happens when Big Data is used for the public good? Instead of caring about profits and ways to earn an extra buck, cities care about cutting costs and maximizing tax dollars to serve the most amount of people. Big Data can help us with pollution in big cities and help us identify areas that need the most police officers on guard at night.

A somewhat unnerving thought is that people could know what time you go to bed as well. A scientist in Brooklyn is doing just that by taking a look across the East River with an infrared camera that can detect light activity in some 800 rooms in Manhattan. Don’t worry though, the camera can only detect light; it cannot identify people or see into rooms at all. However, I’d feel a little creeped out knowing that I was being watched in some sense. What do you think? Are these measures an invasion of privacy? Or is it worth it if we all can benefit from it?

By: Dzvinka Stefanyshyn

October 20, 2014

Since the stock market has been doing relatively well in the past few weeks, international investors have begun to buy bonds from failing countries such as Spain, Italy, and Greece. However, a recent plummet of the global stock market has reminded investors of past experiences with these once-failing countries.

Most of the problems that began two years ago still remain unresolved. New problems, such as the political conflicts in Easter Ukraine, only add to the deteriorating European Union. By: Eddie Yang

October 20, 2014

Ebola, a viral, deadly outbreak, began to spread throughout multiple countries in West Africa starting in March 2014. Only in recent months, though, has the United States grown particularly concerned about the outbreak. The first case in America was documented on September 30th in which a man in Dallas, Texas was diagnosed.The patient, Thomas Erin Duncan, was given the new experimental pill, brincidofovir, a drug provided by Chimerix.

Brincidofovir is deployed against Ebola on a limited basis and yet to be tested in human studies. According to Chimerix, the U.S. government shows that brincidofovir is effective in fighting the Ebola virus. Although the patient died, researchers are hopeful that brincidofovir will prove to be more effective in other cases.

Chimerix is a biopharmaceutical company dedicated to medical research and improvements. Chimerix already produced treatments for adenovirus and smallpox. The company is still researching and developing a 100% effective treatment for the Ebola virus.

Due to the outbreak of Ebola, Chimerix announced on September 3rd that brincidofovir has an in vitro activity against Ebola. In a span of one week, Chimerix’s stock (CMRX) price increased from $24.06 – $30.03, a 24.5% increase., ultimately reaching its peak of $35.98.

There is hope for the new product, brincidofovir. Ashoka Mukpo, a freelance journalist being treated in Nebraska for Ebola, has shown slight improvements after taking the new drug. Although there are no definite conclusion as to whether the drug is completely effective, investor are supporting Chimerix’s cause, as is evident from the 10.77% increase on October 15th.

Ebola has become a world-known virus threatening the existence of many people, including Americans. The increased security in airports and the preparations and training in hospitals prove to show that America is bracing for the Ebola virus. Hopefully Chimerix will be able to find a permanent cure to this deadly virus.

By: Jia Jun Wu

October 1, 2014

It’s uncommon to find people sporting Blackberry devices these days. It’s clear that Apple and Samsung are the leaders in the mobile technology market. The 10 million orders for the new iPhone 6 certainly says quite a lot, but Blackberry needs to be acknowledged for its resilience and integrity. Equipped in its square-shaped smartphone are the Blackberry operating system and a physical keyboard. The idea is that these Blackberry smartphones will be the forerunner in smartphones for professionals. Functionality for work is prioritized before entertainment values. Of course, this vision drives away a great part of consumers. So just how wise is this decision?

Last November, John Chen became Blackberry’s Chief Executive Officer. He quickly implemented methods to reduce costs to alleviate growing losses, and he did so quite successfully. In fact, he hit his target goal three months early. He did so by outsourcing smartphone manufacturing to reduce inventory risk. Additionally, he announced the release of the new Blackberry Passport. This model, geared toward banking, health care, and government consumers, will cost $599 and has garnered 200,000 orders.

As a result, Blackberry reduced its loss for its fiscal second quarter, ending August 30, to $207 million, or 39 cents a share, from the $975 million, or $1.84 a share, from the previous year. Furthermore, it was reported that Blackberry’s device business generated a profit, a first in five quarters. However, revenue still fell 42% from a year earlier to $916 million. Sales of devices also fell to about 2.4 million from 2.6 million in its first fiscal quarter.

Despite these numbers, Mr. Chen remains hopeful. He proclaims that the current sales trend projects profitability and that this is due to consumers believing that Blackberry is a better product. To further combat decreased revenue, Blackberry plans to introduce additional new devices, such as the upcoming Blackberry Classic, and its new management device software, projected to raise software sales revenue to $500 million next fiscal year.

So it seems Blackberry is trying to climb its way back into the mobile device market while adhering to its vision. However, this effort appears to be futile. The market is already flooded with choices, not just in the smartphone category, but also in the management device software category. The breadth of competitors and those who have already established a strong and loyal consumer base are tremendous obstacles to overcome. Perhaps Blackberry’s niche is inappropriate at this time. It’s fair to say many smartphones excel in performing both professional and entertainment tasks. And of course, popularity and reputation play a huge factor in smartphone selection. It’s also important to note that younger audiences constitute an increasingly large percentage of consumers. So how will Blackberry thrive with its current mindset in this ever-dynamic market? Only time will tell.

By: Jaehan Jeong

September 7, 2014

Everyone should have heard about the slumping European economy for the past few years. Unemployment rate is high, businesses aren’t doing too well, and money is simply not circulating enough. To ameliorate current disaster, European Union (E.U) is experimenting with various methods. Past Thursday September 4th, Mario Draghi, the European Central Bank (ECB)’s president announced their new approach to revitalizing the helpless European economy: cutting down interest rates to near zero.

One might think, “cutting down interest rates” sounds somewhat familiar. And yes, it should sound familiar because that’s what U.S government has been doing for quite some time. Even though cutting down interest rates may seem trivial, it’s a huge deal in macro-economics. The obvious goal is to boost the economy and here’s how that goes. First, low interest rates encourage businesses to borrow more money at ease, trying out more ideas at a lower risk. When some of those businesses flourish, that will aid money circulation while providing more work for the unemployed. Secondly, lower interest rates reduce the value of their currency (Euros), and you might wonder, “How is lowering your currency going to help your economy?” And the answer is, lower interest rates allows European traders to export more because for the foreign traders, Euro is more affordable. Therefore, the fundamental idea of this approach is correct when viewed from macroeconomic theories.

What’s interesting to me is that U.S has done this for the past decade, and European Union has joined in this move to ‘delete’ interest rates. What would happen if all countries tried to lower their currency? Who would be most profitable? Some food for thought.

By Josh Solomowitz

September 16, 2014

Minecraft, one of the world’s most popular games, is now owned by Microsoft. The Swedish developer, Mojang, is being purchased by the giant for about $2.5 billion this coming Monday, September 15th. With 100 million players, Mojang is the best paid app with Apple’s iOS and Google’s Android system. Minecraft, which started five years ago as a PC game, now has about 54 million sales, 40% of which are played on mobile devices.

This acquisition may not seem like a big deal, but in the technology sector, it is significant. These large deals don’t come around too often. Microsoft paid eight times Mojang’s sales last year. A deal of similar magnitude occurred last year when Japan’s SoftBank paid 3.5 times projected annual sales of Supercell, a Finnish game maker. Electronic Arts actually paid 11 times the sales of PopCap only three years ago, at a $750 million price tag!

Microsoft only holds 2.5% of the smartphone market, which could mean that they are desperate for more consumers. The acquisition may sway millions of users to now buy Microsoft phones, which could add more benefits to Microsoft smartphone owners.

Joost van Dreunen, Chief Executive of research firm SuperData, said he doubts that the addition of Minecraft will have any lasting effects of Microsoft’s share in the smartphone market.

Was Minecraft worth the $2.5 billion cost? I think it was a good move on their part. Considering that they have $86 billion in cash and short-term investments, Microsoft has some cash to play around with. With Microsoft’s move comes assumptions and high hopes – the loyal fans of Minecraft may just play into their hands — and phones.

By: Joungmin Park

October 20, 2014

Working at Silicon Valley comes with perks and benefits. These include free lunch, massage, child daycare, and more. However, these predominantly male companies have been criticized for its lack of gender diversity. So as an attempt to recruit more female employees, Silicon Valley companies are taking action. Facebook and Apple are financing egg freezing for their female employees.

Egg freezing is a practice mainly for women who want or need to delay childbearing in order to pursue educational, career, or other personal goals. This practice is also common among women who are diagnosed with cancer. Hence, this new perk is a very attractive and appealing to highly ambitious women in the technology field.

Egg freezing is an expensive procedure, costing up to $20,000 with about two rounds of egg retrieval. Why are these high tech Silicon Valley companies putting so much effort into financing this expensive procedure? They want their female workers to stay, and work for as long as possible. Companies are aware that childbearing is one of the most prevalent factors that women contemplate before accepting a job offer. Now this solves their issue. So why not take the opportunity?

This approach comes with both pros and cons. This benefit is also available to employees’ spouses. This can also help talented women balance their workforce and life. However, this brings to light a question: is delaying child labor really necessary? Enabling female employees to delay having children can be seen as temporarily beneficial. But in the long run, these high tech companies need to address the right benefits to workers who are having children. So instead of avoiding these situations for the short-term, they should instead address what is most appropriate and right for the long term. These long-term resolutions should include caregiving, flexibility, and direct supports that secure a spot in their workplace but at the same time help women combine work and life.

So the egg freezing procedure only addresses a small part of a bigger problem. Both Facebook and Apple paid parental leave policies and on-site health care. Facebook also subsidizes daycare costs for their employees. Facebook told NPR that it is offering this benefit because “employees were asking for it.” But for companies, when their employees present them with a choice, they need to be extra careful not to send off a wrong message. For example, expanding benefits to finance egg-freezing could come off as a method for these high tech companies to put pressure on women to delay childbearing so that their employer can get more hours out of them.

All in all, egg freezing gives women more choices and control over their lives and pursuing of their aspirations. Whether or not this is working, we can see that the high tech companies are actively working to recruit more women. They are responding to what young and talented women in the field want. For many women in the field, having children can be a big burden or privilege as they make career decisions. So do babies and high tech advancements not go together hand in hand?

By: Max Fruchter

October 27, 2014

How many people that you know own IBM manufactured computers? What about software security programs? If the answer is zero to few (which it likely is), you are not alone. The past few years have only reaffirmed this downward trend of consumer spending on IBM-made products. Conversely, can you quantify the number of people you know who own an IPhone, Mac, or IPod? If the answer is no (which it probably is), once again, you are not alone. The only difference, however, is that unlike IBM, the number of Apple consumers is too large, not too few, to quantify.

This past week, IBM shares fell nearly seven percent, bringing the company to a three year low. Analysts and theorists alike have responded in utter shock, marveling at how an established, long standing company can fall after nothing more than a worse than expected third quarter earnings report. After all, they may argue, even the illustrious Warren Buffet places high value on IBM in his Berkshire Hathaway conglomerate! To such claims, I refer back to our earlier discussion: “How many people that you know own IBM manufactured computers? What about software security programs?” For whatever reason, many people are still hanging on to what once was the worlds leading computer software provider in hope that it will reinvent itself and, hopefully, increase earnings.

The large presence of Mac computers paired with the ubiquitous nature of IPods and IPhone’s help in explaining Apple’s impressive reported earnings this past week. Once again, Tim Cook and his team have given consumers, and Wall St., plenty to look forward to for the coming months. The introduction of Apple Pay, which officially became available this past Monday, is a clear example of how Apple continues to revolutionize the way in which people act on a daily basis. Something as simple as checking out at the register can now be done that much more efficiently, benefiting the consumer, the Bank whose card was used, and Apple. This innovative payment method, the dominance of the new IPhone 6, and the anticipation of a successful iWatch can all be credited to the rise in Apple earnings. Just this week, Apple shares climbed to nearly $104 a share, setting a high for the company in recent months.

This past week’s rise in Apple shares and fall in IBM’s serve as a microcosm for the way in which the advancement of technology can define a company’s success or failure. IBM “missed the boat” for mobile computing and is only now focusing its efforts on entering the market for data storage and cloud based software. People can hope and pray for the success of IBM as much as they’d like, but no one can deny Apple’s strong presence in the way people act on a day-to-day basis.

By: Nicki Kornbluth

October 13, 2014

This week, the Hilton Group sold the Waldorf Astoria to China’s Anbang Insurance Group. This transaction set two records. Not only was it the largest acquisition of a US real estate asset by a Chinese buyer, but it was also the most expensive purchase of a US hotel.

While private Chinese companies are already leaders in foreign property buying, this record-setting purchase showcases the arrival of China’s state-owned companies onto the US market. This development is made possible by China’s 2012 laws that loosened restrictions on overseas investments for insurance firms. With China’s domestic real estate market in a slump, state-run companies have been turning to international markets to find stable assets.

While most previous purchases outside of China have been in London, this move makes sense for Anbang Insurance Group. New York is also a great location for a first investment. Big cities tend to be less volatile markets, and have more deals available with simpler transaction terms.

Name brand assets are another trend for Chinese buyers. While the Waldorf Astoria is a solid investment in its own right, due to the recent upswing in luxury hotel traffic, the brand name is a way for the Anbang Insurance Group to quickly make a name for itself in the world’s biggest market.

A recent Reuters poll shows that the Chinese have replaced the Russians as the biggest private buyers of Manhattan real estate. After this monumental purchase, I expect to see more Chinese groups, both state-run and private, making purchases of brand name assets in big cities.

What people really want to know is: was it worth it? The close to $2B price tag has analysts and pedestrians alike wondering. While Anbang Insurance Group has no previous experience with hotels, the Hilton Group will continue to run the operations of the hotel for the next 100 years, according to the terms of the agreement. Additionally, Anbang Insurance Group will renovate the hotel to restore the hotel to its “historic grandeur.” Given the already excellent reputation the Waldorf Astoria has, this acquisition should only improve the hotel’s prestige. Given the reliable revenue stream, and the name recognition that Anbang Insurance Group now has on the international real estate market, I would say that this was a worthwhile purchase.

By: Phil Chen

October 13, 2014

JP Morgan, one of the most prominent banks in the country, is facing a cyber dilemma. As the largest bank in the nation, 76 million bank accounts are at risk of being hacked. Statistically, two out of every three households could potentially lose their personal information. Even worse, the FBI believes that other banks may be at risk as well, including Deutsche Bank, The Bank of America, and HSBC. The financial world is under attack and may suffer if action is not taken.

Thirteen other financial firms have also been exposed to hacking. General information has been leaked, although not to any extremes such as Social Security numbers, or account information. The fear is, however, that phishing, a tactic entailed by tricking a customer into giving away personal information, may release such information and allow for severe damage.

Customers are warned to be responsible for their accounts by staying alert for any suspicious behavior. The public is notified as soon as possible and kept up to date as to what is happening. According to official statements, no money has been stolen. As the perpetrators may strike again, steps are being taken to alleviate the widespread concern this hack has spurred.

Such an offense has developed into a crucial reality and in the future, may be an emergency. Enhancing security measures is imperative to easing the tensions caused by the hack. Luckily, things are being done to deter a future attack. Notably, JP Morgan has plans to allocate more than $250 million towards digital security annually in response to these seemingly minor offenses. While the ulterior motives remain unknown, the danger of the hackers to local communities, the United States and all of society is legitimate and concerning. The FBI and SEC continue to investigate and make leads on the culprits.

Thirteen other financial firms have also been exposed to hacking. General information has been leaked, although not to any extremes such as Social Security numbers, or account information. The fear is, however, that phishing, a tactic entailed by tricking a customer into giving away personal information, may release such information and allow for severe damage.

Customers are warned to be responsible for their accounts by staying alert for any suspicious behavior. The public is notified as soon as possible and kept up to date as to what is happening. Such an offense has developed into a crucial reality and in the future, may be an emergency. Enhancing security measures is imperative to easing the tensions caused by the hack. Luckily, things are being done to deter a future attack. Notably, JP Morgan has plans to allocate more than $250 million towards digital security annually in response to these seemingly minor offenses. While the ulterior motives remain unknown, the danger of the hackers to local communities, the United States and all of society is legitimate and concerning. The FBI and SEC continue to investigate and make leads on the culprits.

By: Amy You

November 24, 2014

When introducing the newly released iBookstore in January of 2010, Steve Jobs was asked why a consumer would buy e-books from Apple instead of Amazon. “The prices will be the same,” he replied. This statement was ultimately presented by the Justice Department as crucial evidence of an e-book pricing conspiracy between Apple, Simon & Schuster, HarperCollins, the Hachette Book Group, Penguin, and Macmillan. Apple and these five major publishers were accused of raising the average price of a newly released e-book from Amazon’s set price of $9.99.

The Justice Department initiated the suit in 2012, focusing on the fact that Apple entered the digital books industry in 2010 when publishers still followed the “wholesale model” of print books. This “wholesale model” had publishers charging half the original cover price for a book to retailers. Retailers, however, priced the books according to their preferences.

Rejecting the “wholesale model,” Apple proposed the new “agency model” for selling books. Simply put, this model allowed publishers to set their own prices.

After the case was tried in 2013, Judge Cote concluded that Apple, and Steve Jobs, was aware of the publishers’ frustrations with the “wholesale model” and Amazon’s set price of $9.99 for new releases. This chagrin stemmed from the belief that Amazon’s price was corroding the perceived value of the books. With these grievances as leverage, Apple convinced the publishers to sell their books through the iBookstore app rather than through Amazon.

Judge Cote also concluded that Apple’s opportunistic mindset allowed it to introduce the iPad and iBookstore on a tight deadline which ultimately succeeded with the addition of the conspiracy. As Judge Cote mentioned in the ruling, “Apple seized the moment and brilliantly played its hand.”

By: Joungmin Park

November 24, 2014

Alibaba Group Holding Limited, commonly called Alibaba, made a big hit in the United States when it first announced its IPO on the New York Stock Exchange just two months ago. In September 2014, it established itself as the largest technology listing in United States history, exceeding that of Facebook.

So what is Alibaba? It is a Chinese e-commerce company that provides consumer-to-consumer, business-to-consumer, and business-to-business sales services via web portals. In addition, it also provides electronic payment services, a shopping search engine and data-centric cloud computing services. The group was founded in 1999 by Jack Ma with the start of the website Alibaba.com. Now, Alibaba tops 5 fast-growing Chinese Internet Stocks, and has been a hugely profitable company. As of November 5, 2014, the company’s revenue rose 54 percent to $2.7 billion.

The group is also known for its generosity as well. In September 18, 2014, Alibaba has handed out stock to all levels of workers, creating a wealth diaspora rarely seen in China. Now, Alibaba finally sold $8 billion of bonds in company’s debut sale with maturities spanning from three to 20 years.

Alibaba seeks capital to expand to the West by creating a new digital “silk road” for intercontinental online trade. What makes this company so successful in generating billions of dollars in profits? Alibaba’s business model lies in business-to-business sales. This gives them a high efficiency in reducing costs and a quality control certification process that has curtailed apprehension among skeptical online shoppers.

So now as the top new position for hedge funds, Alibaba is the 16th largest holding of the aggregate portfolio, as 21 of the 50 largest hedge funds had a position in the company. Now, what are the implications of their actions? Alibaba put itself where Americans may not: The United States bond market. Chinese business is entering the United States market, and even topping Americans. This could potentially be the next biggest trend in American bond market, as demand for high-quality investments outruns supply.

Since its successful IPO in late September, the demand for the deal is extraordinary., Alibaba may even be forced to expand its offering size a bit to accommodate orders for well over $50 billion in bonds. Some stock investors see this as a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. On the other hand, bond investors are far more concerned with the stability of Alibaba’s future cash flows.

So while the media is hiking up the popularity and value of Alibaba, in the long run, it is unclear how Alibaba would maintain or even outgrow their current value. It holds quite an uncertain future, and whether or not they would be stable and secure enough. There are risks that follow this argument. First, Alibaba’s history as a public company is quite short. There are also questions about how Alibaba can grow and expand its business scope both domestically and outside China.

Another explanation for why investors were all competing to buy Alibaba bonds is due to scarcity. There simply aren’t a lot of new bonds up for sale in the American market. Numerous American companies issued bonds in euros rather than dollars to take advantage of lower rates there.

Overall, what does this mean for American investors? We do not have a concrete answer, but we do know that Alibaba is a Cayman shell company. A large, high profile company like this one is likely to hold itself to a higher standard. Also, what other issues are on the rise if more Chinese companies invade the American bond markets? There might be another American credit crisis, and China could find itself much more affected than in the 2008 crisis. If the American credit boom ends, bonds of Chinese companies will heavily suffer. So the more they want to get involved with the American market, the higher the risk they are carrying with them. All in all, this is Alibaba’s most risky and dangerous time.

By: Joshua Solomowitz

November 18, 2014

Deliv is the new start-up company that creates technology that offers same day delivery for the same price as a regular 3-5 day delivery. This company crowd sourced $6.85 million as an investment that will be used to hire employees and ship to hundreds of retailers. Upfront Ventures and RPM Ventures were the leaders behind the huge investment. These venture capital firms were also behind the rise of Starbucks, Costco, and Office Depot in the past.

The new company aims its product at consumers in shopping malls, which would explain their new partnership with shopping mall manager General Growth Properties, who also focuses on deliveries for in-store customers. Deliv is already operating in four GGP malls, but plans to be nationwide by the holidays. “Once we sign a retailer all we need to do is add zip codes to our database and we have same day delivery demand in a city,” explained the founder and CEO of Deliv, Daphne Carmelli.

The main purpose of Deliv is to connect the customer, retailer, and courier in an efficient way for the customers to transact with retailers with cost efficiency. To date, Deliv has raised $7.85 million, following an initial investment by companies: Redpoint Ventures, Trinity Ventures, General Catalyst Partners, PivotNorth Capital and The Operator’s Fund.

I think the rise of retail/consumer-based companies is trying to make the whole process of ordering online easier. Amazon has already changed the way we shop online. Now companies like Deliv and Zipments (another same-day delivery start-up) are making it even easier for the consumer. Who likes waiting 3-5 days for a package? Everybody wants their order the second they order it, and now they can (maybe not within seconds, but 24 hours at most). I think that Deliv will only grow and become a consumer favorite.

By: Mahum Khan

November 17, 2014

In the third quarter of 2014, the Chinese annual GDP growth rate was 7.3%, falling short of the 7.5% target designated by the Chinese government. The slowing growth rate, while not a major concern right now, has prompted some serious questions about the future prospects of China, which needs its GDP to grow by at least 7.2% to create an additional 10 million jobs every year for its expanding population. GDP growth declined from 7.5% in the second quarter of 2014 with property values remaining stagnant or declining and the property sector (which accounts for nearly a fourth of GDP) being a drag on overall growth. The slowing growth rate has motivated the Chinese government to roll out several fiscal and monetary easing measures including stepped-up spending on railways, energy, public housing, expanded credit to farmers and private businesses and more relaxed rules for the housing sector. In the latest move, China’s central bank told financial executives late last week that it planned to inject 200 billion Yuan ($32.6 billion) into the banking system in hopes of pushing the economy into a higher growth trajectory. This follows an earlier move to pump 500 billion Yuan into the country’s five major state-owned banks. Chinese authorities have also eased restrictions in dozens of cities on buying property put in place when the market was in danger of overheating

Global and especially Asian markets seemed relatively unperturbed by the news as China continues to be a global powerhouse leading world exports and is showing no signs of drastically slowing down in the near future. However, the concern remains that a slowing Chinese economy might have a rippling effect on the rest of the world and with Europe in a period of stagnation and the U.S. just emerging from the doldrums, this might be the catalyst for weaker global economic results.

Macaulay Business Club

November 24, 2014

On November 21, 2014, Nintendo launched Amiibo, a line of toy figurines compatible with Wii U and Nintendo 3DS systems. This is yet another attempt by Nintendo to recover from their revenue loss, which began back in January 2014, when the company experienced dismal sales on their Wii U consoles. Amiibo figurines “interact with supported video game software, allowing data to be transferred in and out of each game and across multiple platforms.” The characters also give access to special items and bonus points throughout the game. These action figures include all of Nintendo’s classic characters, including Mario and Luigi.

By reaching into the Nintendo character vault, the company hopes to reclaim its strong footing in the video game industry. At the moment, Nintendo’s competitors, Microsoft’s XBox and Sony’s Playstation have asserted their dominance in the industry as Nintendo operated at a loss for the first, second, and third quarters this year. In the first week of September 2014, XBox sold 124,736 consoles; Playstation sold 133,226; and Wii U sold a mere 40,562.

Amid Nintendo’s struggle to maintain its recent return to profit, the video game corporation is utilizing its greatest asset: intellectual property, which includes the classic characters such as the Mario Brothers and Donkey Kong. Although the incorporation of these familiar characters will give Nintendo an edge over its competitors, it is difficult to see the success of this venture. The Amiibo figurines are only compatible with Wii U consoles, which have failed to occupy a majority market share among game consoles. This new line of toy figurines is simply providing an extension to a struggling product.
data.post_title: Nintendo Attempts To Maintain Profits With Amiibo

By: Waqas Tahir

November 17, 2014

The Wall Street Journal reports that Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) has stated it has cut its output sharply. However, oil prices continue to fall. Collectively, OPEC has reduced production by 226,400 barrels a day. Notably, Saud Arabia, the largest contributor, is producing 69,600 fewer barrels a day. This certainly isn’t s sharp decline in production as the article’s title states because it is less than 1% of OPEC’s total volume. It is important to note that OPEC’s statistics are based on secondary data such as energy consultancies.

One reason for the drop may be due to simply natural seasonal cycle, less energy being required in the winter. The OPEC nations are set to meet on November 27th to discuss the possibility of a coordinated reduction in supply if they feel it is necessary. Nonetheless, the nations do not seem to be in agreement with Ecuador and Venezuela to make these cuts, while Kuwait is adamantly against them. The way the current market is set up, if one nation begins to reduce production, another will notice and begin to increase production in order to capitalize the on greater market share. This may be a critical point of debate at the upcoming meeting.

On the flip side, the United States is on its way to becoming one of the largest producers of oil in the world. But what does this all mean for the average American? It certainly means more economic activity is likely, just in time for the retail’s busiest season of the year. The extra $100-150 that will be saved may be the difference between a middle class family going out on a Friday night or staying at home. The November 27th meeting will be a critical indicator of whether oil prices will stabilize or continue to plunge.

By: Anna Chen November 18, 2015 Major airbag supplier, Takata, is at the center of the largest automotive safety recall in history. More than 30 million cars in the United States have been recalled due to faulty airbags that can explode and injure or kill passengers. The main cause of this issue is the airbag’s inflator, a metal cartridge filled with an ammonium nitrate propellant that can ignite explosively and expel metal shards throughout the vehicle. Eight deaths and more than 100 injuries have been connected to Takata’s airbags. As of Friday, November 6th, Honda, Toyota and Nissan have dropped Takata as their airbag supplier while other major Japanese automakers such as Mazda, Mitsubisi and Subaru are considering doing the same. This is creating a huge impact in Takata’s business, as airbags are 40% of their sales. Its stock price have dropped 45% and they are facing more than $200 million worth of fines. Government investigators found Takata had misled regulators since 2009 about the safety of air bag inflators. Anthony Foxx of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration also said that Takata manipulated the test data. The safety agency said that “in several instances, Takata produced testing reports that contained selective, incomplete, or inaccurate data.” Takata said that as of the most recent quarter, it had set aside about 68 billion yen, or $558 million, to cover recall-related costs. The company said it still expects to earn a profit this year, although a significantly smaller one than it had forecasted. It cut its projection for net profit in the fiscal year ending in March to 5 billion yen, or about $41 million, from 20 billion yen. Moving forward, the company has plans to use guanidine nitrate in its airbags in the U.S. market. Sources:
  • Tabuchi, Hiroko, and Danielle Ivory. "Honda Drops Takata as U.S. Issues Huge Fine Over Airbags." The New York Times. The New York Times, 3 Nov. 2015.
  • "Takata Stock Dives after Honda Drops Air Bag Inflators." Detroit News. 4 Nov. 2015.
  • Soble, Jonathan, and Hiroko Tabuchi. "Toyota and Nissan to Drop Takata as Supplier of Airbag Inflaters." The New York Times. The New York Times, 6 Nov. 2015.

By: Andrey Troegubov

November 22, 2015

The iPad Pro-a device that has been rumored to show up just around the corner for[AT1]  the last few years-has finally emerged unto the field. The iPad Pro, unveiled this past September, seems to be Apple’s answer to Microsoft’s Surface line rather than Samsung’s Note Pro. It is a beautiful device, at 12in x 8.68in it is just larger than a piece of standard paper and with a thickness of 0.27in; is thinner than an iPhone6s. On the inside it uses a proprietary Apple A9X chip that allows it to compete with an entry model computer, in terms of processing power and speed. However, from here things go dark; this iPad has a $799 entry-cost for 32gb of memory and that increases to a whopping $949 for 128gb of memory. For comparison, as a student, you can take advantage of the educational pricing in the apple store and buy a MacBook Air for $849 and a MacBook Pro for $999.

But let’s say that you have the money for a MacBook Pro at $999. Even in this case, the $949 iPad Pro still requires that you shell out an additional $99 dollars for the Apple Pencil, a device that allows you to use the iPad Pro to it’s full potential. So, the issue is that Apple appears to be really milking the cost of this iPad. Much like the MacBook Pro, which initially targeted a professional market, this iPad Pro seems to be pursuing a similar trajectory. It is not meant for the average student, or the average user, but rather for the graphic artist.

Collin Chipetine November 24, 2015 For the last year, the US Federal Reserve has tempted the public with the possibility that it might raise the minimum interest rate. With the thought that the economy may just be healthy enough following the recession of 2009, the Federal Reserve hopes that inflation will accelerate at a slower rate in the future and borrowing costs lower to comparatively normal levels. There are multiple factors that hinder the Federal Reserve from simply altering the regulated interest rate at a moment’s notice. Because of either the risk of sending markets into a downward slope, which would bring upon an even slower economic recovery, or the risk that prices would rise on commodities such as homes or cars with an even higher minimum interest rate for consumers, the Federal Reserve is hesitant to make any rash decisions in the near future. As we come closer towards the end of the year, the world awaits what seems to be the inevitable raise in interest rates in America. Many experts have predicted the Federal Chairwoman Janet Yellen, will announce an increased interest rate in a press conference on December 16th, following the two-day Federal policy-making group meeting in which the target rate, or the benchmark interest rate is decided. The Federal Reserve has decided that the current US unemployment rate of 5%, which is recognized as the “full employment” rate, allows the Fed to implement a change that will stimulate the economy rather than bring us back into the recession. While no decisions have been publicized, many speculations have been recorded from within the Federal Reserve. A Federal Policy maker stated “…the committee anticipates it will be appropriate to raise the target range… and is reasonably confident that inflation will move back to its 2% objective over the medium term.” It is likely that our government will change our interest rates depending on changes in policy and economic trends over the next few weeks. Sources:
  • http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/business/economy/fed-interest-rates.html
  • http://www.marketwatch.com/story/where-every-fed-member-stands-on-raising-interest-rates-2015-08-28
  • http://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2015/08/economist-explains-21

Chynelle Menezes November 24, 2015 The global stock markets seem to be remarkably resilient. In the wake of the Paris attacks, stock market prices were expected to decline as they did directly after the 9/11 terrorist attacks, the 2005 London attacks, and the Madrid train bombings in March. Instead the French and European markets rose about 3%[1]. The only French industries adversely affected by the devastating attacks that took place the night of November 13th, 2015 were travel/tourism and luxury. France has the largest number of tourists in the world and the travel/tourism sector accounts for 7.5% of its GDP[2]. Its largest hotel group, Accor Hotels, experienced a 7% decline but ended the day around 5% down. France is second worldwide in luxury goods spending, after New York. Stocks of companies like Christian Dior and Louis Vuitton took hits after the Paris attacks as well. [3] The United States markets were largely unaffected by the Paris attacks. News of the attacks had only begun to trickle in as the day was closing and did not affect US shareholder spending. Oil prices, which are normally sensitive to geopolitical risk, were barely moved by the attacks. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 91.06 points, breaking even for the year. S&P500 and Nasdaq were up 1.5% and 7.8%, respectively.[4] However, the Paris attacks may affect borrowing rates in the future. After 9/11, the Federal Reserve lowered short-term borrowing rates by 0.5% and continued to cut rates over the next year. After the 2005 London terrorist bombings, the Bank of England also cut short-term rates. Economists expect the European Central Bank to follow suit. Currently France’s GDP is flat and rate changes might indirectly boost not only France’s economy, but the economy of Europe as a whole.[5] The Wall Street Journal says the attacks have raised concerns with the structure of the European Union, especially security and immigration regulations, which may later affect the markets. While it is still likely for the U.S. Federal Reserve to raise rates in December, it may re-examine this course in the wake of the attacks and their effects on American foreign policy and their subsequent effect on the market.[6] Sources:
  • [1] "The Real Reason Stocks Are Up After the Paris Terror Attacks." Time. Time, 18 Nov. 2015. Web. 21 Nov. 2015.
  • [2] Kondalamahanty, Aditya. "Paris Attacks: Prolonged Impact On Global Stock Markets 'Unlikely'"International Business Times. International Business Times, 15 Nov. 2015. Web. 21 Nov. 2015.
  • [3] Shell, Adam. "Paris Strong: Dow up 238 as Benchmarks Bounce." USA Today. USA Today, 16 Nov. 2015. Web. 21 Nov. 2015.
  • [4] Starkman, Dean. "Stock Markets Show Resilience despite Paris Attacks, Other Geopolitical Risks."Los Angeles Times. Los Angeles Times, 20 Nov. 2015. Web. 21 Nov. 2015.
  • [5] "The Real Reason Stocks Are Up After the Paris Terror Attacks." Time. Time, 18 Nov. 2015. Web. 21 Nov. 2015.
  • [6] Stubbington, Tommy, Chiara Albanese, and Georgi Kantchev. "Markets, Less Shaken, Look Beyond Terrorist Attacks." WSJ. Wall Street Journal, 16 Nov. 2015. Web. 21 Nov. 2015.

Holden Stein November 22, 2015 Fossil announced today that it is going through with a large-scale acquisition of the company, Misfit. Misfit is being bought out for $260 million. While Misfit is not a direct competitor to Fossil, the acquisition would be would allow the company to widen its target market by including mid-priced accessories. In addition to selling mid-priced sunglasses and watches, Fossil would now have the ability to sell fitness accessories, such as wristband activity trackers. Fossil acquisition of Misfit has reaped many benefits for the accessory company. For one, this opportunity gives Fossil a chance to emerge out of the dreaded “mid-market” and gives the company a chance to target a specific market group or income range. The resulting increase in margins would allow the company to focus on more niche products that are still growing in demand at the moment. Furthermore, Fossil made a great move because it could potentially create a revenue synergy by consolidating the two brands. The power of Fossil’s brand could highlight Misfits proprietary technology and allow Fossil to sell more of the technology and accessory products than Misfit could have sold by itself. Overall, the latest M&A deal demonstrates a few signals going forward. First of all, the big year for M&A shows no signs of slowing down. Companies in this economy are constantly seeking competitive advantages within their market. Even “classic” brands like Fossil are ready to spin their traditional products when synergies and increased revenues are at stake. Fossil acquisition of Misfit allowed the company to expand its product line, diversify its product offerings, and ultimately capitalize on alternative markets. Sources:
  • http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-11-12/fossil-to-buy-wearable-maker-misfit-for-260-million
  • http://logonoid.com/fossil-logo/

Jia Jun Wu November 27, 2015 For months, Starwood Hotels & Resorts Worldwide juggled many offers from different hotel companies around the world. The company settled on an offer from Marriott, which agreed to acquire Starwood for $12.2 billion. This acquisition gave Marriott the designation as the largest hotel company in the world. With over 1.1 million rooms and 30 brands to provide all lodging needs, it hopes to capture the millennial population. By leveraging its size, it hopes to combat the rapid emergence of home-rental companies such as Airbnb, Inc. and to negotiate better fees with travel agencies such as Expedia. However, the company’s size can also obstruct its lofty goals. Although it would not hold a significant portion of hotels in the United States at 15%, it would hold a significant proportion of hotel rooms in many major cities such as New York and Washington D.C. This can lead to the possibilities of anti-trust actions. Similarly, its market share in major cities in Europe and China raises anti-trust concerns. Additionally, other facets such as the combination similar brands and loyalty programs will need to be addressed. The deal is set to close in the middle of 2016. Sources:
  • http://www.wsj.com/articles/marriott-to-acquire-starwood-hotels-resorts-1447673866
  • http://www.reuters.com/article/2015/11/16/us-starwood-hotels-m-a-marriott-intnl-idUSKCN0T513N20151116#EwTRw3SmC4IqKwM0.97
