Jane Ng November 22, 2015 Oil prices have been sinking for the past year and a half. Major causes include the abundance of oil in the market that are oversupplied by the U.S. and other exporting countries unwilling to limit production, as well as the reduced demand of a more environmentally-conscious global population. The current price of oil is just above $40 per barrel, a low paralleled only by the price when the stock market crashed in 2009. Although easier on independent consumers and countries that depend on imported oil (chiefly European and Asian nations), the lower prices on gas generally result in an enormous capital loss for oil production companies and their respective countries’ economies. The central cause of the unstable oil prices across the globe is OPEC’s (13-nation oil cartel) unwillingness to reduce production to stabilize the markets. Venezuela, Iran, and Algeria, all of which are OPEC members, have unsuccessfully been disputing with Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, and other gulf nations as to whether or not to intervene in the oversupplied market and collectively cut down production. Saudi Arabia, with greater resources, such as foreign currency reserves and clout in OPEC, has a similar policy to that of Russia. Russia, a large oil producer and exporter, loses approximately 2 billion U.S. dollars for every dollar drop per barrel, and economists predict its economy will shrink by 0.7% if prices do not recover. Yet, it will not lower production amounts because it cannot risk losing market shares and competitors taking the opportunity to raise their own production outputs. With oil producers around the world either increasing output, refusing to lower output, or lowering output too slowly, prices will continue to spiral downwards. Additionally, a rare type of occurrence that affects oil prices is terrorist attacks. After the Al-Qaeda attacks in New York City on 9/11, transportation-related expenses, on average, went down and resulted in a reduced demand for oil. A similar situation may also arise from the recent devastating attack on Paris by ISIS. Sources:
  • Bowler, Tim. "Falling Oil Prices: Who Are the Winners and Losers? - BBC News." BBC News. BBC News, 19 Jan. 2015. Web. 20 Nov. 2015. <http://www.bbc.com/news/business-29643612>.
  • Krauss, Clifford. "Oil Prices: What’s Behind the Drop? Simple Economics." The New York Times. The New York Times, 05 Oct. 2015. Web. 20 Nov. 2015. <http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/business/energy-environment/oil-prices.html?_r=0>.
  • "US Oil for December Delivery Settles at $40.39 a Barrel, down 0.4%." CNBC. Reuters, 20 Nov. 2015. Web. 21 Nov. 2015. <http://www.cnbc.com/2015/11/19/oil-traders-prepare-for-next-big-price-drop-in-march-2016.html>.
  • "Oil Price: Why It Could Collapse to $20 a Barrel." The Week UK. The Week UK, 20 Nov. 2015. Web. 20 Nov. 2015. <http://www.theweek.co.uk/oil-price/60838/oil-price-why-it-could-collapse-to-20-a-barrel>.

Chris Angelidis December 5, 2015 Each day, thousands of Syrians flee their homes due to continuous violence and conflict. Since 2011, Syria has been torn in civil war. Complicating matters further, foreign groups and countries with vested interests in the outcome of the war have gotten involved as well. In total, the powers in the war include the Syrian government, Syrian rebels, ISIS, Hezbollah, Kurdish freedom fighters, France, America, and Russia. Within a single country, a war for democracy, freedom, religion, and influence rages. Civilians are literally caught in the middle of this as the majority of fighting occurs within the densely populated cities. Government forces systematically cut off food, water, and power supplies to the cities to discourage rebels. Moreover, many of the factions are known to systematically kidnap, torture, rape, and murder citizens as a means of extracting information and oppressing the masses. Since the beginning of the war, approximately 30,000 civilians have died in the crossfire. Migrants fleeing from these appalling conditions typically head for Turkey. Once across the border, they zigzag through the country to avoid detection. They primarily travel towards Ankara, to Istanbul, to the Mediterranean coast, where they pay smugglers approximately 800 euros to take them to any one of the Greek, Dodecanese islands. From there, they head towards Athens to travel by air to larger European countries or the Americas. Those who lack the connections or the resources to obtain or counterfeit ID’s, must travel by foot, bus, and car across Europe. For the majority of these refugees, the ultimate goal is the Czech Republic, Hungary, Germany, France, and the U.K. Migrant rates across Europe as a whole have increased by as much as 750%. This drastic change has overwhelmed small economies such as Greece and Italy from where migrants typically enter Europe. As many as 300,000—over 4 times the native population—can enter an island over the course of a month. These islands lack the necessary housing, electricity, food, and water, to care for the migrants. Moreover, refugees are typically ill received on these islands as their presence hurts the local tourism industry and strains their already limited infrastructure. Clearly these victims cannot be sent back to the wasteland they once called home, and, as such, a more formalized process of migration must be created in order to facilitate this journey while at the same time protecting locals from possible repercussions. Sources:
  • Anna Triandafyllidou and Thanos Maroukis. Migrant Smuggling. (April 2012) Palgrave. Macmillan. 4 November 2015.
  • Kakissis, Joanna. "The Migrant Crisis on Greece’s Islands." Editorial. Migrant Crisis on Greece’s Islands" 22 May 2015: n. pg. The New Yorker. The New Yorker, 22 May 2015. Web. 14 Nov. 2015.
  • Rodgers, Lucy, David Gritten, James Offer, and Patrick Asare. "Syria: The Story of the Conflict BBC News." BBC News. BBC, 9 Oct. 2015. Web. 14 Nov. 2015.

Matthew Lam December 1, 2015 In today’s generation, ad-blocking programs have become an essential part of many people’s web experience. We are often bombarded with many advertisements that surround the webpage we are viewing, whether it be watching a YouTube video or reading a news article. As an immediate response, we download ad-blockers to our web browsers to prevent such advertisements from appearing on our screen. Because of the increased presence of ad-blockers, many ad-based online companies have had decreased viewership. Yahoo has responded to these ad-blockers by preventing email users from accessing their emails unless they turn off the ad-blocking software. The company claims to be testing a “new product experience,” but Yahoo relies heavily on revenue from these advertisements to provide its free email services to users. Other companies such as Apple and Google have developed alternative strategies to combat the age of ad-blocking software. Apple has allowed its iOS users to use third party ad-blocking software that blocks all ads except those that belong to Apple. Meanwhile, Google is beginning to offer a paid YouTube subscription that would remove all the ads from videos and the actual website. Advocates for ad-blocking software argue that it allows users to have a better web experience by clearing up the page and using less data on their phone bills. Ad-blockers can prevent advertisers from tracking people’s search history and are also thought to protect users from getting malware that is embedded in some advertisements. In 2014, Yahoo admitted that their advertisements were infected with malware/viruses for four straight days. Sources:
  • http://www.bbc.com/news/technology-34899575
  • http://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/624/cpsprodpb/13B2A/production/_86828608_yahoomail.jpg

By: Chandrapaul Latchman

January 25, 2015

McDonald’s has a serious problem on its hands. People like us, the “millennials,” don’t care for it too much.  I won’t try to bombard you with declining revenue figures or meat safety scandals in China and whatnot but I do think we should analyze the real issue here. And that’s about our view of fast food and the direct correlation with the rise of fast casual restaurants.

First I’ll introduce both, give an explanation about how they have been able to make enormous profits, and outline future prospects, all with respect to why it happened.

Okay folks, so what is fast food or as folks in the biz like to call it “Quick Service Restaurants (QSRs)?”  The definition is a restaurant that offers competitively priced food in a timely manner. How did they end up being so successful in the US? It’s not a surprise… because they were cheap! And from the 1970s-1990s that’s all that mattered. No one really knew how bad the food was for them; they just ate it because it was cheap and tasted pretty good. And that same thing is happening abroad in China and other rapidly growing economies. That’s why Mcdonald’s and YUM! Brands (KFC, Taco Bell, Pizza Hut) are consistently rolling in dough. While the US market is steadily declining, international profits for these companies are only rising.

A major part of this decline has to do with the emergence of the Fast Casual segment. This segment falls between fast food and casual dining. The biggest players as of early 2015 are Chipotle Mexican Grill and Panera Bread. And you know what? Millennials freaking love them! That’s where all your profits are going to, Mcdonalds and KFC! No one wants your greasy, fried, unhealthy, unappetizing food of yesteryear when we can have freshly cooked, wholesome meals for just a few bucks more in about the same time. Of course we can look at “Supersize Me” a documentary that really put McDonald’s under the microscope, but I believe that the root cause of the decline of all the fast food players in the US Market has to do with the emergence of fast casual options and a willingness to spend a little more to get a lot more (in terms of nutrition and atmosphere).

So what do I think will happen in the future? Well, the huge Quick Service Restaurants will soon dominate more of the international world with their current product offerings. I think, however, that the more important goal is to see how they will respond to the seriousness of fast casual dining by hopefully changing menu items and food supply sources.  My bet is for fast casual to dominate the US market in a matter of 5 years. They will be the largest players in the segment because if millennials like it today, they’re sure to be lifelong customers. McDonald’s, you better come up with a vegan Big Mac, and fast!

Jaehan Jeong

January 31, 2015

Steve Jobs has become the idol for our generation. With the rising tuitions, people doubt the true value of college education, and high unemployment rates around the world swell the fear of uncertainty. Consequently, numerous young entrepreneurs aspire to be the next Steve Jobs.

Jordan Casey is a fifteen year old software developer from Ireland who sold 50,000 units of Alien Ball (Mobile game) since 2012. Known as “Europe’s youngest chief executive,” Mr. Casey was invited as a keynote speaker for a conference in Spain to inspire young Europeans by showing them what he has achieved despite the gruesome European economy. Even though the ultimate root of motivation is from one-self, considering “Spain’s oppressively high youth unemployment -52% at the end of year 2014,” it would be greatly encouraging for the distressed youth in Spain to see an exemplary entrepreneurs like Mr. Casey.

Another young entrepreneur at the conference, Luis Ivan Cuende, 19, emphasized the immense gap between theoretical education system and the labor market. He argued that education system in Spain is ran by “people stuck in the past” and “a teacher who knew nothing about computing and was about to retire,” contributing to the historically high unemployment rate in Spain. Because of Spain’s alarming economic condition, people are quickly identifying their problems and openly discussing ways to address the known problems. Seeing the youthful entrepreneurs taking the initiative is truly inspiring.

Mr. Casey closes with his doubts on the present education system. “I really don’t see what university could teach me that I can’t learn for free immediately,” he said. “There are a lot of skills that you can learn yourself and just by using the Internet.” Of course, not everyone becomes a millionaire without a college diploma. However, it’s a question worth asking ourselves: “Is college education really enough to prepare us for our future?”

In recent years, prestigious institutions including Harvard, MIT, and Columbia University have opened up free online classes for anyone willing to learn the material. With the equalizing playing fields provided by the internet, competition is multiplying daily. And only the people willing to take advantages of these opportunities, just lik entrepreneurs, will stay competitive in this globalized world.

By: Phil Chen

January 25, 2015

The state and/or the health of countries across the globe have come to a seemingly new era of definition of emerging issues with constant implications brought upon the latter and the former. It can be said that the state of the world economy is, to some extent, better than it was during the financial crisis in 2008 seven years ago. Nonetheless, action is still being taken to respond, act and heal not only the flaws and weaknesses of the health of a variety of sovereign, as well as other, nations alike but also in the aspirations, needs and wants of the parts of the global picture in its entirety.

In the onset of contemporary outbursts such as the trending decline in oil prices to the central banks of Denmark and Canada cutting rates soon after the Swiss Bank letting the franc trade freely, are some examples of this period of unprecedented uncertainty that affects almost all countries now and in the looming time to come. As for contemporary highlights to take into account, is the situation occurring in Europe.

Falling oil prices have been the story throughout major countries but deflation especially for Europe. Due to a sense of the effect of plummeting oil prices that are a more of a predicament to the EU than the United States, Mario Draghi and The European Central Bank are taking measures to alleviate deflationary pressures by implementing its quantitative easing program that amounts to at least $1.1 trillion euros against the possibility of a “deflationary spiral” as noted from a relevant article by Jeff Black of Bloomberg LP. Further alarming indications include the fact that the euro has tumbled a month ago to it’s lowest versus the dollar in nearly a decade. Unprecedented times has been answered by unprecedented measures as Europe at this very moment lags behind the rest of the world.

The United States on the other hand has a better picture than Europe but too comes with it’s own flaws. A stronger U.S dollar in addition to the apparent advance in U.S Stocks as noted by the S&P 500 seemingly in response to the ECB Stimulus along with the Dow Jones has proved nothing but positive. The U.S Jobless Claims Report has gone done by close to ten-thousand, the unemployment rate down and a reinvigorating State of the Union Address add on to this positive yet sentimental aggregate. This may, ultimately and presumably, not be the case.

Various and disparate interpretations presume that the best or even the worst has yet to come. The future is full of uncertainty. “For me, QE is not an unmitigated positive or negative. It’s going to have a profound impact on all aspects of our business model and we just have to adapt to it and we have been doing that over the last 2 years” says Anshu Jain, Co-Management of the Management Board, Deutsche Bank. Changing times sometimes requires changing tactics. Europe and the world still awaits the outcome and subsequent policies of the elections in Greece to the aspirations of disseminating risk in the EU.

Even at a comparably better state, the U.S has it’s shortcomings as well. Despite having reached record history low UE rates, wage inflation tells another story. Another version of the unemployment rate, the U-6 has lead several to believe that unemployment is still a few points higher now to that of 2008. The Federal Reserve is hesitant in its intentions to raise interest rates in a superficially growing American economy and many can only assume when that will occur. On and on, the parallels between global and domestic risk only seems to leave unanswered questions where, presumably, time and anticipation may only prove to be the answer.

From the prospects of Davos 2015 to central banks to countries responding across the world, provisional projections are only a piece of the whole pie that is summarized by the paradox between validity and likelihood during changing times and the shifting paradigms in planning for the future. “To some extent the ecb is taking some quite some time in putting this in place and in the meantime deflationary pressures has been building” says the director of Macquarie Private Wealth. Indeed too the United States faces possible issues in the near future. The incoming future, still full of uncertainty as well as interdependency, must not lend a blind eye to the insurgence of the global market and global risk, for years to come.

Layanah Nsouli September 26, 2016 The Dodd-Frank Act of 2010 has brought greater regulation across the financial services industry. However, the recent Wells Fargo scandal has called into question the efficacy and impact of Dodd-Frank reforms. Earlier this month, Wells Fargo was charged with creating over 2 million fake accounts in an attempt to meet aggressive sales quotas. The bank has agreed to pay a $185 million settlement and has fired 5,300 employees in the aftermath of the scandal. In Janet Yellen’s upcoming meeting with the House Financial Services Committee, this will likely be one of the issues brought up in the discussion of the Fed’s supervision and regulation arms. In addition, Wells Fargo CEO, John Stumpf, will be asked to testify at a hearing scheduled with the House of Financial Services Committee later this week. The upcoming supervision hearing was introduced by Dodd-Frank, however it is important to note that it lacks a key player. Under the same reform that mandated the hearings, the president was required to appoint a Vice Chairman for Supervision. Since the Obama administration has failed to select someone to this position, Janet Yellen is taking over this role. Although Yellen's meeting with the House of Financial Services Committee will be centered around regulation concerns, it is likely that there will be continued pressure for rate hikes by the end of the year. Source:

The world’s largest diamond producer is expecting to extract 4.5 million carats a year as it turns its focus away from its other assets to focus on its diamond business. Amira Fleyshmakher October 11, 2016 By the year 2020, the United States and the European Union are planning to finalize long-standing negotiations for a new trade agreement. TTIP, or the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, will boost the economies of the U.S and the E.U by removing or reducing barriers to trade and foreign investment. If an agreement is reached, the deal will lead to a significant growth in trade between the two regions, where smaller corporations will gain an opportunity to compete in the global market and consumers will enjoy a cheaper, greater variety of goods. Since tariffs imposed by the two sides are already relatively low, the bigger gains would be obtained through the reduction of non-tariff barriers, particularly from regulatory cooperation. In this context, firms on both sides of the Atlantic will adhere to the same regulatory principles, which would consequently reduce overall trade costs. However, while a free trade agreement may sound appealing from a theoretical perspective, many related issues have resulted in great controversy and opposition. First, the European Union is concerned that its current food quality standards and consumer protection policies would be weakened if the EU attempts to align its standards with those of the U.S. There is also concern on both sides that the partnership would inevitably result in growing competition, thereby causing workers to lose their jobs to competing foreign sectors. Many have criticized the negotiations for lack of transparency, and even more so for the introduction of the ISDS (Investor-State-Dispute-Settlement), a system that would grant foreign investors the right to sue European states if they believe that EU measures have damaged their investments. Evidently, there is much to be gained from the trade agreement but also much to be lost. It is certainly a difficult task to reach a comprehensive plan that would satisfy both sides, but the final implications will be well worth the effort. Just like NAFTA had been heavily disputed during its initial stages, the results proved to be much more beneficial than expected, and TTIP has the potential to create the same effect. Sources:
  • http://www.bbc.com/news/business-32691589
  • https://stop-ttip.org/what-is-the-problem-ttip-ceta/
data.post_title: TTIP: Is Free Trade Good for the U.S and the E.U?

Adam Su October 28, 2016 Earlier this month, Saudi Arabia announced that it will sell $17.5 billion dollars in bonds to foreign investors. This announcement comes after a year of especially low oil prices compared to the last 15 years. Although oil prices have rebounded to $51.30 a barrel since they dipped as low as $30, the current price still sits close to the export’s 13-year low. Forecasters have predicted a more substantial amount of economic growth for the United States economy since the 2016 presidential election. While economists expected 2.2% economic growth in 2017 prior to the presidential election, they now expect 2.4% economic growth for the year. Similarly, prior to the election, economic growth for 2018 was expected to be 2.0% in contrast to predictions of 2.5% today.

Source: HuffingtonPost

Many of these improved economic growth predictions stem from the promises that President Trump has made to reduce business regulation, reform a tax code that businesses perceive as oppressive, and put a large infrastructure package into place.  These improved economic growth predictions for the next two years help explain the great performance of stock and bond markets. Economists believe that a positive growth cycle could continue so long as optimism about the economy continues on its current path. However, economists expect growth to fall back to 2.1% in 2019 and thereafter. This expected rate of growth is similar to that which was expected prior to the 2016 presidential election.  It can be attributed to the different factors that fuel short-term and long-term growth. Growth in infrastructure spending would put many people back to work for the time being, which would strengthen the economy, and an increase in the deficit would provide for more spending, which would strengthen the economy, but these are only temporary fixes. There are alternatives -- actual and substantial tax reform, simplifying regulation that helps companies operate more efficiently -- that would help give economists reason to believe there will be more growth in 2019 and beyond, but they feel uncertain about how much the current erratic presidential administration will actually be able to accomplish, and so they sit and wait to prognosticate as more is revealed. Source:

Chris Angelidis October 11, 2016 After years of economic hardship, the Greek government believes that the country is finally on track to recovery. Since the economic crisis started in 2010, the national economy has shrunk by over 25%, taking a toll on the living standards of the general population. Taxes have gone up and retirees have experienced pension cuts. The unemployment rate is over 20% and tens of thousands citizens have lost their homes. The public is fed up with suffering from austerity measures and yet for economic recovery, economists agree that it will take years of strict measures to regain stability. Greece’s 2017 economic plan forecasts that the economy will continue to contract across the end of 2016 and will begin to recover in 2017, growing by a reassuring 2.7%. This is primarily because the market hates uncertainty—and this was most certainly an unconventional election. Additionally, stocks have historically gone down the day after Election Day, regardless of a Democrat/Republican win or a re-elected president. By early Wednesday morning, the S&P 500 Index and the Dow Jones Industrial Average were both down about 2.5 percent. These major indexes were flat when the market opened. And by the end of the day, the S&P 500 and the Dow were actually up 1.11 percent and 1.4 percent, respectively. On Thursday, the Dow rose 218 points, closing at a record high for the second day in a row. The market and its participants seem to be getting over post-election jitters pretty quickly. Source: politico.com. Republican candidate Donald Trump became the 45th President of the United States last Tuesday, winning 290 electoral votes and 60,072,551 popular votes. His opponent, Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton, collected 228 electoral votes and 60,467,601 popular votes. Can we expect the stock to keep rallying as Cabinet positions are selected and information about future economic and foreign policies are released? Perhaps. In conjunction with a Republican-controlled Congress, investors forecast that Trump will start to relax some of the strict yet necessary regulations the Obama administration put into place on financial services companies following the 2008 economic recession. Some critical factors that may affect the markets include Supreme Court nominations—namely late Justice Scalia’s key deciding seat—and Federal Reserve appointments. Furthermore, the President-Elect’s firm opposition to free trade has many investors and economists around the world worried. Severe consequences to our economy may ensue if significant issues arise with our current global trading partners. These repercussions could include rising prices for consumer goods and declining profits for domestic companies that export products abroad. Oh, and not to mention Trump’s “complimentary” wall from Mexico and his love/hate relationship with China also raise concerns that he could trigger a trade war with major collateral damage (e.g., plummeting stocks, weakened domestic workforce, and an overall economic meltdown). John Casella November 15, 2016 Last Sunday, November 6th, most of North America received a precious extra hour of sleep from Daylight Savings Time (DST). While this time shift might seem like a bonus, according to a JPMorgan Chase Institute report, it could hurt business sales across the country. This finding shows that consumer spending is directly linked to hours of sunlight, and businesses take a bigger hit when people adjust their clocks in the fall as opposed to when they do it in the spring. To support this theory, the JPMorgan Chase Institute gathered 380 million credit card and debit card transactions from 2.5 million Chase customers in two different cities: Los Angeles and Phoenix. The state of Arizona is unique because it does not follow daylight saving time, allowing the Phoenix consumer population to serve as the control group. In the spring, when daylight saving time results in longer hours with sunlight, Los Angeles has a 0.9% increase in daily card spending per capita when compared with Phoenix. However, when people reversed clocks in the fall, having less sunlight lead Los Angeles to a 3.5% decrease in daily card spending per capita in comparison to Phoenix's spending habits. This change was studied by matching the data in a time range from 30 days before DST, to 30 days after. Daylight savings time has faced much criticism lately because many people do not experience its benefits, and it is an outdated tradition that the United States perpetuates. However, it is unlikely that the US and Canada will abandon the long-standing practice. Source:
  • http://blogs.wsj.com/economics/2016/11/03/daylight-saving-time-may-be-bad-for-the-u-s-economy/
data.post_title: The Impact of Daylight Savings Time on Business

Jane Ng November 15, 2016 The international Korean tech company Samsung Electronics Co. acquired Viv Labs Inc., an Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology startup in the United States in October. Injong Rhee, Chief Technology Officer for Samsung’s mobile division, said Samsung would be developing Viv Labs AI technology for the Galaxy S8, whose release date was pushed to after the Mobile World Congress trade show to be held late February next year. New AI features could include a specialized button on the Galaxy S8 and an improvement on S Voice, a virtual assistant service introduced in 2012. Samsung is facing a great deal of pressure to produce a winning product especially after the $5 billion in losses and recalls of the exploding Galaxy Note 7. This AI hardware revamp will play a part in reclaiming Samsung’s brand reputation and smartphone customer base, and if successful, could be expanded into other products, including home appliances. Other AI technologies in mobile and electronic devices include Apple’s Siri, Microsoft’s Cortana, Amazon’s Alexa, and Google Assistant Service. These AI services include answering questions, organizing planners, and placing orders for Ubers or pizza. Samsung is not quite the major player in this market category, but it is trying to make its comeback with AI. Injong Rhee stated that the Galaxy S8’s new tech would be significantly differentiated from that of its competition. However, this attempt at innovation might be offset by the continued mystery surrounding the overheating of the Note 7. Source:
  • http://www.wsj.com/articles/samsung-tests-button-for-improved-ai-feature-on-galaxy-s8-phone-1478516959

Kevin Savarese November 21, 2016 In the immediate aftermath of the 2016 presidential election, uncertainty became the focus of global markets. The Mexican Peso became the worst performer in emerging markets this year, and Dow futures were down 300 points at dawn on the morning of Wednesday, November 9th. These performances were the result of an election that left many in shock, and in a state of anticipation. While Donald Trump has made his views on some policies in the course of the election trail abundantly clear, his exact views on Wall Street are more difficult to pinpoint. Investors are unclear as to the extent to which Trump will regulate the banking industry, and how many of his promises are factual. In the remaining two months before the impending Trump presidency, however, it is useful to analyze his statements in order to gain an idea of where the banking industry may be headed. While more skeptical investors drove the Dow futures market down, many placed faith in banks. The day after the election, the KBW Nasdaq Bank Index had already risen 5.15%, and lenders such as JPMorgan Chase had risen to post crisis highs. Investment banks meanwhile, such as Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley soared, and Bank of America and Wells Fargo experienced sharp gains. Much of this immediate success for the banking industry comes as a direct result of Donald Trump’s repeated promise to repeal the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act, which was signed into law by the Obama administration in 2010 in response to the financial crisis in the late 2000s. Trump believes the Act to be overreaching and unnecessary, stating that “The banks aren’t loaning money to people that need it… The regulators are running the banks.” With rolled back regulations across the industry, firms will be theoretically freer to release capital or increase lending. While many see this as a necessary step in driving GDP growth, others are more skeptical. In their analysis of possible rollbacks of Dodd-Frank, Moody’s Investors Services states that “While a reduction in regulatory compliance costs would bolster bank earnings, reduced oversight and a roll-back of requirements would also result in a weakening of banks’ capital and liquidity positions, a negative from a credit perspective.” The effects of Trump’s repealing of Dodd-Frank are still the subject of pure speculation, but lessened regulation leads to fears of a repeat of the 2007-2008 financial crisis if banks immediately return to their old ways. While Trump whole-heartedly advocates the repeal of Dodd-Frank, he has expressed his interest in a modern-day version of the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933, which prohibits commercial banks from engaging in the investment business. Signing this Act back into law could potentially negate any effect provided by phasing out Dodd-Frank, and would ironically bring back the regulation repealed by Bill Clinton in 1999. In a similar vain to regulating banks, Donald Trump has stated, “I know Wall Street. I know the people on Wall Street… I’m not going to let Wall Street get away with murder. Wall Street has caused tremendous problems for us.” He also acknowledged that “the hedge fund guys are getting away with murder… They’re paying nothing, and its ridiculous.” While Trump’s campaign would suggest lenient times for banks, his statements suggest otherwise. The frequent recognition of the Wall Street problem shows that Trump may not be willing to sweep it under the carpet, but may not know the exact method to go about doing as such. Donald Trump may be a successful businessman, but his lack of conviction and possible conformance to our new Republican controlled government may mean that none of the regulation he acknowledged as needed will actually happen. Once again, at this point in time a mere outsider can do nothing except speculate as to what the future holds for the banking industry, but perhaps in the meantime it might be best to heed by the advice of Federal Reserve Board Chair Janet Yellen who stated this week that she would “certainly not want to see all the improvements that we have put in place, I wouldn’t want to see the clock turned back on those because I do think they are important in diminishing the odds of another financial crisis.” Sources:

Katherine Virgino November 21, 2016 American consumers are no longer waiting until ‘the night before Christmas’ to begin their holiday shopping. While holiday sales for 2016 are expected to increase by 3.6 percent according to the National Retail Federation (NRF), more consumers than ever before are participating in pre-holiday spending. A survey conducted by the NRF reveals that 41% of Americans have already started buying gifts well in advance of November’s much awaited Black Friday and Cyber Monday sales. Another 41.4% of consumers will begin to start buying gifts in the month of November alone. Interestingly, this same survey also reveals that consumers are equally spending their money in both non-stores, such as online marketplaces, and iconic well-decorated department stores alike. Online sales are expected to increase 7-10% annually, and discount stores, like Marshall’s and TJ Maxx of the TJX chain, have already seen sales growth in the beginning of the 2016 fourth quarter (WSJ). Consumer spending continues to be a vital input of aggregate metrics, such as the much-important gross domestic product (GDP). As an investment indicator and economic variable, increased consumer spending is reflective of recent improvement in job growth and household finances. On the other hand, noting the increase in non-store sales show growth in financial freedoms of millennials currently entering into the job market. Belonging to the ‘millennial’ market segment myself, I can positively affirm this relationship, as more of my friends and peers are finding full-time work and are looking to express their hard-earned freedoms. Overall, this increased consumer enthusiasm reflects a healthy economy and positive growth for the future, and may possibly contribute to expected increased Federal funds rates at the December 14th FOMC meeting. Sources:

  • http://www.wsj.com/articles/shoppers-ramp-up-spending-ahead-of-key-holiday-shopping-season-1479226203

Layanah Nsouli November 6, 2016 Oracle has announced that its acquisition of NetSuite is set to close on Monday, November 7th. The acquisition will allow Oracle to expand its Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), Customer Relationship Management (CRM), and Supply Chain Management (SCM) software arms, three departments in which NetSuite excels. The deal was set to close at least a month earlier, but was set back by complications from NetSuite’s largest institutional shareholder, T. Rowe Price Group, which holds 14.4 million shares of the soon to be acquired company. The investment firm claimed that the offer price of $109 per share was too low. However, it was soon revealed that the firm was concerned with the conflict of interest from Oracle executive chairman, Larry Ellison, who held a large number of shares in NetSuite. In order to rectify this problem, the company held a vote that excluded the chairman in order to decide if the deal would be executed. After successful completion of the secondary voting process. the $9.3 billion deal led to a 6% increase in NetSuite share price. Sources:

Karan Chachlani May 2, 2016 Since 2003, Apple’s earnings have been growing substantially, with the tech behemoth rolling out new products every single year. Ranging from the iPod to the iPhone to the iPad, Apple has been generating tens of billions of dollars every quarter. But just recently, Apple announced that its revenue for its first fiscal quarter, which ended in March, declined 13% to $50.6 billion. This is the first ever instance in 13 years in which the company has suffered a decline in revenue. A possible reason for this decline is that the newest iPhone released by Apple on March 31st, the iPhone SE, popped up in the markets too late to be counted in the quarterly report. Furthermore, with more people becoming Google Android users, Apple’s competition remains as strong as ever. In addition, Apple reached its apex in sales when it introduced the iPhone 6 to the world, a model that was literally a growth in the phone’s model and technological prowess. The iPhone 6S that subsequently released was very similar to the previous model. Wall Street analysts say that it makes sense that Apple had its first decline in revenue, as big tech companies can only bring about so many new products and ideas. However, this is probably just a temporary “pause,” as Apple CEO, Tim Cook, says. “This, too, shall pass. The future of Apple is very bright.” This view will probably come to fruition at the end of the current quarter, when sales from the new iPhone, along with the new iPad, will be counted. Furthermore, if Apple maintains its tradition of introducing a completely brand new iPhone every 2 years, then the iPhone 7 should put Apple back on its path to sustained growth. Surely the Apple innovators currently sitting in Silicon Valley will now be more vehement in making sure of that. Source:

Andrey Troegubov May 2, 2016 Business in Germany, as many travelers have found out this week, is not as usual. Public sector strikes in Germany’s many airports have caused more than a 1,000 flights to be canceled affecting as many as 89,000 travelers who were flying out of, or had a layover, in Frankfurt, Cologne and, Dusseldorf. The strikes, were carried out by ground services, security, fire safety and check-in staff, who staged a walk-out in order to assist the Union in their continuing battle against Lufthsana, Germany’s largest airline operator. The workers have been in conflict with the airline giant over pay and early retirement provisions. Across Germany, these walk-outs were carried out into various industries, including the metals and electrical industries where close to 100,000 workers participated. In the southwestern state of Baden-Wuerttemberg, the home of car brands Porsche and Mercedes, more than 37,000 workers from more than 150 companies joined walkouts on Friday. The unions had initially demanded a pay hike of 6 percent for the next 12 months while public sector employers had offered a wage increase of 3 percent over two years. Though a deal was reached on Friday, April 29th; it includes a pay hike of 2.4 percent for this year, starting retroactively on March 1, and another increase of 2.35 percent starting next February. It is interesting to note that, in France many are also protesting similar issues, including a labor reform, which many say, will put French workers in a worse position with less protections and less benefits at a time when the French unemployment rate is rising. It is comforting to see that the German government took action so quickly in order to reach a concession with it’s citizens. Sources:

Anna Chen March 12, 2016 Shake Shack released its fourth quarter earnings after the markets closed on Monday, March 7th with earnings per share of $0.08 – beating analysts’ estimates by one cent. The fast- casual burger chain also reported revenue of $51.06 million, an increase of 46.8% from the previous year and ahead of the estimates of $50.44 million. However, these positive numbers did not stop Shake Shack’s stock from dropping 8% in after-hours trading on Monday. Shares of Shake Shack closed at $42.23 on Monday, and dropped to $39.02 in the hours after the release of the Q4 report. Investors are put off by the growth projection for stores that have been open for at least 2 years. The expected rate of 2.5% to 3% is a substantial slowdown compared to the 13.3% of 2015 at those same stores. Pressure on this fast-growing burger chain’s stock will remain high given its extremely high valuation. Shake Shack’s stock has been on a roller coaster ride since its IPO on January 29, 2015, growing to a high of $96.75 last May and then declining closer to its initial price. This small yet volatile company has investors on edge, as seen by the reactions to its Q4 earnings. While it may not reach another year of 13% growth, the 2.5% to 3% estimate seems conservative, especially with Shake Shack’s new menu addition, the ChickenShack. Additionally, its plans to open 14 new company-operated restaurants in the U.S. in 2016 would increase its location count by nearly a third. Sources:

Erynn Hughes March 28, 2016 One of the most important principles to remember when making journal entries in accounting is how to record assets that cannot be seen or touched. These types of resources are known as intangibles, and include patents, intellectual property, trademarks, goodwill, client lists, and even franchise agreements. The calculation of assigning value on these materials is complex and susceptible to change. For this reason, U.S. companies don’t record these items on their books as assets under current accounting rules. From an investor’s perspective, the absence of intangibles inhibits their ability to accurately determine potential risks. Other analysts say they don’t require this specific value because the company’s stock price reveals the market’s assessment of these assets. In my opinion, I believe that it depends on how long the business has been in existence. High levels of consumer awareness and customer satisfaction truly affect a company's brand image. One cannot precisely select this amount as there are too many variables in play. A large number of businesses are investing more in nonphysical assets than tangible resources these days. Based on Carol Corrado’s research from 2014, companies’ investment in intangibles and physical assets totaled 14% and 10% of private sector’s GDP, respectively. The opposite was true 40 years earlier, when 13% went to tangibles and 9% to abstract materials. According to economist Leonard Nakamura of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, American corporations could have more than $8 trillion in intangible assets, which is almost half of the combined $17.9 trillion market capitalization of the S&P 500 index. The Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) is currently in the process of updating its rules to recognize the increasing significance of intangibles. Although it’s still in the early stages of development, this could lead to a new rule that requires companies to put these assets on their balance sheet. They will no longer underrepresent their book value by accounting for (formerly) priceless, untouchable matter. A main issue that will influence this addition is whether its value will depend on how much it costs to create, or if managers have to estimate the fair value of these assets. The FASB also understands that it is much more difficult to measure the depreciating value of intangibles over time. If in fact an asset of this kind has a finite useful life, a company is required to amortize it—just as they would depreciate a physical asset’s value. At the end of each fiscal year, the income statement will reflect this decrease in an account called “amortization expense.” It is important to note that not all intangibles should be amortized if it continues to deliver economic value to a business indefinitely. In these cases, value should be periodically reviewed and adjusted to fluctuating conditions in a process known as “impairment.” This is where the FASB’s new rule would step in. Otherwise, “you’re leaving a lot to the imagination,” Corrado said. It is too soon to predict the future complications that may arise when a company inaccurately assigns value to its intangibles in response to this new principle. Sources:

Karan Chachlani March 8, 2016 The U.S. government has been increasing its recent efforts on Internet surveillance. Just back in January, the government issued a court order for Apple to give the FBI internal access to the iPhone used by the shooter involved in the San Bernardino, California event. Since then, Apple has been engaged in a legal battle to fight this order, believing it to be a spark that will cause further violations of privacy by the government. Other major tech companies, including Microsoft, Google, Facebook, and Amazon, have announced their support for Apple in this matter. Microsoft in particular has begun to publicize its recent initiatives to combat cyber security issues and strengthen its involvement in cyber defense. For instance, Microsoft president, Brad Smith, announced in November the opening of the company’s state-of-the-art Cyber Defense Operations Center at its Redmond campus in Seattle. The division’s purpose is to detect cyber attacks and coordinate immediate responses. Since then, Smith has spoken at the RSA cyber security conference in San Francisco and hosted Secretary of Defense Ash Carter in a business meeting. Microsoft also reportedly invested $1 billion in 2015 to strengthen its defense systems. Smith’s belief is that only tech companies with immense resources, like Microsoft and Apple, and not the government, can effectively combat cyber security. Although there are several obstacles to overcome, Microsoft is not sparing any expenses in its effort to strengthen its cyber security actions. The company has placed a primary focus on stronger protections of its Cloud system, given the immense amount of information on the company’s network. Lastly, Microsoft should take into account that although breaches of privacy need to be prevented and confidentiality of personal information needs to be maintained, transparency in such terrorism investigations can be crucial in government prevention of future attacks. Source:

Matthew Choon March 24, 2016 There is no doubt that during a technological boom, corporations must be one step ahead of their competitors to survive. This may be the reason why Intel’s CEO, Brian Krzanich, is considering selling part of Intel’s venture capital unit (Intel Capital) as a potential source of capital. The company is instead looking to invest in American and Chinese-based startups in shifting technological fields. The potential sale of assets will provide Intel with more access and resources to focus on areas capable of complementing its business strategies. Intel’s previous concentration in PC’s is a stationary market. Today’s growing technology market is heavily focused on data centers, mobile devices, cloud computing, enterprise software, and the Internet. These tools dominate research and development focuses. Although Intel Capital plans to sell a hefty $1 billion worth of assets to secondary private equity firms, this strategy sacrifices just a small portion of Intel’s portfolio. Its total investments since 1991 amount to around $11.64 billion across 430 active investments. Headed by Wendell Brooks, the venture capital unit invested $514 million across 143 companies among sectors including digital media, security, and wearable technology last year. Intel has yet to make a comment about the move, but right after Brooks blogged about the continuation of $300 to $500 million worth of annual investments in tech startups in February, the share price rose 51 cents and has been increasing since. Current price per share is $32.34. Sources:

Maxine Lizaso March 28, 2016 Negative inflation rates in Japan are a looming issue for the country's economy. The Bank of Japan set a 2% inflation target in January 2013; 2% is considered healthy for most established economies. However, the Bank has struggled to achieve this goal since then. The Bank decided to set negative interest rates this past January, after European central banks cut their rates below zero and kept them there for over a year. The implementation of negative interest rates is seen as an act of desperation; the only option when others are exhausted or ineffective. This move is an effort to keep the economy from sliding back into stagnation and deflation. So here’s how it works. A central bank uses its deposit rate to influence how banks handle their reserves. When banks set negative rates, they want to dissuade lenders from keeping their money in accounts. They hope financial institutions will instead use that money to lend to individuals and businesses, putting more money into the economy and in turn contributing to inflation. Many economists expect the central bank to continue cutting the deposit rate, perhaps approaching the negative 0.75% in Switzerland. Even though the rates should serve them well in theory, in practice there are several risks to the policy. If banks make more customers pay to hold their money, lenders may end up losing a vital source of funding. In addition, Bloomberg says, “when banks absorb the cost of negative rates themselves, that squeezes the profit margin between their lending and deposit rates, and might make them even less willing to lend.” The Bank for International Settlements reported this to be the month of “great uncertainty”; if more and more banks use negative rates as a stimulus tool, the policy might ultimately lead to a “currency war” of competitive devaluations. In the 1600s, Hudson’s Bay Company opened as a fur trading post in Canada. As the company grew and expanded over time, it has become one of the oldest retail giants and acts as parent company to major retailers such as Lord & Taylor, Saks Fifth Avenue, Home Outfitters, and more. Recently, Hudson’s Bay’s Executive Chairman, Richard Baker, set his sights on a new acquisition: Neiman Marcus.

Soure: TheHuffingtonPost

Neiman Marcus currently has $4.9 billion in outstanding debt. At this point, the company has enough cash and credit to operate until the end of the fiscal year, but the debt is unsustainable. Hudson’s Bay is currently searching for a way to buy out Neiman Marcus, without acquiring its debt. Neiman has been faltering in the changing retail market. It is unable to compete with the competitive prices of retailers like Macy’s or Lord & Taylor and can not top the convenience of online retailers like Amazon. The company either needs to go through drastic changes to attract millennial shoppers, or consider its acquisition opportunities Sources:

Michal Sudo March 14, 2016 Recently, a number of Wall Street Journal articles, namely “Rising Global Debt and the Deflation Threat” and “Eurozone Slides back into Deflation” have shared the same gloomy prospect for the possible dangers now facing European markets. With the constant threat of a vicious deflationary cycle, people are cutting down on their purchases in fear of the uncertain economy, which in turn leads to lower profits for business and decreasing cash-flows to employees. In order to stimulate the economy, the European Central Bank (ECB) has lowered its interest rates to ensure that there is adequate money supply to prevent this deflationary spiral. One of the ECB’s primary strategies was the decrease in the deposit rate, the rate at which banks earn interest on money stored within the ECB, which currently sits at -0.03%.  This negative interest rate means that banks have to pay interest charges to the ECB for storing their money. This wasn’t the only tactic the ECB used to combat the threat of deflation. Over a year ago, the ECB embarked on their quantitative easing strategy. Despite the failure of the quantitative easing program and the current deflation, Simon Nixon of the Wall Street Journal believes “there is little evidence that current disinflation is feeding through to the kind of self-fulfilling deflationary spiral.” However, most carry more bleak outlooks because of the failure of Draghi’s quantitative easing program. The plan served as the primary strategy in efforts to  achieve the target inflationary rate of just below 2%, a prime inflation rate among all central banks. The philosophy behind the quantitative easing plan was that with the purchasing of government bonds and other safe assets, the ECB would effectively impact the interest rates. The large-scale demand for bonds would increase bond prices, which in turn would inversely affect interest rates. The resulting low interest rates would make it easier for businesses to borrow money, money that would eventually make its way into the equity market. While the reasoning is sound, the plan failed to reach its goal. Actually, 52 weeks into the program the Euro Stoxx index has dropped 16%. In their most recent meeting this past week, the ECB made a decision to drop the rate to -.04%, a more significant decrease than projected. With no surprise, the ECB implemented a shift in its bond-purchasing plan, from sixty billion to eighty billion euros a month. Additionally, instead of solely purchasing government bonds and safe assets, the ECB will begin to purchase corporate debt. By doing so, the ECB proved that it was willing to do whatever it takes to meet, if not beat, the anticipated inflation rate. However, the ECB will have to break the three-year trend of failing to meet inflation expectations. Sources:

Othilla Wlodarczyk March 8, 2016 “Make America Great Again.” The premise of Donald Trump’s campaign is that America has lost its greatness and he is the only one who can re-instill it. While his ability to do so is certainly questionable, it is difficult to judge whether or not America is doing as well as it was in the past. U.S. productivity growth has stalled, and while we know that Trump is ready to put on his cape and fly off to rescue the country, it may be best to pinpoint the actual cause of the lack of growth. J.P. Morgan Chase theorizes that the reason U.S. productivity growth has stalled is that the American workforce is less skilled than it used to be. According to J.P. Morgan and the San Francisco Federal Reserve, the labor quality of an average worker has steeply declined since 2008 along with college enrollment which has declined after peaking in 2011.  While some of the downward trend is cyclical and can be attributed to the recession, U.S. labor quality is actually lower than where it was in the 1940s. Another benchmark that J.P. Morgan economists Michael Feroli and Robert Mellman analyze in their report is worker productivity. According to their report, productivity has grown at only 0.7% annually over the past three years, a much lower growth compared to the average 2.9% growth between 1995 and 2005. The key in reversing this trend lies in the workforce’s ability to gain the skills and education necessary for the economy’s continued development. Sources:
  • http://blogs.wsj.com/economics/2016/02/29/how-a-less-skilled-american-workforce-may-be-holding-back-growth/
  • http://www.jobsnhire.com/articles/36770/20160303/less-skilled-american-workforce-holding-back-growth.htm

Stephen Esposito March 22, 2016 Starwood’s impending merger with Marriott International Inc., has been uprooted by a substantially higher offer from the newly prominent Anbang Insurance Group. Headquartered in Beijing, the 10-year old company has already acquired about $114 billion in assets. Anbang Insurance Group originally offered Starwood $76 per share or roughly $13 billion as opposed to Marriott’s deal for $65.33 per share or $11 billion. However, on March 18th, Starwood announced that Anbang Insurance raised their offer to $78 per share, a slight increase of about $200 million. If this deal were to go through, it would be the largest Chinese purchase of an American company. Although it has only 3.6% market share with respect to insurance companies in China, Anbang Insurance Group has large holdings outside the industry. Within the past few years, Anbang has proven itself to be one of the most driven and prominent international investors. In October 2014, Anbang purchased the renowned Waldorf Astoria hotel in New York City for $2 billion. Furthermore, less than a month before making its offer to Starwood, it purchased Strategic Hotels and Resorts Inc. for $6.5 billion from Blackstone Group LP. These huge purchases and recent interest in overseas companies from Chinese corporations is due to China’s slowing economy, as well as a slowly sinking Yuan value. If Starwood sells to Anbang, it will be required to pay a $400 million fee to the Marriott for backing out of their original deal. However, Marriott International Inc. has until March 28th to raise their offer. Despite the foreign pressures from Anbang, it is unlikely that the Marriott-Starwood deal will fall through. Marriott’s drive to become the largest hotel chain will likely supersede. Sources:

Amira Fleyshmakher January 20, 2016 Less than a week into the beginning 2016, Apple Inc. announced that it has purchased Emotient, a California-based startup that utilizes artificial intelligence (AI) technology in order to detect human emotions by reading and analyzing facial expressions. Emotient’s technology relies on deep learning, a process that requires programming artificial neural networks on enormous amounts of data and then directing them to analyze and make inferences about new data. By using this method, Emotient was able to acquire a patent for identifying approximately 100,000 facial images on a daily basis so that computers are better able to recognize and label different expressions. The Wall Street Journal first reported the news about the acquisition on Thursday, January 7th, though details regarding the deal were never disclosed. Emotient’s precise role and contributions to Apple therefore remain unclear, though several speculations have already been made to suggest possible ways in which Apple may be using its newly acquired artificial intelligence. One possibility is that Apple will partner up this technology with Siri, its personal assistant software that currently operates on human voice commands. If Siri is able to detect the user’s emotions, it could better tailor its responses. Another suggestion is that if Apple gathers sufficient and accurate information about the user’s mood, it could make adequate recommendations for the user to purchase other Apple products, such as movies, music, e-books, and more. So far, Emotient has gained a reputation within the advertising and marketing industries, where researchers have used the technology to learn about consumers’ preferences and get a sense of how customers feel about certain products. The improvement of image recognition has been a hot topic in Silicon Valley, where Apple and its various competitors have been investing heavily in artificial intelligence techniques. According to Tractica, a market intelligence firm that analyzes global market opportunities surrounding human interaction with technology, the market for AI systems for enterprise applications will increase from $202.5 million in 2015 to $11.1 billion by 2024, expanding at a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 56.1%. For now, users are anxious to find out how Apple will be using the new technology. Sources:

Anand Poonai January 10, 2016 1400 years have gone by and the prolonged sectarian division between Shiite and Sunni Muslim has recently taken a turn for the worst, leading to a Sunni-dominated Saudi Arabia’s official severing of ties with the predominantly Shiite Iran. What triggered Saudi Arabia’s rash decision were the events that followed after this past Sunday, when the Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, a Shiite cleric, was executed in Saudi Arabia. Not only was the Sheikh executed, but so were 47 other men who were suspected of being a part of Al Qaeda and partaking in terrorism-related activities. Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr outwardly criticized the Saudi royal family and was adamantly opposed to Sunni power. Seen as a high level threat to an already unstable Saudi government, Sheikh al-Nimr was accused of encouraging rebellions and violent protests, thus leading to his execution. The execution of the Shiite cleric has led to further heated and violent protests in Saudi Arabia. Iranian protestors stormed the Saudi embassy in Iran’s capital, Tehran, this past weekend. Molotov cocktails were thrown at the embassy and protestors ransacked the building, hoping to get revenge for the death of the Sheikh. Due to the severity of the situation, Saudi Arabia ordered Iranian officials to evacuate the country within the next 48 hours. The execution of the Shiite cleric seems to have further cemented the split between the Sunni and Shiite-supporting countries, thus supplementing greater tension in the Middle East. Predominantly Shiite countries, including Iraq are outraged by Saudi Arabia’s execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, for they believe the Sheikh was simply a peaceful dissident and wasn’t a threat to anyone. To the Shiite community’s dismay, Saudi Arabia and its Sunni allies have not spoken out against the execution. Geopolitical discrepancies and the recent involvement in proxy wars in Syria have undoubtedly been fueling the animosity between Saudi Arabia and Iran, and the recent executions, which has been the largest execution to have taken place in the Middle East for decades, has sealed the deal in terms of severed ties between the two nations. Anand Poonai January 10, 2016 1400 years have gone by and the prolonged sectarian division between Shiite and Sunni Muslim has recently taken a turn for the worst, leading to a Sunni-dominated Saudi Arabia’s official severing of ties with the predominantly Shiite Iran. What triggered Saudi Arabia’s rash decision were the events that followed after this past Sunday, when the Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, a Shiite cleric, was executed in Saudi Arabia. Not only was the Sheikh executed, but so were 47 other men who were suspected of being a part of Al Qaeda and partaking in terrorism-related activities. Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr outwardly criticized the Saudi royal family and was adamantly opposed to Sunni power. Seen as a high level threat to an already unstable Saudi government, Sheikh al-Nimr was accused of encouraging rebellions and violent protests, thus leading to his execution. The execution of the Shiite cleric has led to further heated and violent protests in Saudi Arabia. Iranian protestors stormed the Saudi embassy in Iran’s capital, Tehran, this past weekend. Molotov cocktails were thrown at the embassy and protestors ransacked the building, hoping to get revenge for the death of the Sheikh. Due to the severity of the situation, Saudi Arabia ordered Iranian officials to evacuate the country within the next 48 hours. The execution of the Shiite cleric seems to have further cemented the split between the Sunni and Shiite-supporting countries, thus supplementing greater tension in the Middle East. Predominantly Shiite countries, including Iraq are outraged by Saudi Arabia’s execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, for they believe the Sheikh was simply a peaceful dissident and wasn’t a threat to anyone. To the Shiite community’s dismay, Saudi Arabia and its Sunni allies have not spoken out against the execution. Geopolitical discrepancies and the recent involvement in proxy wars in Syria have undoubtedly been fueling the animosity between Saudi Arabia and Iran, and the recent executions, which has been the largest execution to have taken place in the Middle East for decades, has sealed the deal in terms of severed ties between the two nations. The Obama administration has been advocating for peace between the two nations, but as of now, the split between the two nations seems almost unchangeable. Sources:

Erynn Hughes January 10, 2016 Within the first week of the New Year, China’s stock market has already tumbled despite calculated measures employed to prevent rapid price changes. These recent developments alarm investors of possible instability and market decline, as experienced in the previous year. In 2015, China experienced huge stock market volatility, including a devaluation of its yuan currency, falling imports and exports, and a rising concern about nonperforming loans. In January, the Shanghai composite index started at a value of 3,350, rose to a high of 5,178 in June, and then fell to a low of 2,850 in August. In response to the downward trend, the Chinese central bank cut interest rates and regulators organized the purchase of shares with cash supplied by the central bank. After the crash during the summer—which resulted in trillions of dollars in losses—Chinese markets managed to recover in the last couple of months of 2015. But this stability did not last long going into the New Year. Introduced for the first time on January 4th, 2016, the circuit-breaker mechanism was just one of the numerous new rules initiated by Chinese regulators to limit volatility, guarantee stock trading functionality, and avoid irrational price swings. The concept of the circuit-breaker is that if the overall market index (CSI 300) experiences high volatility, then there must be something unusual in the market as a whole and so all trading must stop. Under this mechanism, trading in all stocks would be halted for 15 minutes if the CSI 300 index rises or falls by 5%, so as to let the investors “cool down.” After this short break, trading would resume; and if the market continues to rise or fall an additional 2% (for a daily total of +/-7%), then trading would cease for the entire day, as it did on January 4th. The drop on January 4th can be attributed to several factors: weak manufacturing figures, lower expectations for China’s GDP growth in 2016, lower credibility of official macro statistics, and even the implementation of the new circuit-breaker regulation. For the second time this week, trading in the Shanghai stock market suspended on January 7th after the markets reopened and losses dropped 7% in seconds. Chinese stocks initially traded for less than 30 minutes before entering the 15-minute break period. One of the unintended consequences of the circuit-breaker mechanism is that shareholders on the margins have an added incentive to sell stocks more quickly than ever before. The reason why this mechanism encourages investors to sell more (while initially aiming to limit losses) is because once the first breaker is reached too quickly, experts believe that investors use the cool down 15-minute period to line up additional sell orders. This creates more chaos as stockholders sell out of fear that they won’t be able to recover their investments before trading is stopped. Peter Lewis, Director of Peter Lewis Consulting, said, “People think this is a manipulated, distorted market.” Because the market is not open, Lewis thinks that foreign institutions will be very alarmed by the selling restrictions. Other rules that regulators intend to implement attempt to sharply decrease stock sales. In any three-month time period, major shareholders are allowed to unload only 1% of their holdings, and they must disclose their intentions at least 15 days in advance. In the first week of 2016, the CSI 300 index of companies listed in Shanghai and Shenzhen has already fallen 12%. Analysts expect further volatility in the Shanghai stock market in the coming months. In a recent survey conducted by CNNMoney, it found that most investing professionals listed China as the largest risk to U.S. stocks. The first Chinese market suspension of the year sparked a global selloff, causing losses of approximately 2% in the U.S. After the second stoppage, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 392 points, the Standard & Poor’s 500 dropped by 2.4%, and the Nasdaq decreased 3%. China recently held an emergency meeting on January 7th to suspend circuit-breakers effective the following day. Chief market analyst at The Lindsey Group Peter Boockvar believes that this decision will ease pressure on Chinese stocks in the short-run but won’t be a lasting solution to their mounting issues. John Casella January 23, 2016 With the extensive accessibility of mobile devices, much of your daily news is probably obtained through a screen. News outlets like CNN and the New York Times, along with social media platforms like Facebook and Twitter, have been able to capitalize on their strong online presence. With the release of iOS9 last September, Apple decided to put a built-in News app into its phones and tablets so that consumers could have easier access to top stories. The initiative has been greeted with mild success as over 100 publishing partners internationally have teamed up with the company. Despite this, there remains a disconnect: neither Apple nor the publishers know how many people are using Apple News. Inaccurate estimates can hinder the company’s ability to efficiently sell advertising and properly manage resources. Apple lets publishers retain 100% of revenue when they sell their own ads into the app, and retain 70% of revenue if Apple sells ads on their behalf. Despite this hindrance, the underestimated number has not interfered with the feature’s overall success; Apple boasts over 40 million users since September. Publishers remain hopeful about the situation and still see the potential success that Apple News could bring. Sources:

Matthew Choon January 20, 2016 Nike’s (NKE) earnings of $8.4 billion had exceeded analyst predictions in the first quarter of FY16, leaving investors hopeful for the brand’s performance to follow. In the second quarter, which ended November 30, 2015, the brand brought in $7.3 billion revenue, up 13% on a currency-neutral basis, with another $398 million coming from its subsidiary brand, Converse. Nike raked in $7.7 billion total, a 4.1% increase in year-over-year sales. Although the sales number fell just short of the Wall Street analyst consensus of $7.8 billion, Nike posted double-digit growth in all of its geographies and indicated a strong global demand for its products. The unfavorable foreign exchange rate impacted international revenue in most overseas markets. However, due to higher average selling prices and higher product input costs, gross margin increased 50 basis points to 45.6%. Net income increased 20% to $785 million and earnings-per-share increased 22% to $0.90. This may be attributed to its strong revenue growth, gross margin expansion, a lower tax rate, and a 1% decline in the weighted average diluted common shares outstanding. Reported sales were positive for all of the brand’s geographic segments, which include Japan, China, and North America. Nike’s largest segment, North America, saw a sales growth of $306 million, a 9.4% increase in year-to-year sales, to $3.5 billion total in the quarter. Nike’s peers, Sketchers (SKX) and Columbia Sportswear (COLM) acquired 39.4% and 23% of their sales from outside North America, posting record sales in third quarter of FY2015. In contrast, approximately 54% of Nike’s second quarter sales stemmed from international store, leaving CEO Mark Parker enthusiastic about the brand’s success: "Our strong Q2 growth and profitability show that Nike continues to drive real momentum through the Category Offense — by going deep with consumers by sport and serving them completely… We see tremendous opportunity ahead as we enter an Olympic and European Championships year with a full pipeline of inspiring innovation for athletes everywhere." Despite foreign currency hindrances, allotments for footwear and apparel orders from December 2015 through April 2016 are 15% higher than they were last year. Sources:
  • http://finance.yahoo.com/news/analyzing-nike-revenue-performance-fiscal-153115499.html

Anand Poonai February 22, 2016 At the crossroads of lifestyle and logistics, Uber has certainly reeled in an extensive user network through its innovative combination of a mobile platform and taxi service. Although Uber has certainly provided convenience and luxury to its 25 million users, many people have been unaware about the numerous governmental and industry challenges pitted against the legality of Uber’s services. In December 2014 and January 2015, two class action lawsuits were brought against Uber due to its false advertising practices. They argued that the company has been misleading its customers about its safety practices. Uber preaches that it is “industry leading” and “safer than a taxi”, but as it turns out, Uber hasn’t been checking off all the boxes regarding its safety criteria. Uber has been charging customers between $1 and $4.50 as a “Safe Rides Fee” in order to cover the costs of its driver’s background checks, vehicle safety inspections, and driving training. Meanwhile, Uber has failed to conduct national sex-offender registry and employment fingerprint identification. As a result, Uber has been legally obliged to rename its “Safe Rides Fee” to “Booking Fees”, as well prevent its use of superlatives when describing the features that it offers. As a result of recent allegations, Uber has agreed to pay a $28.5 million settlement to compensate for its false advertisements regarding safety. All Uber customers – including foreign users – who have used Uber services between January 1st, 2013 and January 31st, 2016, will be refunded approximately $0.82 directly to either their Uber accounts or credit cards. Although Uber has been facing intense media scrutiny over their falsified safety advertisements, paying out settlement fees has been a major relief. Uber has released a statement, saying, “We are glad to put these cases behind us and we will continue to invest in new technology and great customer services so that we can help improve safety in our cities.” Uber hopes to regain the trust of its consumers and provide enhanced services that will amplify the consumer experience. Sources:

  • https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2016/02/11/uber-is-about-to-pay-its-u-s-riders-28-5-million-heres-why/
  • http://techcrunch.com/2016/02/11/uber-proposes-28-5-million-settlement-over-safe-ride-fee-class-action-lawsuits/

Adam Su February 29, 2016 Would you sacrifice your freedom for your personal information? Many say yes because they are resolute in defending their privacy. Currently, there is much controversy regarding whether or not the government should force Apple to unlock the iPhone used by the San Bernardino terrorist. The San Bernardino terrorist’s iPhone may contain crucial information regarding the attack, such as whether or not accomplices were involved. The FBI is attempting to force Apple to create a “backdoor” to iPhones, which will allow the government to access private information. Apple executives, however, have the consumers’ interests in mind and state that this “backdoor” access violates their company’s privacy policy as well as people’s personal freedom. Additionally, if judges rule in favor of the FBI, many argue the case will likely serve as precedent for other cases of privacy violation. Those in favor of FBI access to such information consider this case to be an exception. Sources:

Chris Angelidis February 22, 2016 The sudden death of the highly conservative Justice Scalia has enormous implications on the 2016 Presidential Campaign and the Republican Party as a whole. Justice Scalia was appointed by President Ronald Reagan in 1986 with unanimous approval from the senate. Over the thirty years he spent in the Supreme Court, he was regarded as one of the “most prominent legal thinkers of his generation.” He was known for stringently interpreting the constitution with its original purpose in mind and famously voted against the recounting of the Florida votes in Bush v. Gore, as to not undermine Bush’s legitimacy as president. He was found dead of natural causes on February 13, 2016, in a luxury resort in western Texas. Justice Scalia’s death carries profound repercussions for the Republican Party and for the nation as a whole. Prior to Justice Scalia’s passing, the court held a Republican majority. To prevent that majority from disappearing, several prominent Republican figures have vowed to stop President Obama from appointing a new justice. Republican leaders are arguing that the next president should appoint someone in Scalia’s place despite the fact that ten months remains in Obama’s current term. Their argument stands on weak ground, however, as in the recent years, both President Eisenhower and President Reagan successfully appointed judges in the final months of their term. Furthermore, it would be the first time in recent history that a justice position remains vacant for over a year. Should Obama successfully appoint a democratic justice, it would mean the end of a republican reign in the court, and the beginning of a new era. 2016 will carry several pivotal court cases, including Whole Women’s Health v. Cole, which covers the legality of a Texan Law that would force about 75% of the states abortion clinics to close and Zubik v. Burwell, which questions Obamacare’s birth control mandate in religious-sponsored non-profit corporations. The fate of these cases lies with whoever is appointed to fill Justice Scalia’s shoes.   • http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/14/us/antonin-scalia-death.html
