Collin Chipetine February 24, 2016 A country torn apart by chaos and war. A regime that refuses to relent. An ally that may actually be an adversary. And now… a ceasefire? As of this past Saturday, Russia and the United States have agreed upon a cease-fire on the warfare in Syria in hopes of pushing towards peace after five years. However, since Russia maintains close ties with the Assad regime of Syria, it has the responsibility to not only end attacks on rebel groups, which don’t include “terrorist organizations” like the Islamic State group and Nusra Front, but also to insure its full cooperation with the United Nations to prevent any further attacks or airstrikes. Syria has just accepted this cease-fire, for a tentative two-week trial. Despite these promising events and the week-long proceedings of hearings held in Geneva between Putin and Obama, Russia’s guarantee of peace remains uncertain. Many members of the U.S. Pentagon consider Russia to be too great a potential adversary to ally with and are skeptical of Putin’s promise. Between the potential of dragging the United States further into the war in Syria and the avid bombing campaign launched by Russia only last year against CIA-funded rebels, many Pentagon officials are not optimistic about the cease-fire. Preparing for what they consider inevitable, they have prepared various contingencies for if the cease-fire is violated, including a potential game changer. The U.S. could provide the rebels with ground-to-air anti-aircraft weapons, which would escalate tensions dramatically. Regardless of what will happen as discussions continue in the remaining few months of President Obama’s presidency, the United States must follow appropriate foreign policy to prevent a greater conflict. Collin Chipetine February 24, 2016 A country torn apart by chaos and war. A regime that refuses to relent. An ally that may actually be an adversary. And now… a ceasefire? As of this past Saturday, Russia and the United States have agreed upon a cease-fire on the warfare in Syria in hopes of pushing towards peace after five years. However, since Russia maintains close ties with the Assad regime of Syria, it has the responsibility to not only end attacks on rebel groups, which don’t include “terrorist organizations” like the Islamic State group and Nusra Front, but also to insure its full cooperation with the United Nations to prevent any further attacks or airstrikes. Syria has just accepted this cease-fire, for a tentative two-week trial. Despite these promising events and the week-long proceedings of hearings held in Geneva between Putin and Obama, Russia’s guarantee of peace remains uncertain. Many members of the U.S. Pentagon consider Russia to be too great a potential adversary to ally with and are skeptical of Putin’s promise. Between the potential of dragging the United States further into the war in Syria and the avid bombing campaign launched by Russia only last year against CIA-funded rebels, many Pentagon officials are not optimistic about the cease-fire. Preparing for what they consider inevitable, they have prepared various contingencies for if the cease-fire is violated, including a potential game changer. The U.S. could provide the rebels with ground-to-air anti-aircraft weapons, which would escalate tensions dramatically. Regardless of what will happen as discussions continue in the remaining few months of President Obama’s presidency, the United States must follow appropriate foreign policy to prevent a greater conflict. Chynelle Menezes February 15, 2016 Venezuela's Oil Minister Eulogio Del Pino (L) and Saudi Arabia's Oil Minister Ali al-Naimi smile while they talk during a bilateral meeting at the Summit of South American-Arab Countries in Riyadh. (Source: Reuter) On February 7, 2016, Venezuelan oil minister Eulogio Del Pino met with Saudi Arabian oil minister Ali al-Naimi in Riyadh to discuss plans for stabilizing the global oil market. Del Pino is meeting with other crude oil producers, including Russia, Qatar, and Iran on a global tour to coordinate a meeting between the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) countries, which currently produce 40 percent of the world’s oil. Because oil production reached an all time high in January, Venezuela is attempting to convince OPEC leaders to cut down production in order to prop up prices. Saudi Arabia faces rising threats to its oil industry in U.S. shale production and Iranian sales. As shale gas production is a relatively young industry, the United States has not yet reformed its infrastructure and policy regulations to maximize its profits. However, the United States and its NAFTA partner, Canada are the two largest shale producers in the world and pose a future threat to Saudi oil dominance. At the same time, Iran is trying to recover its market share of crude oil, lost during the 2012 international sanctions. The sanctions were lifted in January and Iran immediately increased sales as rivals Saudi Arabia and Iraq increased supply. Iran is poised to add one million barrels a day to its production by the end of this year. Saudi Arabia is unlikely to agree to reduce production and raise prices, which could allow competitors to fill the demand and threaten its position as the world’s largest oil exporter. Sources:

Dzvinka Stefanyshyn February 22, 2016 As of August 2015, the global markets have been anything but steady. Offset by an oversupply of oil and economic unpredictability in China, many investors are flocking to any last remaining safe-haven assets, which leads to even greater turmoil in the markets. A few months ago, the Chinese decided to peg the Yuan to a basket of currencies as opposed to just the U.S. dollar, ultimately devaluing their currency. They believe that their currency is overvalued, and if the Federal Reserve is to raise interest rates that will drive up the dollar, the Yuan will soar even higher. However, as of mid-January, the People’s Bank of China has decided to once again peg the Yuan to the dollar. This move, though meant to shed positive light on the economy of China, has resulted in volatile trading. What the central bankers must be wary of is the dollar’s move in the global markets because any sharper rises could once again send the already weakened Chinese economy spiraling. Adjustments must be made to the nation’s monetary policy because the central bank’s intention to maintain the peg, and heavy intervention in the currency market could result in further capital draining. As the PBOC is trying to find the best route for its currency (the devaluation was meant to set the currency in line with market prices, but backfired), another factor may be helping the Chinese economy bounce back. As the currency is weakening, many Chinese banks have been heavily extending credit, hitting an all-time high in January. Additionally, the Chinese companies cut foreign-currency debt. As many claim that this increase in lending may provide a much-needed boost for the economy, several analysts are less hopeful. One reason is that January is usually the month in which banks reset their loan quotas, which prompts higher than usual borrowing. Chinese economists believe that the central bank ought to remain cautious with heavy borrowing, as economic growth has significantly slowed over the past several years. The borrowing is meant to provide liquidity for the domestic market, which it has. The PBOC has injected nearly 2 trillion Yuan worth of funds through its monetary tools. By the end of January, China’s M2 was 1.5% higher that then median forecasted by economists. Even as the PBOC did not cut reserve requirements for banks, capital outflow increased, which poses several concerns regarding upcoming short-term interest payments. Regardless, the Chinese will continue to closely monitor the forex market and adjust their monetary policy accordingly. Sources:

  • http://www.wsj.com/articles/china-favors-flexibility-in-managing-yuan-1455541059

Jane Ng February 14, 2016 An employee works on the assembly line producing the Ford Fiesta at a plant in Cuautitlan Izcalli, Mexico, in 2010. (Susana Gonzalez/Bloomberg News) Ford is expanding its manufacturing capacity in Mexico to more than double its current output. Ford produced 433,000 vehicles in Mexico last year, 14% of its North American production, and plans to increase that output by 500,000 units. By 2018, Ford will have spent more than $1 billion to expand its existing Cuautitlán plant to encompass 150,000 more units annually and build a new plant in San Luis Potosi that will generate 350,000 units annually. Ford will be producing up to three models at the new assembly complex, including a new hybrid vehicle (to compete with Toyota’s electric Prius) and the Focus compact car (currently being produced by unionized workers in Michigan). This shift will allow its American factories to focus on the more profitable trucks and sports-utility vehicles. American automobile manufacturers, including the top six automakers competing in the U.S. market, have been investing billions in their Mexico plants over the last few years. Last spring, Ford announced a $2.5 billion investment directed at building an engine and transmission plant in Mexico. Mexico’s inexpensive labor force, favorable free trade agreements, and proximity are undermining the UAW’s (United Auto Workers union) efforts to increase worker wages and keep jobs in the United States. Ford’s intention to double its Mexico production capacity was released after the union ratified expensive new labor agreements last November with the “Big Three” headquartered in Detroit, the automotive giants Ford, General Motors and Chrysler. UAW President Dennis Williams stated that there is no need to jump ahead to outsource manufacturing to countries like Mexico, Taiwan, and Thailand, because car companies are already profitable enough without the fatter profit margin provided by low wages overseas. Mexican labor wages are approximately one-fifth of the domestic automotive laborers’ wages (approaching $30 an hour in the next few years). On the other hand, Ford’s decision may maximize its shareholder returns, offsetting the harmful effects of outsourcing. A Ford spokesperson declined to comment on the future plans. Ford’s expansion south of the border may have strong ramifications for the coming 2016 presidential election. Last year, presidential candidate, Donald Trump, speculating that Ford planned to build a new assembly plant in Mexico and simultaneously close Michigan factories, promised to put in place a 35% tax on all automotive imports from Mexico if elected. As a result of his prediction coming true, Donald Trump may win even more supporters. Despite this, we have yet to see whether the growing trend of car companies outsourcing labor will affect the American economy positively or negatively in coming years. Sources:

Chris Angelidis April 20, 2016 Every semester, colleges expect students to pay for tuition, student fees, room and board, textbooks, online access codes, cafeteria food, transportation, and other living expenses. These countless costs quickly add up and put the average college student thirty-thousand dollars in debt by the end of his/her undergraduate degree. As of 2014, there were forty-million people in America with student loan debt and the number has only grown since then. With over twelve percent of the nation’s population in student loan related debt, it is important to look at this the long-term and macro implications of this issue. Recent studies have shown that millennials try to get rid of their debt at one time instead of financing it over a lifetime. This means that a significant portion of our early career income will go towards paying off these large fees, leaving us short of cash. Furthermore, these substantial payments lessen the amount of money put aside for retirement, causing people in the generation to lose out on $325,000 in their 401k’s over the course of a lifetime and delaying retirement as a result. A recent survey conducted by Forbes even reported that thirty-percent of millennials would be willing to sell an organ to get rid of their student debt. At the end of the day, the student loan crisis is heavily impacting millennials and their ability to stand as independent adults. Each year, more and more young workers are choosing to live with their parents and are forced to put off important life decisions. This unfortunate situation has largely influenced the political scene, with presidential candidate Bernie Sanders offering to provide free public collegiate education for all. Such a move would not only provide the opportunity for students to graduate from college debt free, but would also increase college attendance by those who would otherwise be unwilling or unable to take out a loan.   • http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-12-10/four-ways-student-debt-is-wreaking-havoc-on-millennials

Anna Chen April 26, 2016 During Facebook’s annual conference for software developers on Tuesday, April 16th, Mark Zuckerberg unveiled what will likely be the next big thing in tech – chatbots. Chatbots are interactive software agents powered by both artificial and human intelligence. They are designed to simulate human conversation. Chatbots will pop up on messaging services where you can use them to perform simple tasks, such as to ask questions or make a purchase. Zuckerbergs plans to incorporate chatbots into the existing and very popular Facebook Messenger app. Users will be able to chat with businesses just as if they were to message their friends. This eliminates the burden of downloading an excessive numbers of apps, an issue that Zuckerberg is hoping to resolve with chatbots. During the conference, Zuckerberg said "To order flowers on 1-800-Flowers, you never have to call 1-800-Flowers again." Facebook has been testing this idea out – it partnered with Uber last year so that users can order a ride without having the Uber app on their phone. In China, chatbots have already taken off through the popular messaging app WeChat, where users can schedule doctor’s appointments, play games, and send money. Profiting from bots isn't the first priority for Facebook, but analysts see great potential. Capturing half the predicted business for customer support via messaging would represent a brand-new $4 billion revenue opportunity, says Evercore Group LLC. Over the next few years these chatbots could forever change the way users interact with businesses and service providers. Sources:
  • Abutaleb, Yasmeen. "Facebook's next Frontier: Chatbots." Reuters. Thomson Reuters, 2016. Web. 21 Apr. 2016.
  • Guynn, Jessica. "Zuckerberg's Facebook Messenger Launches 'chat Bots' Platform." USA Today. Gannett, 12 Apr. 2016. Web.
  • Person, and Robert McMillan. "Facebook Hopes Chatbots Can Solve App Overload." WSJ. 17 Apr 2016. Web.

Amira Fleyshmakher April 12, 2016 Last month, the Chinese government set a target growth rate of 6.5% to 7% for the year 2016. Unfortunately, economists believe that this level will only be feasible if excessive monetary and fiscal policies continue to take place to stimulate the slowing Chinese economy. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) had announced in its annual report that Chinese growth will only reach the lower end of the government’s target, predicting that it stays at 6.5% this year. This certainly seems to be bad news, particularly when comparing China’s growth at the end of 2009 and 2010, when its GDP was growing by over 10%. China’s growth in GDP over the past decade as compared to its target rate There are various factors that have contributed to China’s slowdown. First, there has been a sharp drop in domestic investments, particularly in the real estate sector and other capital-intensive industries, although this will be partly offset by increased government spending on infrastructure. There is also an oversupply in the steel and coal sectors, which have been producing up to 30% more than the market currently needs. There are plans to reduce production capacity by about 10% over the next five years, but this would require the government to provide a substantial amount of funds to support the displaced workers. Economists also expect interest rate cuts, and if the Fed goes ahead with increasing interest rates in the U.S, this will further harm the Yuan, since investors will be more inclined to move their capital out of China and into the U.S. The Chinese government’s attempt to regulate and stimulate the Chinese economy is merely an artificial measure of securing growth. If monetary and fiscal policies constantly have to be in place in order to maintain the 6.5% level, growth will not be sustained for too long. Sooner or later, the markets will have to play their role. Sources:

  • http://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-13/weakening-china-growth-challenges-leadership-wedded-to-6-5-goal

This certainly seems to be bad news, particularly when comparing China’s growth at the end of 2009 and 2010, when its GDP was growing by over 10%. China’s growth in GDP over the past decade as compared to its target rate There are various factors that have contributed to China’s slowdown. First, there has been a sharp drop in domestic investments, particularly in the real estate sector and other capital-intensive industries, although this will be partly offset by increased government spending on infrastructure. There is also an oversupply in the steel and coal sectors, which have been producing up to 30% more than the market currently needs. There are plans to reduce production capacity by about 10% over the next five years, but this would require the government to provide a substantial amount of funds to support the displaced workers. Economists also expect interest rate cuts, and if the Fed goes ahead with increasing interest rates in the U.S, this will further harm the Yuan, since investors will be more inclined to move their capital out of China and into the U.S. The Chinese government’s attempt to regulate and stimulate the Chinese economy is merely an artificial measure of securing growth. If monetary and fiscal policies constantly have to be in place in order to maintain the 6.5% level, growth will not be sustained for too long. Sooner or later, the markets will have to play their role. Sources:

Adam Su April 11, 2016 After already laying off 2,400 employees in the previous year, one of Norway’s major Oil equipment companies, National Oilwell Varco, has signaled plans for further mass layoffs. At the intersection of poor market conditions and a decreased incentive for further oil drilling and exploration, drilling service companies such as National Oilwell Varco are on the downfall. Because of the abundance of oil and natural gas in Norway, the nation serves as Western Europe’s biggest oil exporter. However, because the global oil market has produced a massive supply, oil suppliers are reducing the rate in which they explore or search out for new oil reserves. According to the Wall Street Journal, National Oilwell Varco currently has “500 offshore rigs and drill ships, and about 300 are retired so far”. In addition, the Norwegian oil industry as a whole has decreased their budget for exploring for new oil reserves by 25% from 2014, down to $19.7 billion. Sources:

Collin Chipetine April 19, 2016 For those who believe unicorns don’t exist, there are actually 229 roaming the world as we speak. As of January 2016, there were a reported 229 unicorns, or start-ups valued at over 1 billion dollars. Whether it be the clever picture-sharing website Pinterest, the rapid-growing social media site Snapchat, or the decacorn (start-up valued over 10 billion dollars) driving website sweeping the nation known to all as Uber, there are new unicorns that enter the world each and every day. However, it’s not always as simple as these well-known companies make it seem, and Mixpanel is not the first company to succumb to the difficulties within the financial world. Mixpanel is now facing an important question: Is it worth the sacrifice of profitability for the gain of growth? Mixpanel provides a platform for apps to view the particular actions their subscribers are taking within the app, as well as make changes to cater to the particular interests and actions of their users. However, for the founders and CEO’s, Suhail Doshi and Tim Trefen, are inspired “re-up the risk in the startup.” Opening multiple offices abroad, tripling its sales staff, and developing a new line of analytical software to even further analyze the intricacies of the apps in terms of sales and finance, the company was valued at around $865 million dollars by venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz. This 2014 valuation just missed the $1 billion unicorn status that the founders sought. Whether or not it will reach unicorn status within the next few months or even years is unknown for Mixpanel, but the company certainly has a bright future. Gaining its profitability within a short four years with little to no marketing, it came to no surprise when Sequoia Capital and other elite “angel” investors caught on to the company. Source:
  • http://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2016/04/11/mixpanel-ceos-unicorn-dreams-take-a-back-seat-to-cutting-costs/

Chynelle Menezes April 11, 2016 On April 4th, Alaska Airlines outbid JetBlue and acquired Virgin America for $2.6 billion. This creates one stronger, more competitive airline with more destination and flight offerings. While the full merger will take 1-2 years to complete, the company assures customer that its rewards programs will remain uninterrupted. Once the airlines are fully merged, all Elevate points from Virgin America will be transferred to Alaska Airlines Mileage Plan, which has been ranked the #1 airline rewards program by U.S. News and World Report. Alaska Airlines has investment-grade credit rating, no net debt, and $1.3 billion cash, combating Virgin America, which has been struggling since its IPO in late 2014. The merger has tremendous implications for the airline industry as a whole. As of now, the industry is extremely consolidated with four carriers (American, Delta, United, and Southwest) controlling more than 80% of the U.S. market. With this merger, Alaska Airlines is effectively placing itself as a competitor to such premier airlines and will displace JetBlue for the fifth spot on the list of the top American carriers. Alaska-Virgin America expects to gain $225 million in annual cost savings after one-time integration costs with a 27% boost in annual revenue. Sources:

John Casella April 8, 2016 Since the economic crisis of 2008, the inconsistent job market has been looming over the recovery of the American economy. However, virtually every jobs report in 2016 boasts excellent numbers and findings, and last month showed no different. First off, the United States labor force has grown to 1.92 million in the last four months, the biggest labor boom since 2000. Additionally, the proportion of the adult population that is working is up to 59.9% from last year’s 59.3%. While this represents only minute improvement, the increase shows a movement towards the 63% that worked before the 2008 recession. Similarly, wages are only up .3% in March, and 2.3% in the last year. However, inflation has remained low enough that this small surge actually gives more buying power to the everyday worker. Because of this slow but steady rate of growth, the Federal Reserve will stick with its “cautious, slow path of raising interest rates, rather than get any ideas that a huge outbreak of inflation is on the way.” With all this good news there still remains one major drawback: the potential economic output looks to be substantially weaker that the potential job market, which means the productivity growth is particularly weak. The conflicting reports regarding the job market and productivity growth are indicative of the continually shaky recovery of the US economy. Source:
  • http://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/02/upshot/this-is-the-job-market-weve-been-hoping-for-all-these-years.html?ref=economy

Jehanzeb Khan April 4, 2016 On Monday March 28, 2016 one of the largest foreign buyouts took place when NTT Data Corp., a Tokyo based tech and communications company finalized a deal to buy Dell Inc.’s IT-services branch for $3.05 billion. Over the past few years Nippon Telegraph & Telephone (NTT) Corp. made several attempts to expand overseas and increase its international presence by acquiring foreign-based tech companies.  Acquiring foreign companies has become a trend for many Japanese corporations due to slow growth in the domestic economy. Since the start of the decade NTT Data acquired Keane Inc., a U.S based IT company for $1.4 billion, and Dimension Data Holdings PLC, a South African based IT company for $3.2 billion. However, NTT Data’s latest acquisition of Perot Systems, Dell’s IT services branch appears to be the most promising acquisition thus far. Representatives from NTT Data have stated that purchasing Perot Systems is a significant step forward for the company in expanding its markets to North America and project that the company will see a $4 billion increase in overseas revenue by the 2018 fiscal year as a result of the acquisition. For Dell, the underlying purpose behind selling its IT services department is to gain cash and reduce some of the debt the company will accumulate after spending $59 billion in acquiring EMC Corp., a data storage company. This will certainly not be the only department that Denali Holding Inc., Dell’s parent company will try to sell in the upcoming weeks leading to the acquisition of EMC Corp. For some, the sale of Perot Systems to NTT Data for only $3.05 billion came as a surprise. Initial talks for Dell’s IT department were for more than $5 billion. This deal seems to be mutually beneficial for both companies, as it will help both of them expand their businesses and accomplish their long-term goals. However, this deal could have been much more favorable for Dell if it were able to sell Perot Systems at a higher price. Sources:

Jane Ng April 12, 2016 HP just released the thinnest laptop in the world. The personal computer and printer producing company aims to seize a greater market share of the premium PC category with the HP Spectre. CEO Dion Weisler hopes it will help rebrand HP with the aesthetic sleekness and innovation currently associated with Apple Inc’s high-priced portable electronics. Hewlett Packard unveiled the upgraded model at The New York Times International Luxury Conference in Versailles on Monday, April 4th. The 13.3’’ notebook is as thin as an AAA battery (1.04 centimeters thick), with a black and gold finish. However, HP developed the Spectre for portability and design, trading off functionality. While the new model boasts a 9.5 hour battery life, it is said to have limited upgrade capabilities. The unveiling of the HP Spectre comes at a time of subpar performance for the tech giant. In the last fiscal year, HP’s revenue fell 12%. Unit sales in 2015 fell 5.9%, though HP boosted its share of global shipments from 18.4% to 19.4%. In light of these figures, HP developed the trendy new clamshell model, slimmest of its kind, hoping to turn around sales. But premium laptops may be the wrong category to fall back on. Stephen Baker, an analyst at NPD Group tracking US retail PC sales, said that such systems make up only a small share of the portable electronic market. “The challenge for doing really, really thin and light products is it’s a very, very thin and light segment to go after,” Mr. Baker said. As numerous computer companies jump onto the bandwagon, other factors of a computer may wind up being more important to users during this “millimeter madness”, including processing speed, encryption, and bandwidth capability. Othilla Wlodarczyk April 21, 2016 The recently volatile markets have led to low revenues across the largest competitors in the financial services industry. Goldman Sachs’ quarterly earnings decreased by 60%, net income fell from $2.84 to $1.14 billion, and the revenue plummeted by 40% from $10.62 to $6.34 billion. Apart from Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley’s revenue dropped by 21%, and other big banks average between 3% and 11%. In terms of trading revenue, Morgan Stanley’s decreased by 34% and J.P. Morgan Chase’s by 11%; investment-banking revenue also fell by 23% in the first quarter of 2016. Goldman Sachs stated that “net revenue in its Investing & Lending unit fell a jaw-dropping 95%,” from $1.7 billion last year to $87 million. Considering that the unit has $99 billion in assets, the return was only 0.087%. These numbers have taken a toll on compensation and benefits packages, for which the costs have been reduced by 40% in Goldman Sachs; this percentage cut has largely come from what would be employee bonuses. The decreased revenues can be attributed to low investor confidence in the current markets, China’s slowing growth, a shaky energy market, and uncertainty over the Federal Reserve’s next moves. The energy slump has also caused for J.P. Morgan Chase, Citigroup, and Wells Fargo to build up their reserves, or “rainy-day funds”: “The big national banks added a total of $777 million to their reserves for soured loans in the first quarter. That is up from the $296 million they added in the fourth quarter of 2015.” “The new reserve builds are driven largely by worsening credit conditions among energy-industry borrowers.” Sources:

Layanah Nsouli September 26, 2016 The Dodd-Frank Act of 2010 has brought greater regulation across the financial services industry. However, the recent Wells Fargo scandal has called into question the efficacy and impact of Dodd-Frank reforms. Earlier this month, Wells Fargo was charged with creating over 2 million fake accounts in an attempt to meet aggressive sales quotas. The bank has agreed to pay a $185 million settlement and has fired 5,300 employees in the aftermath of the scandal. In Janet Yellen’s upcoming meeting with the House Financial Services Committee, this will likely be one of the issues brought up in the discussion of the Fed’s supervision and regulation arms. In addition, Wells Fargo CEO, John Stumpf, will be asked to testify at a hearing scheduled with the House of Financial Services Committee later this week. The upcoming supervision hearing was introduced by Dodd-Frank, however it is important to note that it lacks a key player. Under the same reform that mandated the hearings, the president was required to appoint a Vice Chairman for Supervision. Since the Obama administration has failed to select someone to this position, Janet Yellen is taking over this role. Although Yellen's meeting with the House of Financial Services Committee will be centered around regulation concerns, it is likely that there will be continued pressure for rate hikes by the end of the year. Anand Poonai January 10, 2016 1400 years have gone by and the prolonged sectarian division between Shiite and Sunni Muslim has recently taken a turn for the worst, leading to a Sunni-dominated Saudi Arabia’s official severing of ties with the predominantly Shiite Iran. What triggered Saudi Arabia’s rash decision were the events that followed after this past Sunday, when the Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, a Shiite cleric, was executed in Saudi Arabia. Not only was the Sheikh executed, but so were 47 other men who were suspected of being a part of Al Qaeda and partaking in terrorism-related activities. Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr outwardly criticized the Saudi royal family and was adamantly opposed to Sunni power. Seen as a high level threat to an already unstable Saudi government, Sheikh al-Nimr was accused of encouraging rebellions and violent protests, thus leading to his execution. The execution of the Shiite cleric has led to further heated and violent protests in Saudi Arabia. Iranian protestors stormed the Saudi embassy in Iran’s capital, Tehran, this past weekend. Molotov cocktails were thrown at the embassy and protestors ransacked the building, hoping to get revenge for the death of the Sheikh. Due to the severity of the situation, Saudi Arabia ordered Iranian officials to evacuate the country within the next 48 hours. The execution of the Shiite cleric seems to have further cemented the split between the Sunni and Shiite-supporting countries, thus supplementing greater tension in the Middle East. Predominantly Shiite countries, including Iraq are outraged by Saudi Arabia’s execution of Sheikh Nimr al-Nimr, for they believe the Sheikh was simply a peaceful dissident and wasn’t a threat to anyone. To the Shiite community’s dismay, Saudi Arabia and its Sunni allies have not spoken out against the execution. Geopolitical discrepancies and the recent involvement in proxy wars in Syria have undoubtedly been fueling the animosity between Saudi Arabia and Iran, and the recent executions, which has been the largest execution to have taken place in the Middle East for decades, has sealed the deal in terms of severed ties between the two nations. The Obama administration has been advocating for peace between the two nations, but as of now, the split between the two nations seems almost unchangeable. Sources:

  Earlier this week, technology giants Qualcomm Inc. (NASDAQ: QCOM) and longstanding partner, BlackBerry (NASDAQ: BBRY) agreed to a binding arbitration to settle a yearlong dispute in regard to a pre-arranged cap concerning licensing payments, which ultimately awarded BlackBerry $815 million.

Source: Android Authority

Qualcomm, self-described as a ‘world leader in 3G and next-generation mobile technologies,’ is an American multinational semiconductor and telecommunications company, and licenses patents necessary for mobile communication, thus collecting royalties on nearly every smartphone in the market. The company charges its licensing fees based on a percentage up to 5% of the average selling price of a device, but its agreement with BlackBerry prior to the arbitration decision included a cap on such fees. After recently reporting a second-quarter profit of $749 million on total sales of $5.02 billion, this arbitration decision cut greatly into Qualcomm’s top line, decreasing revenue in its patent licensing segment by 40% to $1.33 billion. Although this particular case has had no impact on Qualcomm’s licensing agreements with other partners and notable clients, the company has faced a very recent $1 billion lawsuit with Cupertino-based giant, Apple, concerning similar ‘inordinately high’ prices for its technologies. Likewise, Qualcomm has also faced legal action from the Federal Trade Commission in addition to South Korea and China’s regulatory authorities regarding anti-competitive practices. As this chipmaker is under attack, how much can it continue to profit from its seemingly monopolistic intellectual property? On the other hand, what does this mean for BlackBerry? After reporting unusually large adjusted earnings in its last quarter, the company has begun an expansion of its licensing strategy into other technology components – including wearables, tablets, appliances, medical devices, and possibly automobile software. Immediately after its $815 million arbitration agreement, BBRY stocks shot up 16%, as BlackBerry stockholders are aware of the additional cushion to its balance sheet. Although the company has been lagging behind competitors such as Apple and Samsung for quite some time, BlackBerry Chief Executive John Chen has since stated that he expects BlackBerry’s software business to continue to grow 13% to 15% in the next fiscal year. This legal dispute between BlackBerry and Qualcomm Inc. bring into light anti-competitive practices that continue to exist past the Rockefeller Age and into the ‘Age of the Smartphone.’ With several regulatory authorities recognizing Qualcomm’s control of the mobile technology realm, Qualcomm’s mobile technology competitors – including Huahei, HTC, Nokia, and Samsung – have more leverage now than ever to rise, improve product potential, and maximize revenue. With professional sports around the world reaching the height of their popularity, team valuations have begun to explode. In July 2016, Forbes published an article listing the most valuable sports franchises in the world, which was led by the Dallas Cowboys football team at $4 billion. That’s $1.37B more than your friendly-neighborhood GameStop (NYSE:GME). So what is it about sports teams that makes them so valuable? Let’s examine one specific NBA team, the New York Knicks, for example. The Knicks make money from their portion of the television deals the league has with Turner Sports and ESPN ($240M), their huge market ($1.456B), the money generated by MSG (ticket sales, non-basketball events, premium attractions, etc.) ($907M) and their specific brand ($447 M). All of those add up to a team valuation of ~$3 Billion. Reading that Forbes article got me thinking: why don’t sports teams offer shares on the public markets?

Source: espn.com

As we just saw, buying a sports franchise is an expensive endeavor, one usually reserved for billionaires and the ultra-connected, but need that be the case? Why can’t franchise-owners, like CEOs that IPO their companies, look to the public markets to raise funds for a new stadium or to go after a highly-coveted free agent? What sports fan wouldn’t be interested in becoming a part-owner of their favorite team, even if they only owned a fraction of a percent? If they are worried about inexperienced outsiders ruining their team, the ownership group could set up the public shares in such a way that they do not allow the holders to vote on team matters, similar to how Snap, Inc. (NYSE:SNAP) offered theirs. While there have been instances in the past when teams have offered shares and underperformed the market, I believe that an equitable arrangement that allows investors to share in the financial gains and appreciation of the teams will solve this problem. In 2012, Business Insider published a piece titled “The Fastest Growing Sports Franchises Since 2000.” In it, they detailed teams that grew by over 200% over the 12-year period, a period in which the S&P 500 had growth of less than 50%. A team’s valuation would undoubtedly be highly cyclical based on its recent performance (which would without a doubt impact all aspects of its revenue stream), but in the same way that value investors find the neglected stocks bound to soar, the smart money would see past the struggles of today and buy into the bright future. While there are, without a doubt, still issues that need to be resolved with this idea, I believe that such an offering would be attractive to both fans seeking to join in their team’s success and investors seeking above-market returns.   Sources:

Ashley Torrenti March 8, 2017 On February 27, 2017 Comcast, the largest broadcasting and cable television company in the world, announced that it will be integrating YouTube into its X1 set up boxes. Comcast’s X1 DVR allows its users to simultaneously record and watch 6 shows. Furthermore, you can download those shows and watch them where ever you go, with or without Wi-Fi. Another added bonus is the new ability to use a voice controlled X1 remote.

Source: YouTube

Despite these new and improved qualities of the X1, Comcast still competes against Roku and Google’s Chromecast, thereby motivating the company to bring its next greatest innovation: the integration of YouTube. "We are excited to partner with Google to bring YouTube to X1 and provide our customers easier access to all the content they love in one place," said Sam Schwartz, Chief Business Development Officer, Comcast Cable. With this new YouTube feature, X1 users can access YouTube’s videos via the app. Additionally the smart tech can also recommend videos based off of the channels and programs you watch on cable.This integration of an internet video provider with the traditional TV programming is not the first step Comcast has made. In fact, just last year Comcast integrated Netflix into its XI set up boxes as well.However, what are the implications of integrating traditional television programming and internet videos? Well for starters, it’s one of the first wide scale steps in separating the divide between “what you see on TV” and “what you see on the web.” As of right now, over 50% of the Internet’s bandwidth is consumed by Netflix and YouTube users alone. Both of these sites are now partnered with Comcast, thus creating a large demand for its cable and internet services. However, YouTube will still be taking in its full revenue from the ads they place in the services they provide without any commission to Comcast. The usual YouTube user could choose to completely bypass Comcast’s X1 box for YouTube Red, unless Comcast allows them to directly subscribe via X1, an opportunity not available as of right now. Regardless, this new bundle with the Comcast X1 set up box demonstrates the shift in Comcast’s video strategy by placing the customer experience before the competitive disputes. Comcast users look forward to this new launch of the YouTube app on X1 to be released later in 2017. Sources:
  • http://corporate.comcast.com/news-information/news-feed/comcast-to-launch-youtube-on-xfinity-x1
  • http://www.recode.net/2017/2/27/14747186/comcast-youtube-x1-google-alphabet
  • http://www.bizjournals.com/philadelphia/news/2017/02/28/comcast-brian-roberts-x1-youtube-netflix-fcc-pai.html

Samsung Electronics Co. plans to invest approximately $300 million into oven-range production facilities in the United States. This could generate 500 jobs in whichever state it chooses, boosting the U.S. manufacturing industry. The decision was largely influenced by President Donald Trump’s campaign to create more U.S. manufacturing jobs and enforce penalties on non-compliant companies.

Source: Samsung

This news may signal a shift into more U.S. manufacturing from foreign companies. LG Electronics Inc. announced its plans to invest $250 million in a home-appliance factory in Tennessee, rivaling Samsung’s current plans with the creation of over 600 jobs. Much of Samsung’s home appliance manufacturing is done in Mexico but that may change. While production plans are currently focused on ovens, future U.S. manufacturing may expand to include other home appliances like refrigerators, washers, and dryers. The expectation of pro-business policy from America’s current President is attracting foreign investment. Samsung was already one of America’s largest direct foreign investors with a recent announcement to invest over $1 billion into production facilities for processor chips (used in smartphones and other devices) in Austin, Texas. Other Asian firms, like SoftBank Group Corp. and Foxconn Technology Group, have also pledged to expand U.S. operations with grand direct investments as well. Though with Samsung’s Vice Chairman, Lee Jae-yong, is currently on trial for a political and corporate corruption scandal, the long-term interests of these foreign investors should garner some concern.   Source:
  • https://www.wsj.com/articles/samsung-plans-u-s-expansion-would-shift-manufacturing-from-mexico-1488985610

Collin Chipetine March 22, 2017 AIG recently revealed its fourth quarter earnings, which reported losses totaling approximately $3.04 billion, a loss marked as “the worst performance by the New York City-based firm since its near-collapse in 2008 at the height of the financial crisis.” In response, AIG and its Chief Executive made a drastic decision in allowing the current CEO, Peter Hancock, to step down. Although he was CEO of AIG for less than three years, Hancock had lofty plans from the start of his time with the firm. One of these plans included returning $25 billion to shareholders through a combined effort of share buybacks and a consistent dividend stream for two years. This goal was ahead of schedule with returns of $13.1 billion to its shareholders by the end of 2016. Despite these efforts, after a couple of days of trading at a plunge of almost 9% prior to the Q4 results an at only 85% of AIG’s entire stated assets value, Hancock wasn’t the only one concerned about his position at AIG. In times such as these for companies as large as AIG, it is easy to turn to the leadership as the main cause of such a crash. This of course is not always the case, but nevertheless, begins to make people question whether a change should be made to preserve the progress of the company. This was exactly the case for Hancock, claiming even without the full support of AIG’s shareholders, he felt it was both in his own self-interest and in the interest of the greater organization to not further undermine the growth of the firm. While the CEO succeeding Hancock will be the sixth in just 12 years for AIG, many investors and shareholders do agree that it is in fact the best solution for the organization as a whole. Carl Ichan, the fourth largest investor in AIG, stood fully behind this change of leadership. As expected, shareholders are skeptical of a new leader’s ability to progress the company as needed. At the point, AIG’s goal is to decrease the volume of its balance sheet through several deals to shrink or sell parts of the company. Hancock himself had even had a combined 17 deals to shrink the company overall to just over $498 billion half of its value in 2007, when it took such a devastating blow following the recession. With almost a 5% stake in the company, Ichan frequently states his ideas for a more regulated supervision of the company, even if that means taking on more capital. In order to take all of these ideas and goals and put them into action, AIG must be diligent in who they choose to succeed Hancock. Hancock has agreed to stay on until his successor is chosen, in hopes of avoiding any damage that can be dealt to its shareholders’ interests resulting from such uncertainty. Regardless of whom AIG chooses to fill the shoes of Hancock, the firm’s main priority will be to continue shedding assets and reducing risk in order to avoid repetition of the 2007-2008 crisis. Much is unknown, but one thing that is a definite for AIG is that these next few upcoming weeks will be crucial to the future of the company. Sources:

Jane Ng
March 27, 2017
Clifton S. Robbins is trying to change the investing industry. He is the founder and CEO of Blue Harbour Group and advocates socially active investing as a way to address environmental and social issues while improving companies’ financial values. Mr. Robbins is affiliated with many different organizations and companies with vested interests in conservation and developing technology, including iFormation Group Management Corp., Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, and The Central Park Conservancy. With his influence and statistical support, Mr. Robbins is persuading companies to hold environmental, social, and governance issues to the same level of importance as financial issues.

Source: CNBC

The common sense approach for a company to address these issues in their policies and decisions is that investors recognize their long-term value. Clifton Robbins also states that it reduces risk. Anticipating environmental issues like carbon footprints, social issues like gender wage inequality, and governance issues like transparency allows corporations to take proactive steps in addressing them. Doing so might save money in the long run and boost stock value now. A December BAML report states that companies that scored in the top third on these characteristics outperformed stocks in the bottom third by 18%. As Anne Shehan, head of governance at California State Teachers' Retirement System, says, nonfinancial issues can turn financial quickly. Studies show that being socially active can affect company culture and financial stewardship, which strongly impact business decisions and the bottom line. At one point, Blue Harbour couldn’t project how much activism could increase stock prices, and it sold its stake in packaging manufacturer, Gerresheimer AG, for a 69% gain and a $32 million profit. However, the stock price steadily climbed as the company consciously reduced its carbon footprint, which lowered costs and boosted profits. Had Blue Harbour kept the stake, it would have earned $25 million more. Sources:

Uber, the mobile transportation app, has revolutionized the way people travel. With thousands of drivers, GPS tracking, and completely electronic transactions, Uber has become the preferred option over the traditional taxi system. Even with major growth and profits, Uber is now facing a problem: the resignation of its president.

Source: CNN Money

Jeff Jones, the president of Uber, has spent only six months with the company. With such little time in the position, Jones’ resignation is shocking. In a statement to Recode, he said, “The beliefs and approach to leadership that have guided my career are inconsistent with what I saw and experienced at Uber.” During his time as president of Uber, Jones’ primary goal was improving the companies public image. Even though the reason is unclear, such a sudden resignation, especially after the minimal time in the position, draws red flags for the company’s investors. Jeff Jones was not an intrinsic part of the company in that his absence will be minimally invasive. However, his resignation could be a sign of much larger problems.   Source:

Forecasters have predicted a more substantial amount of economic growth for the United States economy since the 2016 presidential election. While economists expected 2.2% economic growth in 2017 prior to the presidential election, they now expect 2.4% economic growth for the year. Similarly, prior to the election, economic growth for 2018 was expected to be 2.0% in contrast to predictions of 2.5% today.

Source: HuffingtonPost

Many of these improved economic growth predictions stem from the promises that President Trump has made to reduce business regulation, reform a tax code that businesses perceive as oppressive, and put a large infrastructure package into place.  These improved economic growth predictions for the next two years help explain the great performance of stock and bond markets. Economists believe that a positive growth cycle could continue so long as optimism about the economy continues on its current path. However, economists expect growth to fall back to 2.1% in 2019 and thereafter. This expected rate of growth is similar to that which was expected prior to the 2016 presidential election.  It can be attributed to the different factors that fuel short-term and long-term growth. Growth in infrastructure spending would put many people back to work for the time being, which would strengthen the economy, and an increase in the deficit would provide for more spending, which would strengthen the economy, but these are only temporary fixes. There are alternatives -- actual and substantial tax reform, simplifying regulation that helps companies operate more efficiently -- that would help give economists reason to believe there will be more growth in 2019 and beyond, but they feel uncertain about how much the current erratic presidential administration will actually be able to accomplish, and so they sit and wait to prognosticate as more is revealed. Source:

You have probably seen the Facebook videos of the futuristic, cashier-less, and line-less Amazon Go stores, the first one of which opened its doors exclusively to Amazon employees in December of 2016. Amazon Go relies on computer vision and sensors to track which items consumers grab off of shelves and later charge their accounts for the items. Apart from the large-scale benefits to consumers, such as saving time by eliminating lines and self-check machines, the benefits to Amazon are immense. Using the multitudes of cameras within the Amazon Go stores, Amazon can track what caught your eye or what you picked up and later put back, in order to create even more comprehensive “Recommended Products” lists for its customers.

Source: The Verge

Amazon Go was slated to open its doors to the public in early 2017, but recent reports have revealed that this opening has been delayed due to technical difficulties that the store is facing. Examples of such difficulties include an inability to track more than 20 customers within the store and keeping track of items that have been taken off of shelves and later replaced. In fact, Amazon Go’s technology only seems to function flawlessly when there are less than 20 customers in the store or if its customers are moving very slowly. Sources have not revealed how long this delay will last and for now, human staff is on hand at the store to ensure that technical glitches are fixed smoothly and efficiently. It is commendable how careful and diligent Amazon is being in ensuring that Amazon Go stores will run smoothly when they are finally opened to the public. Despite the delay in the opening of these stores, the project, which was started by Amazon in 2012, is certainly reaching its final stages. Sources:

May 1, 2017
Over the last few days, President Donald Trump has announced new policies and actions that he will be taking to fulfill his campaign promises. While the new tax proposal that would lower the corporate tax rate from 35% to 15%, arguably enticing businesses to return to the United States and repatriate profits from outside of the United States, has been hogging the most attention, Trump also announced a 20% tariff on Canadian softwood-lumber imports. The tariff is in response to a trade dispute with Canada that has lasted for decades, and the main issue is the Canadians government’s subsidies on its softwood-lumber industry. The tariff is just one example of Trump’s hardline approach on trade, and while Canada’s actions are considered violations of trade policy, the tariff will have a negative impact on the United States consumer.

Source: NPR

Tariffs and protectionist policies negatively impact domestic consumers because they drive up domestic prices, and in this case they will affect the average consumer. Softwood lumber is typically used to build single-family homes. The tariff will not only eventually drive lumber costs up for U.S. customers by 6.4%, according to the National Association of Home Builders, but the anticipation of the lumber prices rising has already pushed them 22% higher since the start of 2017. Overall, the National Association of Home Builders estimates that the increase in price will total to $1,236 per each single-family home. The tariff will drive up domestic home prices as well as negatively impact relations between Canada and the United States. This is a crucial time for favorable relations considering Canada, Mexico, and the United States will shortly be renegotiating NAFTA. This tariff will leave a sour taste on both sides of the border and will likely also cause retaliatory action. Negotiations between Canada and the United States would have led to a mutually-positive result, especially considering the two countries are close allies. Going into NAFTA negotiations will be more difficult after this hard-headed policy slap.   Sources:

  • http://www.cnbc.com/2017/04/25/trumps-canadian-lumber-tariff-could-cost-us-homebuyers-about-1200.html
  • https://www.wsj.com/articles/dear-canada-its-not-personal-its-just-trade-1493234522

Over a year ago, Verizon had offered to purchase Yahoo for $4.83 billion dollars, but the deal was postponed because of Yahoo’s security breaches. These security breaches had reached over one billion users which caused Verizon to reevaluate the acquisition of Yahoo. In addition to the acquisition of Yahoo, Verizon also acquired AOL, which would later be combined with Yahoo to create a new parent company, Oath. Because of this merger, Verizon ended up purchasing Yahoo for $350 million less than the original asking price.

Source: CNN Money

Within the spectrum of online advertising, Google is Verizon’s top competitor. Advertising has become a prominent source of revenue for technology companies and Verizon wants to get its foot into that industry. The acquisition of Yahoo will likely allow Verizon to gain an initial foothold in this industry. The Verizon and Yahoo deal is expected to close by the second quarter of 2017. Sources:

Matthew Severin
May 1, 2017
On Tuesday, April 25th, J. Crew Group Inc. announced its plans to cut around 250 jobs as part of a cost cutting effort in the wake of declining sales, a major slowdown in foot traffic in its retail stores, and shifting shopping patterns. J. Crew mentioned that it would cut about 150 full time positions and 100 open positions. Most of these cuts would be from its corporate headquarters in New York City. Sales at its stores have fallen consistently for the past 10 quarters, and the company reported a $23.5 million loss (with revenue down 3%) for the fiscal year ended January 28th.

Source: Wall Street Journal

J. Crew explained that it expects charges of around $10 million in its fiscal first quarter due to cut related expenses. However, the company foresees about $30 million of annual pretax savings as a result of these job cuts. J. Crew Chief Executive Millard Drexler said, “While challenging, we know what needs to be done and this is a critical step to position J. Crew for the future. We are committed to treating impacted associates with respect and support through this period of change.” Some of J. Crew’s long-term employees have already made the bold decision to leave the company in fear of job instability. Even though this is a difficult business decision to make, it is very rational. The online shopping trend has increased tremendously, and less people are visiting J. Crew’s retail stores each quarter. J. Crew needs to focus future prospects and securing its position  within the fashion world. For now, it needs to deal with its declining revenues and engage in some business restructuring.   Sources:

Stephen Esposito
May 7, 2017
On Tuesday, May 2nd, Apple, one of the most distinct companies of the 21st century, released results which show that it currently has more than $250 billion in cash. This current total of assets, excluding incurred liabilities, exceeds the amount of assets for some of the most renowned companies on the market, specifically WalMart, General Electric, and Proctor and Gamble. Additionally, Apple has gained much of these assets in the past four years at an exponential rate, with earnings exceeding $3.6 million per hour in the last quarter of 2016.

Source: WSJ

You may ask, however, why would Apple have so much of this money at its disposal, and what would they hope to do with it? Along with many other large companies, Apple keeps most of its money offshore (93%) due to high tax rates in the United States. Under President Trump, and his initiative to bring U.S. companies back into the country, he has proposed a day of reduced taxes on these companies in an attempt to encourage them to move back to the U.S. This would allow Apple to utilize its resources here by marketing to more shareholders or being able to be more active in acquisitions. Because of these political prospects, and the fact that Warren Buffet’s share in Apple has doubled in the past year, the Apple stock is soaring. These factors have driven Apple’s stock up and have made it a possibility that Apple will soon have a larger dividend yield in the future. Although many of Trump’s proposed policies have been controversial, it seems to me that his desire to bring U.S. companies back into the U.S. would be a beneficial one. I believe that Apple coming back into the United States would allow it to grow even faster than it currently is, in addition to bring more jobs and more opportunities to the American people through this move. Sources:
  • http://www.cnbc.com/2017/05/02/apples-cash-hoard-swells-to-record-256-8-billion.html
  • http://www.foxbusiness.com/features/2017/04/30/apples-250-billion-cash-pile-enlivens-hopes-fuels-expectations.html

Quetourah Dalencourt
May 7, 2017
The Nintendo Switch console has been selling quickly since its release on March 3, 2017. The company sold 2.74 million consoles in March, its first month of sales, exceeding the 2 million it expected to sell. Nintendo has been forced to ship the console by air in March to meet high consumer demand. However, in April, the company resumed standard freight shipping.

Source: Nintendo

The console which has its own screen and resembles a tablet which can be morphed into a typical TV console by putting it in its dock. The versatile console has been selling by the hours instead of days as Mario Kart 8 Deluxe 's release date approaches. Nintendo is targeting a new audience with the new console and the new games it will release. Nintendo is known as a family-friendly company but ultimately hopes to attract "hard-core gamers" and players of all ages. To attract a new audience, Nintendo will have to be able to meet its customers' demands. While shipping by freight is the cheaper option, Nintendo risks not meeting demands quickly enough. Nintendo must be proactive about how to meet customers' demands in order to avoid backlash in the future. Sources:

Katherine Dorovitsine November 10, 2017 On September 12th, Apple grabbed the attention of millions of eager viewers during its special event at the Steve Jobs Theater. New models of the Apple TV, Watch and iPhone were met with the usual excitement from loyal customers, and the latest iOS update promised to make iPhone and iPad “the most powerful, personal, and intelligent devices they’ve ever been.” Users were greeted with one more improvement in Apple’s line of products which stood out among the rest, though; boldly introducing the iPhone X as a vision to the future, Apple once again brought itself to the forefront of innovative technology. The new model features an all-screen design, the most sophisticated camera yet with face ID technology, a more durable and water-resistant shell, and countless other upgrades from what seems like the now outdated iPhone 7. [caption id="attachment_459" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Macrumors.com[/caption] Concerns over the new iPhone’s large price tag, starting at $999 and increasing with storage size, were settled within 3 days of its release in stores. 20 major cities had already sold out and online shipments were delayed, estimated to arrive as late as December. Apple’s clear success in the release of the newest iPhone model became apparent in its stock price as well, pushing it to a new record of $174.25. The newest iPhone release is also expected to have effects that span beyond the borders of Apple itself. Sales during the holiday season are expected to decrease drastically as a result of the high price tag of Apple’s newest, in-demand products. Morgan Stanley analysts have estimated more than $52 billion of spending will be deferred from other retail products this holiday season, as a result of Apple’s new releases. While Apple’s employees and shareholders are benefitting from its growth, what does it mean for competitors? Apple and Samsung have been in constant competition for years, with one company’s newest smartphone always working to “one-up” the other. Has the iPhone X placed itself ahead of its competitor indefinitely? Or will it fuel the competition as Samsung prepares to release its newest Galaxy? While it’s unclear whether one company will finally dominate the other in the near future, we can be sure that smartphone technology will continue to provide users with huge advancements. The iPhone X is likely just the beginning of a new age of digital reliance. Apple’s advertisements seem to be right in that it’s time to “say hello to the future.”   Sources:

John Casella October 23, 2017 The iconic yellow cab has been a staple of New York culture for almost a century. But in a city where trends mirror the lifespans of fruit flies, the taxi dynasty is screeching to a halt. [caption id="attachment_367" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Ad Meskens[/caption] At the start of 2017, Uber and Lyft vehicles outnumbered yellow cabs 4 to 1, which has undercut the taxi’s longstanding stronghold on ridership and profits. In November 2010 alone, yellow cabs made 463,701 daily trips and brought in $5.17 million in fares. Six years later, they made only an average of 336,737 daily trips and $4.98 million in fares. This monthly loss of over 100,000 daily riders and almost $200,000 offers only a snapshot into the crisis yellow cabs are facing. However, ride-hailing apps are not the only thing threatening the taxi business. Say hello to self-driving cars. Governor Cuomo recently announced Manhattan as the testing grounds for General Motors’ new technology (through its start-up subsidiary Cruise Automation) in early 2018. The current demand for this form of transportation is difficult to estimate, but falling behind in the age of rapid advancement could hurt the state in the long run. Consequently, this kind of automation is threatening the employment of drivers across the board, but it is particularly dangerous to the life of yellow cabs. This is because Uber and Lyft have already introduced driverless cars. A lobbyist group for taxi and limo drivers fought earlier this year to ban the new technology in New York State for 50 years, but this attempt has fallen on deaf ears. The taxi industry is forced to go without a viable long-term strategy, while its drivers remain pessimistic about its future. The bright pops of color that once dominated Manhattan’s streets are taking a backseat in the race to ridership. Employed drivers might become an obsolete occupation overall, but the interest for ride-sharing apps continues to soar, while taxis are facing extinction. While other companies are racing ahead, the yellow cabs are stuck in neutral.   Sources:
  • https://www.nytimes.com/2017/10/17/nyregion/driverless-cars-manhattan.html
  • https://ny.curbed.com/2017/1/17/14296892/yellow-taxi-nyc-uber-lyft-via-numbers
  • http://fortune.com/2017/01/06/taxi-drivers-uber-self-driving-car-bans-new-york/
  • https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/oct/20/new-york-yellow-cab-taxi-medallion-value-cost

Sidonya Hakimi October 28, 2017 America has been performing economically well in previous years. However, American consumer debt levels are exceedingly high, and the ratio of household debt to household income has drastically risen. [caption id="attachment_381" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: US News Money[/caption] In August of 2017, American consumer debt rose to $3.766 trillion, which was higher than July’s reporting of $3.753 trillion. Statistics from the Federal Reserve have indicated that American households are billions of dollars deeper in debt compared to the figures just one year ago. According to the monthly International Monetary Fund report, the median household debt-to-GDP ratio has risen from 52% to 62% in the years 2008 to 2016 (consumer debt currently equals two thirds of America's GDP). This ratio has also risen in emerging economies around the world, so America is not alone in this problem. The steep incline in consumer debt is particularly alarming because personal loans must be paid back in a timely fashion, whereas government debt is ongoing. Credit, loans, and leveraging are hurting consumers this intensely because the repercussions of inflation are stronger than growing wages. Moreover, as consumer debt increases, economic recessions are prolonged. To remedy this problem, government policies may be administered in the near future, especially programs that can help with ‘household debt restructuring’ for struggling families. However, short term economic growth and increasing consumer debt go hand-in-hand; a more financially stable economy is paired with lower growth and higher unemployment. Americans heavily rely on auto loans, college loans, and mortgages to finance their lives, and would be unable to live at the standard they would like without them. Programs need to help families rely less on external financing, which involves loans with extremely high interest rates that exceed the same increase in income over time. If contractionary monetary or fiscal policy is implemented to help stabilize the economy, such as a higher reserve requirement or increased taxation, Americans will have less opportunity to spend, and consumer debt levels will continue to rise.   Sources:
  • www.thebalance.com/consumer-debt-statistics-causes-and-impact-3305704
  • www.businessinsider.com/americans-are-more-indebted-than-ever-raising-economic-risk
  • http://www.imf.org/en/Publications/GFSR/Issues/2017/09/27/global-financial-stability-report-october-2017

Namita Jain October 28, 2017 Amazon has recently announced its search for a second headquarters. Currently, the tech giant's only headquarters is located in Seattle, Washington. But due to the company’s fast-growing nature, executives are unsure how much Seattle will be able to handle in the near future. Cities such as Chicago, Dallas, and San Diego immediately started showing interest in this new project. [caption id="attachment_401" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Seattle Business Magazine[/caption] Amazon has laid out its criteria for its project, which is called HQ2. The company would like their new headquarters to be located in a welcoming, metropolitan city with more than one million residents, have on-site access to mass transit, a quick commute to an international airport, and easy access to a main highway or road. They are also looking for a location that is diverse and has many recreational opportunities. Currently, Dallas and Chicago have been showing the most interest in becoming the new location. Dallas representatives have started to contact Amazon regarding the next steps of the project and think this new addition will be highly beneficial to their fast-growing economy and community. In addition, Chicago fits all of Amazon’s criteria and is an urban setting with an established culture. According to the New York Times, “Amazon is one of the largest tech employers in the world. But the company said the total number of new employees at its second headquarters outside Seattle could reach 50,000.” This new project would stimulate the economy because of the job opportunities it offers. However, it would have a much stronger impact in a smaller city than in a very large one. While the expansion has its benefits, these cities must also anticipate some drawbacks, including rising housing costs, bad traffic gridlock, and an increased gap between the middle class and lower class. Overall, the city that will house the new headquarters will benefit the most, because the positives certainly outweigh the negatives.   Sources:

Abishek Johnson October 30, 2017 On the week of the 20th anniversary of the MetroCard, the MTA has announced it will officially be putting an end to the payment method. As a commuter school, Baruch College has thousands of students who rely on public transportation every day. The MTA provides this service to the vast majority of these students who swipe their MetroCard on a daily basis. [caption id="attachment_407" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: New York Times[/caption] Following a widely successful European model, the MTA has decided to forgo its MetroCard by 2019, in exchange for an NFC (Near-Field Communication) type of electronic payment. The benefits of this change would be a reduced wait time on MTA buses, a reduced need for separate cards in the wallets of commuters, and it would save the MTA $6 Million per year on MetroCard production. The MTA hopes to rely on help from Credit/Debit Card Companies to implement embedded chips within their cards to promote a EZ Pass–esque method of payment. Tapping these embedded chips on turnstiles could also be included in keychains and other devices such as smartphones. With this implementation of a new innovative way to pay for Subway fares, consumers would no longer need to worry about refilling, losing, or even swiping their card. In its prime, the MetroCard was a great step forward technologically. But as stated by spokesperson Aaron Donavon, “[The MetroCard] was revolutionary for its time. Its time has come, and it's time to move on to the next innovation." As we move on from the idea of separate travel cards for our daily commute and the well-known struggle to swipe correctly on the first time, we realize that we are the generation that will see technology advance far more than any other generation before us. So, next time you go to swipe your metro card and the dreaded 3 words, “Please Swipe Again” appear, remember to smile for it may be the last time you see that message ever again.   Sources:
  • http://gothamist.com/2014/01/09/farewell_metrocard_mta_plans_to_kil.php

Its time has come, and it's time to move on to the next innovation." As we move on from the idea of separate travel cards for our daily commute and the well-known struggle to swipe correctly on the first time, we realize that we are the generation that will see technology advance far more than any other generation before us. So, next time you go to swipe your metro card and the dreaded 3 words, “Please Swipe Again” appear, remember to smile for it may be the last time you see that message ever again.   Sources:

Zill Ratanji February 18, 2018 This year's flu season has been absolutely brutal. Not only has it been affecting health care clinics, but also businesses nationwide. More employees taking off from work leads to more production being faltered, causing a standstill in the overall economy. Moreover, for small businesses, this effect can cause their whole work force to go missing, leaving no one to operate the business. To put this effect into perspective, “the total cost to employers could be $15.4 billion in lost productivity, or output…such a toll theoretically could cut first-quarter economic growth by three-tenths to four tenths of a percentage point, from a projected 2.6% annual rate to 2.2% or 2.3%” (Davidson). This shows how the effects of the flu spread far greater than just the medical field. [caption id="attachment_501" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Benzinga[/caption] Due to these circumstances, businesses are considering giving their workers free flu shots to avoid such an epidemic to their firm. Although it may not guarantee a perfect success rate, it will be a great path towards prevention. Other businesses are even considering giving their employees paid sick leave. This will incentivize sick employees to stay home and avoid risking other employees from getting sick as well. “A recent study out of Florida Atlantic University found that, unsurprisingly, US workers without paid sick leave are more likely than those with paid sick leave to keep going to work when they’re ill” (Gillett). Therefore, businesses should reconsider their health care policies and procedures to prevent their businesses from entirely shutting down in cases of such an outbreak. Businesses face losses that are employee related, but customer related too. Restaurants and other service organizations experience a great loss of customers because people are less willing to go out to eat and shop because of the flu. All in all, businesses have been suffering a great deal from this flu internally and externally.   Sources:
  • www.usatoday.com/story/money/2018/02/13/nasty-flu-season-takes-toll-small-businesses/321785002/.
  • www.businessinsider.com/2018-flu-season-will-cost-employers-billions-2018-1
data.post_title: Bad Flu Season Burdens US Businesses

Recently, there has been much controversy about Trump's new tax reform. Upon his presidency, Trump has declared the Unified Tax Reform Framework on September 27, 2017. This new tax reform would reduce the income tax rates and lower the corporate tax rate from 35 percent to 20 percent. It is stated that the Trump administration wants to boost the money supply and have more revenue flowing through the economy. According to Fox News, "cutting corporate rates could also increase the average American household income by $4,000 annually." People will have more money to spend on goods and services, which will boost the economy.
[caption id="attachment_413" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Keloland.com[/caption]
On the other hand, some people assert that Trump's tax reform plan would merely benefit the rich corporations and have minimal impact on the poor or middle classes. For example, the poorest fifth of the population would see their current tax break of 0.5 percent drop to 0.2 percent. The Balance claims this tax plan "eliminates itemized deductions except for those on charitable contributions, mortgage interest, property taxes, and retirement savings." The Tax Policy Center said that the Framework would increase the $20 trillion national debt by $7 trillion over the next ten years. The plan eliminates state and local tax deductions, which means the taxpayers in states with high taxes such as California and New York will not benefit from this new tax plan. The Framework also eliminates personal exemptions. The personal exemption allows taxpayers to subtract $4,050 from income for each person claimed on the tax return, mainly children known as dependent to the family. Families with many children would pay still higher taxes because the children are not held accountable anymore.
This plan has sparked some very contentious debates. It will be interesting to see how it moves through Congress in the upcoming weeks.
Sources:
  • https://www.thebalance.com/trump-s-tax-plan-how-it-affects-you-4113968
  • http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2017/10/30/democratic-women-in-senate-were-all-for-these-tax-reform-principles-until-trump-proposed-them.html

Zoe Sailer November 3, 2017 The founder of SpaceX and CEO of Tesla electric cars has begun his newest venture, The Boring Co., on an old parking lot outside the Hawthorne headquarters of SpaceX. There, a boring machine is completing the entrance to a tunnel that Elon Musk, one of today’s most impressive minds, hopes will one day carry cars to LAX and beyond. [caption id="attachment_423" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Electrek[/caption] Since August, Musk has been teasing the public with ideas of tunnels that eliminate “soul-destroying” traffic in the country’s busiest and congested cities. Although this idea may seem pretty out there, construction of the tunnel has already begun; Hawthorne's city council has given him permission to build a two-mile test under the city of Los Angeles. The initial stages began just this past weekend, and pictures of the progress can be seen on Musk’s twitter (@elonmusk). Although right now he is only permitted to build test tunnels, he already has plans for future routes that will find their homes under LA streets. Musk wants the first official route to follow the 405 highway from the Los Angeles International Airport, and then connect to the 101 highway. The ultimate goal of the tunnels are lightning fast rails that will allow cars to move at a much faster speed than they are currently able to. Musk’s mission is to produce these high-speed tunnels in a cost effective and fast way. In the future, he wants to reduce the time for a trip from New York City to Washington D.C. to under 30 minutes. If he can do it, this will solve travel density problems in some of the most populated cities. Elon Musk's innovative mind will truly change the world for the better.   Source:
  • https://qz.com/1115298/elon-musks-first-image-of-his-tunnel-to-banish-los-angeles-soul-destroying-traffic-with-the-boring-company/
