Sami Vukelj November 4, 2017 Halloween spending in the United States was projected to reach a record high this year at $9.1 billion (according to the National Retail Federation). While 2017's results are still being tallied, the organization's projections usually fall in line with actual amounts. The NRF has been conducting a Halloween spending survey since 2003, and releases its predictions every September. The forecast is an increase from 2016’s record of $8.4 billion in spending because more Americans are participating in Halloween than in previous years. This increased participation has helped Halloween spending jump to $9.1 billion in 2017 from $3.3 billion in 2005. The largest portion of the spending was projected to be costume costs, which accounts for $3.4 billion. Other projections include $2.7 billion for candy, $2.7 billion for decorations, and $410 million for greeting cards. [caption id="attachment_433" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: University of Windsor[/caption] 47% of consumers reported going to discount stores for Halloween products, while 38% said they opted for specialty shops. Business from discount stores, grocery stores, and department stores is reduced by the seasonal Halloween stores that can be found temporarily in October. To remain competitive, these year-round businesses must find a way to make their Halloween sections stand out in comparison to these temporary specialty stores. A CIT Bank survey reported by CNBC states that millennials (ages 18-36) spend about twice as much as other generations for Halloween, and reveals how the various generations celebrate differently. Ages 18-24 are more likely to dress in costumes and host/attend parties, while other generations are much more likely to stay home and hand out candy. This shows that younger people not only spend more on costumes and Halloween preparations, but they are also more likely to spend money by going out to Halloween themed events. The 18-36 demographic is spending the most for Halloween, and as its biggest patron, it makes sense for retailers to continue to cater towards and target millennials each October.   Sources:

Basil Harding November 4, 2017 Amazon is on the prowl, ready to disrupt yet another industry. Amazon has done this so many times that Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s visionary founder, might as well run a master class on the subject. By focusing on customer experience above all else, the tech giant continues to find new business opportunities in various different fields. Right now, the business empire has its sights set on the pharmaceutical industry. [caption id="attachment_442" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: PYMNTS.com[/caption] According to reports made by CNBC, Amazon is currently hiring a general manager to lead a team to discover how to break into this business. As of April, Japan Times reported that Amazon has expanded its Prime Now service to deliver drugs. Amazon has a history of testing new product lines in foreign countries, and the Japanese version of Amazon's website includes pharmaceuticals as a shopping category. With healthcare reform taking the limelight in the current political climate, many consumers are worried about the cost of prescription drugs. If Amazon can offer competitive prices and convenient delivery they will become a major disrupting force in this industry. Look out CVS, Walgreens, and Express Scripts--Amazon is coming for your lunch!   Sources:

Katherine Dorovitsine November 10, 2017 On September 12th, Apple grabbed the attention of millions of eager viewers during its special event at the Steve Jobs Theater. New models of the Apple TV, Watch and iPhone were met with the usual excitement from loyal customers, and the latest iOS update promised to make iPhone and iPad “the most powerful, personal, and intelligent devices they’ve ever been.” Users were greeted with one more improvement in Apple’s line of products which stood out among the rest though. Boldly introducing the iPhone X as a vision to the future, Apple once again brought itself to the forefront of innovative technology. The new model features an all-screen design, the most sophisticated camera yet with face ID technology, a more durable and water-resistant shell, and countless other upgrades from what seems like the now outdated iPhone 7. [caption id="attachment_459" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Macrumors.com[/caption] Concerns over the new iPhone’s large price tag, starting at $999 and increasing with storage size, were settled within 3 days of its release in stores. 20 major cities had already sold out and online shipments were delayed, estimated to arrive as late as December. Apple’s clear success in the release of the newest iPhone model became apparent in its stock price as well, pushing it to its new record of $174.25. The newest iPhone release is also expected to have effects that span beyond the borders of Apple itself. Sales during the holiday season are expected to decrease drastically as a result of the high price tag of Apple’s newest, in-demand products. Morgan Stanley analysts have estimated more than $52 billion of spending will be deferred from other retail products this holiday season, as a result of Apple’s new releases. While Apple’s employees and shareholders are benefitting from its growth, what does it mean for competitors? Apple and Samsung have been in constant competition for years, with one company’s newest smartphone always working to “one-up” the other. Has the iPhone X placed itself ahead of its competitor indefinitely, or rather, will it fuel the competition as Samsung prepares to release its newest Galaxy? While it’s unclear whether one company will finally dominate the other in the near future, we can be sure that smartphone technology will continue to provide users with huge advancements. The iPhone X is likely just the beginning of a new age of digital reliance. Apple’s advertisements seem to be right in that it’s time to “say hello to the future.”   Sources:

John Park December 5, 2017 Founder Steve Ells will step down as Chief Executive Officer of Chipotle after 24 years of selling the company's organic, freshly-prepared burritos, bowls, and salads. He has failed to keep pushing the boundaries, as several mainstream chains, including McDonald’s and Wendy’s, have also switched to fresh ingredients. Furthermore, Chipotle has failed to recover from its drop in customer traffic and share value ever since the fall of 2015, when an E.coli outbreak affected various Pacific Northwest restaurants. Mr. Ells has acknowledged he disregarded customer service as he tackled E.coli, salmonella, and other norovirus outbreaks. [caption id="attachment_488" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Denverpost.com[/caption] Chipotle’s innovation, dubbed “fast-casual,” is an upgrade from fast food without the table-service of a sit-down restaurant. However, it has now become a common category of dining chains. Ells put it best when he said, “It is clear that we need to move faster to make improvements.” He has voluntarily stepped down, and will move into the role of Chipotle’s executive chairman focusing on innovation. Chipotle’s shares went up 3.2% soon after Ells’ new role was announced. Sanford Bernstein analyst Sara Senatore said, “He has long been viewed as the culinary and cultural standard-bearer for the company, but less focused on operations.” With new leadership on Chipotle’s horizon, change is inevitable. “There would be a realignment of the performance pay,” according to Mizuho analyst Jeremy Scott, “Ells’ stock package is one of the highest on the street.” The new CEO will be paid a salary reflective of Chipotle’s performance in contrast from Ells’ $15.7 million, which included salary, stock, and option awards. Under new leadership, many expect Chipotle to utilize customer-loyalty programs that Mr. Ells abhorred, but that other chains like Starbucks have instituted profitably. Chipotle has undergone many recent changes even before the announcement, like the restaurant’s morphing online order and pickup service, and so, it is exciting to see what Chipotle has in store for us next.   Sources:

Jun Huang November 11, 2017 After almost twenty years of rivalry, two of the largest electronics manufacturers, Intel and AMD, will collaborate on their first solution for high performance laptop chips. Their goal is to combine AMD Radeon graphics processing units (GPU) with Intel central processing units (CPU) using the Embedded Multi-Die Interconnect Bridge (EBIM) technology. What sets this new innovation apart from previous generation laptops is the weight, size, and power consumption of the final product. Intel claims that compared to traditional laptops, a laptop with EBIM has a reduced thickness of up to 15mm in height. Additionally, power consumption will be drastically improved, resulting in a reduction of up to 50%. This technology allows Intel and AMD to bring a longer and more portable gaming experience to the consumer without compromising performance. [caption id="attachment_464" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Fudzilla[/caption] The pricing of this new technology has not been announced yet, but seeing the recurring trend of Intel’s pricing with their desktop processors, this innovation will certainly come with a heftier price tag. In the long run, however, this new technology is beneficial to the consumer in many ways. One, of course, is the innovative aspect of this collaboration. For the past few years Intel has shown little to no innovations within the gaming community. According to a performance benchmark conducted by HardwareCanucks, the i7 2600k, a Sandy Bridge 32 nanometer architecture CPU released in January 2011, has a negligible performance difference compared to a more recent model, the i7 7800k, which was released in October 2017. Although this is the desktop CPU situation, it is actually accurately representative of the mobile gaming technology Intel is bringing to the gaming community. Hopefully, their collaboration with AMD is an indication of gaming innovation. While initial prices are expected to be higher for this new technology, this certainly brings attention to Nvidia, an even bigger oligopoly of the gaming industry. As of Q1 2017, Nvidia dominates 72.5% of the discrete GPU market, with AMD as its only significant competitor. Intel’s attempt to join forces with AMD is not only an effort to take down the GPU supergiant, but also their introduction into the GPU market. As such, we can expect to see the disruption in the market shares bringing more competition, ultimately resulting in lower prices and more innovation for the consumer.   Sources

Jennifer Pareja November 12, 2017 As the holiday season approaches, businesses are awaiting to see how people will shop. According to a Deloitte survey of about 5000 Americans, shoppers are projected to spend 51% of their holiday budget online, compared to 42% in stores. This will be the first time that online holiday shopping is expected to beat out in-store sales. [caption id="attachment_468" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Odyssey[/caption] Moreover, only 28% of people expect to shop in traditional department stores, which is a decrease of 4% from last year. A larger percentage of people internet shopping is causing companies to focus on their online businesses. This can be seen through Macy’s holiday hiring; they recently decreased their total amount of seasonal workers, but increased the number of workers that will be assisting with online orders by 3000 people. Target is also hopping on the internet trend. They recently launched Gift Now, a service which allows customers to send gifts via email. Similar to Deloitte, Adobe is predicting an increase in online shopping. They expect online sales will reach $107.4 billion dollars, which is an increase of 13.8% compared to last year. A great part of this will be due to Cyber Monday, which is predicted to be the largest online shopping day with $6.6 billion dollars in online sales, a 16.5% increase from last year. Anthony Patafio November 12, 2017 Snapchat just had its third earnings report while being public and it caused the stock price to decrease by as much as 20%. It is particularly tough for analysts to predict earnings and user growth for Snapchat because unlike most public companies, they do not provide future estimates. While this may seem like an extremely disappointing quarter, it does not mean all hope is lost. [caption id="attachment_478" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Usatoday.com[/caption] Back in 2012 when Facebook had its IPO, it struggled for many months before actually turning in steady profits. Snapchat reported 178 million daily active users which represented an increase of 3% from its previous quarter where it only had 173 million daily active users. Although this may seem like a lackluster figure, Snapchat is still reaching a high amount of users and is working to drive growth in new ways as well as please the public market. One of the most important tasks for social media companies is not just growth of users, but retaining those same users to create a following that will last for years. The CEO came out and said he was going to redesign the app which may prove to be disruptive at first, but hopefully will provide long term dividends for the company. The problem many new users are having is that they believe it is too difficult to use. The main worry is losing their strong current user base for new users who may not be as loyal. Snapchat will have some steep hills to climb, especially given how successful their competitors have become. But from a contrarian point of view, they have been doing a lot right and will figure out ways to reduce their high costs and boost user growth.   Sources:

Jun Huang March 14, 2018 Over the past year, cryptocurrency has faced exponential rates of growth. The most popular cryptocurrency, Bitcoin, reached an all time high of $20,000 in December 2017. Investors who purchased Bitcoin when the prices were in the thousands expected further potential from it. Some even say that prices will continue to skyrocket as cryptocurrency becomes more widely traded and accepted. [caption id="attachment_522" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: ETHNews.com[/caption] On December 18th, 2017, Bitcoin, Ethereum, Litecoin, and other major cryptocurrencies began plummeting. By the end of December, prices dropped by nearly 40%. It continued to plummet until it reached $7000 per Bitcoin, which is roughly a 65% drop from the all time high. The major reason for this crash was the concern towards regulatory crackdown in Asia. According to Business Insider, Russian President Vladimir Putin claimed that  "legislative regulation [for bitcoin] will be definitely required in future." In addition, Chinese officials announced their plans to restrict access for major cryptocurrency platforms. Aside from stricter regulations, cryptocurrency possesses many inherent risks. Its greatest strength and weakness lies in the decentralized market. Without government control or regulation, both buyers and sellers are fully anonymous. However, the lack of regulation can also pose many threats. Without proper regulation and safety systems implemented, hackers can easily reroute the address of the recipients to their own wallet and receive those funds. Goldman Sachs, a multinational investment banking company, has recently noted the security flaws of the blockchain technology. They mentioned that they will be compliant towards their clients, but will be mindful that they “may be vulnerable to cyber attacks”. Another concern Goldman hinted at was how “nascent” the blockchain technology is. Governments across the globe are still deciding whether they need stricter regulations on cryptocurrency. Some have already announced stricter regulations, which can mean that cryptocurrency is potentially dangerous for Goldman Sachs. Additionally, there aren’t many places that accept cryptocurrency. Whether cryptocurrency will become the future is still up for debate. Despite these claims and concerns from Goldman, there has been little to no price drops in the markets. In fact, Bitcoin prices have increased by around 10% since the announcement.   Sources:

John Park December 5, 2017   Founder Steve Ells will step down as Chief Executive Officer of Chipotle after 24 years of selling the company's organic, freshly-prepared burritos, bowls, and salads. He has failed to keep pushing beyond the frontier as several mainstream chains, including McDonald’s and Wendy’s, have also switched to fresh ingredients. Furthermore, Chipotle has failed to recover from its drop in customer traffic and share value ever since the fall of 2015, when an E.coli outbreak affected various Pacific Northwest regions. Mr. Ells has acknowledged he disregarded customer service as he tackled E.coli, salmonella, and other norovirus outbreaks. [caption id="attachment_488" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Denverpost.com[/caption] Chipotle’s innovation, dubbed “fast-casual,” is an upgrade from fast food without the table-service of a sit-down restaurant. However, it has now become a common category of dining chains. Ells put it best when he said, “It is clear that we need to move faster to make improvements.” He has voluntarily stepped down, and will move into the role of Chipotle’s executive chairman focusing on innovation. Chipotle’s shares went up 3.2% soon after Ells’s new role was announced. Sanford Bernstein analyst Sara Senatore said, “He has long been viewed as the culinary and cultural standard-bearer for the company, but less focused on operations.” With new leadership on Chipotle’s horizon, change is inevitable. “There would be a realignment of the performance pay,” according to Mizuho analyst Jeremy Scott, “Ells’ stock package is one of the highest on the street.” The new CEO will be paid a salary reflective of Chipotle’s performance in contrast from Ells’ $15.7 million, which included salary, stock, and option awards. Under new leadership, many expect Chipotle to utilize customer-loyalty programs that Mr. Ells abhorred, but that other chains like Starbucks have instituted profitably. Chipotle has undergone many recent changes even before the announcement, like the restaurant’s morphing online order and pickup service, and so, it is exciting to see what Chipotle has in store for us next.   Sources:

Natalie Csak December 5, 2017 U.S. new-home sales have reached a ten-year high, and according to Seeking Alpha, the U.S. housing market may be on the brink of another bubble. Federal Reserve Economic Data (FRED) show that there is an upward trend in new-home prices, similar to the trend the U.S. housing market experienced prior to 2008. Seeking Alpha examines this growth and states, “the U.S. housing bubble of 2000s, its boom and bust character in particular, had been defined largely by the investor's intent on flipping houses (buying houses in order to sell them within 12 months period and get capital gains).” Not only this, but poor management of assets without sufficient leverage also contributed to the housing market disaster. Even though there is insufficient evidence of this occurring now, investors remain wary. [caption id="attachment_497" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Rose Law Group Reporter[/caption] Some firms in Brooklyn, for example, reported that their Q3 earnings were the highest they’ve seen in nine years. “According to Corcoran’s [a New York real estate company’s] report, the median is $733,000, and the average is $856,000, based on 1,670 closed sales.” The increase in luxury homes is also helping to push prices higher throughout Brooklyn and other surrounding areas. Lower housing inventory is, across the board, not having an effect on housing sales, as Brooklyn’s “building boom” continues to meet the demands of the market. Looking forward, there is concern amongst realtors that the newly passed tax reform bill will cause housing prices to drop in every state. Particularly, it is the changes within mortgage interest deduction that stands to lower housing prices. Under the current law, you can deduct mortgage interest “for purchases of up to $1,000,000 plus an additional $100,000 for equity debt.” Under the new tax bill, “the state and local property tax deduction would remain in place but would be capped at $10,000. Under the Senate bill, the property tax deduction would be eliminated.” The National Association of Realtors estimates that housing prices would fall by at least 10% all over the nation, hitting places like New York and New Jersey hard. What the government is trying to do is ensure that wealthier Americans do not take advantage of tax deductions that they do not necessarily need. Essentially, this generates more tax revenue from American taxpayers who might otherwise be able to find loopholes in the current mortgage interest deduction policy.   Sources:

Zill Ratanji February 18, 2018 This year's flu season has been absolutely brutal. Not only has it been affecting health care clinics, but also businesses nationwide. More employees taking off from work leads to more production being faltered, causing a standstill in the overall economy. Moreover, for small businesses, this effect can cause their whole work force to go missing, leaving no one to operate the business. To put this effect into perspective, “ the total cost to employers could be $15.4 billion in lost productivity, or output…such a toll theoretically could cut first-quarter economic growth by three-tenths to four tenths of a percentage point, from a projected 2.6% annual rate to 2.2% or 2.3%” (Davidson). This shows how the effects of the flu spread far greater than just the medical field. [caption id="attachment_501" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Benzinga[/caption] Due to these circumstances, businesses are considering giving their workers free flu shots to avoid such an epidemic to their firm. Although it may not guarantee a perfect success rate, it will be a great path towards prevention. Other businesses are even considering giving their employees paid sick leave. This will incentivize sick employees to stay home and avoid risking other employees from getting sick as well. “A recent study out of Florida Atlantic University found that, unsurprisingly, US workers without paid sick leave are more likely than those with paid sick leave to keep going to work when they’re ill” (Gillett). Therefore, businesses should reconsider their health care policies and procedures to prevent their businesses from entirely shutting down in cases of such an outbreak. Businesses face losses that are employee related, but customer related too. Restaurants and other service organizations experience a great loss of customers because people are less willing to go out to eat and shop because of the flue. All in all, businesses have been suffering a great deal from this flu internally and externally.   Sources:
  • www.usatoday.com/story/money/2018/02/13/nasty-flu-season-takes-toll-small-businesses/321785002/.
  • www.businessinsider.com/2018-flu-season-will-cost-employers-billions-2018-1.

Mark Kashani February 18, 2018 Since 2009, the stock market has seen relatively steady growth, with the exception of occasional small dips. Overall, investors have been pleased with this growth and lack of volatility. The first week in February, however, the markets took a plunge. Over the course of two days, the Dow fell more than 1,800 points. On February 5th, the Dow recorded its biggest one-day point drop in history, which was approximately 1,175 points. [caption id="attachment_514" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: ADVFN.com[/caption] Although there is no specific reason for this decline, Business Insider gives a couple of theories on what may have caused it: tax cuts are working, workers are finally getting raises, interest rates (and inflation) could be going up, and the placement of the new Chair of the Federal Reserve, Jerome Powell. This volatility in the Dow Jones and S&P 500 has caused anxiety among investors, but for the average person investing for retirement, daily market moves do not matter as much as they do for day traders. In fact, the best thing you can do, according to Business Insider, is to keep your money invested, and perhaps even invest more. Since the drop of over 1,800 points, the Dow Jones, as well as the rest of the market, has begun to correct itself. On January 26th, the Dow was slightly over 26,500 points. Following the drop, it dipped a little shy of 24,000 points. As of Friday, February 16th, the Dow closed at 25,219.38. Over the course of about ten days, the market slowly began creeping up again. Now is still a great time to invest; the Dow has a good chance of catching up and surpassing where it was within a couple of months.   Sources:
  • https://www.cnbc.com/2018/02/06/us-stock-futures-dow-data-earnings-market-sell-off-and-politics-on-the-agenda.html
  • http://www.businessinsider.com/dow-jones-sp-500-volatility-cause-investors-to-panic-2018-2
  • http://money.cnn.com/2018/02/02/investing/why-dow-dropping/index.html

Natalie Csak February 18, 2018 As the 2018 fiscal year is launching into full speed, the United States federal budget is experiencing some significant changes, as would be expected under the Trump administration. According to Inside Gov’s projections, the most drastic changes will occur within the allocation of government funding and the total deficit as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP). [caption id="attachment_518" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Politico[/caption] Surprisingly, the federal government is expected to allocate 28% of its total spending towards Medicare and general health spending. This is more than twice the average amount of money that has been put into health spending in previous years. One of Trump’s most notable goals was to “repeal and replace” Medicare and substitute it with something less costly, which is why the hefty 28% is shocking to many analysts. Compared to all preceding fiscal years, this is the most amount of money that the government has ever put into health spending. Although spending appears to be at a high, the total deficit as a percentage of GDP is at a low -2.3%, which is less than the historical average. As the debt ceiling rises it will become increasingly important for the Trump administration to keep this number as low as possible. Public debt as a percentage of GDP, on the other hand, is at an all-time high. Nevada Republican Senator Dean Heller's website says that "as our national debt grows, the dollar is weakened and Americans have to work more so they can buy less." Over the remainder of the 2018 fiscal year Americans should be paying close attention to increasing inflation rates. Between the extensive debt that the United States is in and the Federal Reserve’s plan to increase interest rates, Americans can expect the dollar’s value to deplete. Although steadily increasing inflation generally promotes healthy economic expansion, the increasing interest rates and debt combined might counteract any foreseeable benefit that inflation would have on the American economy.   Sources:
  • http://federal-budget.insidegov.com/l/121/2018-Estimate
  • https://www.cnn.com/2018/02/10/politics/budget-deal-in-nlew-era-of-spending/index.htm

Jun Huang March 13, 2018 Over the past year, cryptocurrency has faced exponentials rates of growth. The most popular cryptocurrency, Bitcoin, has reached its all time high of $20,000 during December. Investors who purchased Bitcoin when the prices in the thousands expected further potential from Bitcoin. Some even say that prices will continue to skyrocket as cryptocurrency becomes more widely traded and accepted. [caption id="attachment_522" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: ETHNews.com[/caption] On December 18th, 2017, Bitcoin, Ethereum, Litecoin, and other major crytocurrencies began plummeting. By the end of December, prices dropped by nearly 40%%. It continued to plummet until it reached $7000 per Bitcoin, which is roughly a 65% drop from the all time high. The major reason for this crash was the concern towards regulatory crackdown in Asia. According to Business Insider, Russian President Vladimir Putin claimed that  "legislative regulation [for bitcoin] will be definitely required in future". In addition, Chinese officials announced their plans to restrict access for major cryptocurrency platforms. Aside from stricter regulations, cryptocurrency posses many inherent risks. Its greatest strength and weakness is the decentralized market that it encourages. Without government control or regulation, both buyers and sellers are fully anonymous. However, the lack of regulation can also pose many threats. Without proper regulation and safety system implemented, hackers can easily reroute the address of the recipients to their own wallet and receive their funds. Goldman Sachs, a multinational investment banking company, has recently noted the security flaws of the blockchain technology. They mentioned that they will be compliant towards their clients, but will be mindful that they “may be vulnerable to cyber attacks”. Another concern Goldman hitned at was how “nascent” the blockchain technology is. Governments across the globe are still deciding whether they need stricter regulations on cryptocurrency. Some have already announced stricter regulations, which can mean that cryptocurrency is potentially dangerous for Goldman Sachs. Additionally, there aren’t many places that accept cryptocurrency. Whether cryptocurrency will become the future is still a question at large. Despite these claims and concerns from Goldman, there has been little to no price drops in the markets. In fact, Bitcoin prices have increased by around 10% since the announcement. Sources:
  • http://www.coindaily.co/2018/02/27/goldman-sachs-cites-risk-of-crypto-after-acquiring-crypto-exchange/
  • http://www.businessinsider.com/bitcoin-cryptocurrency-market-crash-explained-causes-2018-1?r=UK&IR=T
  • https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/2017/12/19/bitcoin-exchange-collapses-second-cyber-attack-year/

Namita Jain March 14, 2018 This year’s Winter Olympics took place in Pyeongchang, South Korea. The United States of America sent 242 athletes to the Olympics and brought home 23 medals including 9 Gold medals, 8 Silver medals, and 6 Bronze medals. This was very far off from the team’s projected medal count of 37. Team USA won gold medals in the following events: Men’s Slopestyle Snowboarding, Women’s Slopestyle Snowboarding, Men’s Halfpipe Snowboarding, Women’s Halfpipe Snowboarding, Women’s Giant Slalom, Women’s Cross-Country Team Sprint, Men’s Halfpipe Freestyle Skiing, Women’s Ice Hockey, and Men’s Curling. [caption id="attachment_527" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: NBC News[/caption] According to The Atlantic, this year was the worst America has done since Nagano 1998 when it only won 13 medals. In the 2010 Vancouver Winter Olympics Team USA brought home 37 medals, and in the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics they won 28 medals. In Pyeongchang, Team USA managed to move up to fourth place in the overall medal count by the Closing Ceremony. This year’s performance was disappointing based off of the number of athletes sent. Norway, which came in first place in the overall medal count, had a team size that was less than half of Team USA's, and still managed to do outstanding. They won 39 medals overall, a new Winter Olympics record. Team USA had some very close calls and many athletes missed a medal because they placed either fourth, fifth, or sixth place. Nevertheless, Team USA will try its best to make a comeback in the next Winter Olympics in Beijing 2022.   Sources Used:

Basil Harding March 14, 2018 Loretta Lee, a former Google Engineer says she was consistently sexually harassed and that Google’s “bro culture” contributed to her ordeal. Lee notes several specific acts of harassment such as male colleagues spiking her drink with whiskey and laughing about it. She also claims that when she approached her desk one day she found a male colleague on his hands and knees hiding underneath the desk. Lee claims that the next day that same co-worker who was hiding under her desk grazed her breasts when he grabbed her name tag to read her name. Lee also claims that she was shot at with nerf bullets and balls every day. She has since filed a lawsuit. [caption id="attachment_531" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: The Indian Express[/caption] Loretta Lee’s claims fit into a wider movement to end sexual harassment called #Metoo. The Metoo movement looks to end sexual harassment in all spheres including business. Google is known to be an innovative forward-thinking company. Their workplace culture is thought to be progressive and inclusive. The fact that a company like Google is struggling with maintaining a harassment-free work environment should make it abundantly clear to all companies that a safe work environment for all employees is not a given. Companies must take a series of definitive steps to prevent sexual harassment and empower employees to report any cases if they arise. One important step I believe companies need to implement into their sexual harassment training is a victim impact statement. Many would-be sexual harassers do not see the negative consequences of their behavior. By incorporating victim impact statements into sexual harassment training all employees will be able to fully recognize the harm that can come from someone being abused in that form.   Sources:

Abishek Johnson March 23, 2018 The recent breaking news of Lloyd Blankfein stepping down as Chief Executive Officer at Goldman Sachs caught many by surprise. The world-renowned investment banking company was one year away from its 150th Year Anniversary. Under Blankfein's leadership, Goldman was able to stay afloat during the 2008 financial crisis. After struggling with cancer in 2015, he continued to lead the company in a very productive way, something that made him a powerhouse in the financial world. [caption id="attachment_537" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: CNN Money[/caption] Although Blankfein has stated that he will only retire by the year's end, the process to find a suitable successor has already begun. The current frontrunner is David Solomon, the President and the Co-Chief Operating Officer at Goldman Sachs since 2017. Many people also know David Solomon for his many gigs across the world as a part-time electronic dance DJ. Although unconventional, many of the best leaders come from diverse backgrounds with many skill sets. Having a creative perspective can be very valuable in the business world in a way that can open up many doors for Goldman Sachs. Personally, I feel as though this is the right move for both parties involved. It was time for Lloyd to do what was best for his mental and physical health, and Goldman Sachs is now able to appoint a new and diverse leader that can connect with younger generations of business leaders. I look forward to seeing the transition of power and seeing how the company does under its new leadership.   Source:
  • http://money.cnn.com/2018/03/09/investing/lloyd-blankfein-goldman-sachs/index.html

Sidonya Hakimi March 23, 2018 After 70 years, our beloved childhood toy store is finally closing its doors. Numerous factors contributed to the demise of Toys “R” Us. With the rise of big-box retailers banking on broad, low cost strategies such as Walmart and Target, specialty stores such as Toys “R” Us could not hold up to the competition. Also, with the gaining influence of the internet and websites such as Amazon killing the need for a middle man, people started buying toys and other merchandise with a click of a button; there was no longer a need to make an entire trip to Toys “R” Us to buy kids Christmas gifts when similar items were readily available to be purchased on any electronic device. This drastic shift away from traditional storefronts is damaging the retail industry and forcing companies that are still intact to shift to an online platform to remain relevant. [caption id="attachment_542" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Bloomberg[/caption] In September of 2017, Toys “R” Us filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy and began selling stores and liquidating their assets. In 2017, more than 300 retailers have also filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy as they came under immense pressure from large retailers and online stores. Toys “R” Us planned to restructure the company after filing for bankruptcy in September, but did not manage to make enough to stay open and recover from their debt. Over the past decade, Toys “R” Us accumulated $5 billion in debt in an effort to remain on the grid in this heavily digital age; immense sales were not enough to save the company. On Thursday, March 15th, Toys “R” Us declared that unfortunately, it must liquidate its business, which would ultimately lead to the closure of 735 stores worldwide and the unemployment of 33,000 employees. The company’s last hope to remain intact was the outcome of the holiday season. However, Christmas of 2017 produced earnings at nearly 50% of a normal business year. The underperformance during the holiday season was the final indication that it was time for the company to shut down. Toys “R” Us will potentially remain open for another two months, which is around the time when they declared they will no longer be able to continue paying employees. The company hopes to maintain some stores outside of the United States which have proven more profitable. Sadly, stores in America will dissipate and in generations to come, kids will merely here the tale of when their parents and grandparents used to shop at Toys “R” Us.   Sources:
  • http://money.cnn.com/2018/03/14/news/companies/toys-r-us-closing-stores/index.html
  • https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/business/2018/03/15/toys-r-us-files-bankruptcy-liquidation/427129002/

Sherry Chen March 24, 2018 On Thursday, March 22, President Trump had officially announced tariffs on steel and aluminum. Trump said the “US will impose a 25% tariff on steel imports and 10% tariff on aluminum” to increase revenue in these industries (Diamond- CNN). This tariff policy will negatively impact international trading with other steel-producing countries, especially China. This strict measure will impose tariffs on $60 billion worth of China’s goods to combat the rising national threat (Landler and Tankersley- The New York Times).
[caption id="attachment_548" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: Paychex[/caption] Trump implied that this trade action is used against a country that he says is responsible for thousands of lost American jobs and billions in lost revenue. The White House emphasized that this tariff is in retaliation towards “China’s use of pressure and intimidation to obtain American technology and trade secrets” (Landler and Tankersley). After Trump announced the moves, China’s Ministry of Commerce said that it was proposing tariffs of its own on “128 products from the United States, like nuts, wine and pork, that it valued at about $3 billion.” China urged the Trump administration to find a conciliation where the two nations can maintain a friendly economic relationship and to “avoid damage to the broader picture of Chinese-U.S. cooperation.” Some critics fear that these tariffs will cause a trade war between the world’s two largest economies. After Trump’s announcement, the financial markets plunged and the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index dropped 2.5%. Some Republican lawmakers stated that the tariffs would hurt the economy internally because it would increase costs for consumers. Republican Senator Ben Sasse of Nebraska harshly criticized Trump’s decision, as he said “the President is proposing a massive tax increase on American families.” On March 1, Trump tweeted that “Our Steel and Aluminum industries (and many others) have been decimated by decades of unfair trade and bad policy with countries from around the world. We must not let our country, companies and workers be taken advantage of any longer. We want free, fair and SMART TRADE!” The purpose of this tariff was to strategically to defend the US from China’s economic aggression and boost internal tariff revenue, but the outcome is uncertain.

Anthony Patafio March 24, 2018 Over the past week, the three major stock indices in the United States reentered correction territory. One of the stocks hit the hardest has been Facebook, which fell below $160 for the first time since July of last year. For the contrarian buyer, this seems like a great time to step in and buy. Part of the reason Facebook’s stock has been hit so hard is due to privacy issues. Many people are becoming more aware of how much information Facebook is taking from them and they are not pleased. [caption id="attachment_563" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Source: SiliconBeat[/caption] Despite the concern for regulation hindering Facebook’s business, they are still in great shape and any regulatory efforts will probably not affect their long term plans. Facebook continues to gain users and grow its bottom line. Data is huge in today’s world and companies are willing to pay large amounts of money to access the data Facebook retrieves. Data can be analyzed in so many ways and Facebook is great at figuring out what people may want to buy. Although this may seem kind of creepy at times, it does give people greater opportunities to spend money on things they want. Overall, Facebook’s recent pullback may make many buyer’s anxious and skeptical about getting into the stock, but if you believe in data and Facebook’s long term model, now might be a great time to invest. Facebook is likely to be volatile, as is the market over the next few months, but in a market upswing, Facebook would be one of my picks for the greatest growth opportunity.

Arya Sanghavi October 15, 2018 My first class at Baruch was Business Fundamentals. The very first thing we were taught before we embarked upon our predictable yet inevitable adventures to becoming entrepreneurs was the importance of ethics. We learned about the “rights and wrongs” a business has to distinguish between and the respective lens through which they should view it from. After reading the article JPMorgan Chase Settles Allegations It Violated U.S. Sanctions, I was intrigued as to how my dream employer was caught violating the very same ethics I had learned about and how they would be the very first case study I would apply my syllabus to. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="359"] Source: JUSTIN LANE/EUROPEAN PRESSPHOTO AGENCY[/caption] The renowned bank was charged to pay a heavy restitution fee of 5.3 million to settle allegations of violating various U.S. sanctions programs. Going on for about six years now, JPMorgan Chase choose to act under illegal circumstances and use negligence as their fall back plan. 87 of their transactions involved clients and foreign entities with airlines that were subject to U.S. sanctions. The bank, in 2010, had been subject to investigation for a lack of a comprehensive system that screened all their clients. Three years later in 2013 the bank rescreened 188 million client records using their “new and improved” system, eventually reporting the violations. The scandal was passed off as mistake in the compliance program deficiencies, but what really should be stressed on is the lack of attention paid by JPMorgan Chase that may not have been so unintentional. From small convenience shops to large financial institutions such as JPMorgan Chase, ethics are universal and are the core of the Business Fundamentals my professor was teaching me about. Sources:

Subrina Oaishe October 15, 2018 About 35 years ago millions of American southerners had devised a groundbreaking and unconventional method to set themselves up for their retirement and for their future offsprings to come ahead. The ingenious idea was to buy up acres of land and grow trees on them. Given that it was the 80’s, who could have predicted the emergence of technology, or the instability of mid-2000, or understood the science behind the volatile but gratifying stock market, it seemed to be an easy and effortless plan to guarantee a definite success. As stated by a timber broker explaining this once tree craze, “If you work and you didn’t want to put all your money in the stock market, you’d buy 40 acres and plant trees and they’d be ready to cut by the time your kid went to college...It’s like a 401(k).” Beside this rationale of the time, there was another factor pushing for this sensation-The U.S. Government. Back in the 80s to help fight a current agricultural trauma the Reagan Administration had an incentive, the Conservation Reserve Program, which paid farmers from “$30 to $50 dollars for each acre they planted with trees or grasses”; there was soon enough reasons for investors to go forward with this movement. The popular use of trees as a major building resource inevitably did not sit well with the housing crash of 2008. That year the housing prices declined, homeowners struggled to make mortgage payments, and houses foreclosed. The decade ago event has negatively affected the timber market of the South and the well thought out 401k’s of the people because soon many mills closed and leading to an overstock of goods. Although America is slowly recovering from the events of 2008, the timber market has not been able to recover that swiftly. Landowners are forced to sell their overstock logs at a lower price than decades ago to their nearby mills because no one wants to bear the costly responsibility of transporting thousand tons of large logs to the North to sell at higher price. In the end, what seemed to be a well thought out investment of the 80s, given time and recent tragedy turned to be a bust. It goes to show nothing is definite and do give or take a few bumps on the road when you are planning to invest in the long run. Source:
  • www.wsj.com/articles/thousands-of-southerners-planted-trees-for-retirement-it-didnt-work-1539095250

Michelle Nazar October 15, 2018 [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="626"] Source: EPA-EFE[/caption] Interest rates are what the rate depository institutions are charged for borrowing money from Federal Reserve Banks. When the Fed increases the federal funds rate, it is more expensive for banks to borrow money. Then, a ripple effect forms and the financial institutions often increase the rates they charge their customers to borrow money. Therefore, these customers are then more reluctant to spend money voluntarily on goods that provide every day pleasure like a toy or food from a restaurant. This effects the stock market in that since a company now has “less money" to spend to better its products or service, the estimated growth in the company lowers which then causes its stock to plunge. This plunge frightened many people with their investments. In reality, this is a short-term problem. The Fed can only increase its interest rate when they know that people are spending otherwise. If the economy is down and customers aren’t buying things then they would actually lower its interest rate in hopes that because it is easier for people to borrow money, people are more reluctant to spend discretionary money. Over time, the stock market will return back to most of those company’s “share value”. I do not think there should be any worry that comes with this sudden shock the stock market experienced, and I believe that words through the media also play a huge, underrated value in the the estimated cash flow of a company. Source:
  • https://www.wsj.com/articles/fed-raises-interest-rates-signals-one-more-increase-this-year-1537984955

On Monday October 15, 2018, the 132-year old store Sears has filed for bankruptcy in New York. Sears has been having issues for years since shoppers favor have gone to online shopping and their rivals Walmart and Home Depot. There also recent store closings and cutting cost have made a damaging effect on the store. Dumping the Craftsman brand, as well as Lands End, continued to put fuel in the fire. Debt increased significantly, and Sear’s market value has fallen below $100 million. As of now the company is closing 188 stores country wide.
 
The Sears bankruptcy goes to show that the managerial authorities should have been changed or taken up by an individual that would lead them far from debt. The internal conflicts due to the competitions from the management, took a toll on the company. The slash in advertisement spending was a severe and disastrous action taken. The steps that they have taken to relieve debt, only hurt them more. I feel the only way to save this store-chain is to be bought by a large company. Sears being around since post- World War II, may have also run its course and may have to shut down, such as ToysRus and RadioShack.

Over the past year, it has come to the general public’s attention that video games hold a tremendous audience. Thanks to Fortnite, with over 2.4 billion views on YouTube in February alone, the eSports growth has exploded. Gaming organizations, such as FaZe Clan, are a collective group of gamers who entertain and compete on multiple platforms, such as YouTube and Twitch. They basically make a living playing video games. The growth throughout the years of gaming entertainment have been mind boggling. Who would have thought that there would be so much money to be made playing video games? More importantly, who would have ever thought people would be interested in other people using a controller to compete in a virtual game that contains no physical activity whatsoever and is still regarded as a “sport”? Nevertheless, you cannot argue with the statistics. This is only just the beginning. As time goes on, video games will advance with technology. Viewership within these games will increase. The passion of gamers is like no other profession. The excitement and enjoyment content creators produce for their audience is revolutionary. A few years ago, no one could have predicted this to be the reality of video games. It is truly astonishing.   Sources: https://www.statista.com/statistics/746230/fortnite-players/ https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/02/style/fortnite.html

data.post_content: Joshua Gadasi 10/20/2018 As Election day approaches, California residents have suggested an approach to reconcile the housing crisis currently affecting their state. Their solution, Proposition 10, is a legislation that would give states more power to implement rent control laws. The proposition suggests revoking the Costa-Hawkins Rental Housing Act, essentially allowing the state to implement rent control laws for more homes and apartments. The California Democratic Party and other advocates of the proposal argue that passing it would help reverse the lack of affordable housing currently available in Los Angeles, while opponents believe that passing the plan would lead to developers having less incentive to build new homes. Both sides of the argument raise legitimate concerns. Lack of affordable housing is a severe issue that should be addressed, but if developers are not motivated to create more living spaces, there will be less units which cities can apply rent control laws to. The solution, unfortunately, lies somewhere in the middle. Opponents main concern is that if the bill doesn’t pass, landlords will continue to raise rents. If California passes a law, similar to the rent stabilized units in New York City, which restricts the amount that landlords can increase rent levels, it would allow developers to continue building, while safeguarding lower income families from assaults on their housing. It is imperative that California learns from cities with successful affordable housing options. Any other choice would risk the possibility of permanently damaging the diversity of the state and ruining the progress we have worked so hard to attain.   Source: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/12/business/economy/california-rent-control-tenants.html

Lucy Liu 10/20/2018   Uber Technologies Inc. is adding a new tractor-trailer rental business called Powerloop. Its purpose is to connect small carriers with fully filled trailers from big businesses (like brewer Anheuser-Busch InBev), helping big-rig truckers haul freight around the country. It has leased hundreds of trailers and is renting them for $25 a day. Related to this is Uber’s Freight division, which alerts truckers with empty trailers to waiting cargo loads (similar to Uber’s business of connecting people with rides). Uber has already accrued some success from UberEats, its food delivery unit, which may alleviate the losses from Powerloop. Because of a fast-growing U.S. economy, rates for last-minute truck transportation were up one-third from the year before, during what was supposed to be a slow time of the year. This means the trucking industry, which has always been considered cumbersome and cost-intensive, is squeezing U.S. businesses even more with rising freight costs and a tight capacity. Uber expects to expand Powerloop outside of Texas, where it’s being tested now, which is a good move. While Powerloop sounds cost-intensive to maintain, I think it’s a great way for Uber to gain an advantage in multiple industries. For instance, the rise of e-commerce is dramatically affecting retail supply chains, since they have to ship their goods in smaller loads in order to meet consumer demand. This means a raise in transportation costs for businesses, who also have to pay rising contract rates, since trucking companies are so swamped with demand that they have to turn down freight. Uber is taking advantage of this: carriers can load trailers at their own convenience instead of waiting for them to arrive, which wastes time and increases costs. However, there is a lot of risk involved, especially if the economy slows down, which would impact manufacturing, and therefore the trucking industry. In addition, Uber faces competition from big tech players like C.H. Robinson Worldwide Inc. and Echo Global Logistics. Uber’s services also aren’t guaranteed to win over shippers, who could easily negotiate their own contracts and prices with trucking companies. However taking this risk could propel Uber into the trucking and retailing industries and lead to greater profits.   Source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/uber-targets-trucking-with-new-trailer-rental-business-1539781200?mod=djemCFO_h

Deanna Pisacreta 10/20/2018 Recently Washington Post journalist, Jamal Khashoggi, went missing while visiting Saudi Arabia’s Istanbul consulate. Just yesterday it was announced he is presumed to be dead, and Saudi government officials may be behind it. If this is true, many U.S. lawmakers are calling for sanctions against Saudi Arabia as a retaliation. However, if these sanctions are imposed Saudi Arabia may react by driving up oil prices. The price of oil is already a growing concern with planned sanctions on Iran already causing worry over supply constraints. As of Friday, Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Robert Kaplan stated that the situation with Saudi Arabia is too unpredictable to, “significant effect on my thoughts on monetary policy.” It is clear to him that the sanctions on Iran will have a significant effect on the price of oil, but the Saudi situation is too unclear to judge at the moment. At this point, Saudi Arabia is America’s greatest ally in the Middle East, against Iran. However, an attack on an American journalist cannot go unanswered. It is also important to note that Saudi Arabia is a member of NATO, an international agreement stating, “an attack on one is an attack on all.” If America does place sanctions on Saudi Arabia it could definitely has a drastic effect on the price of oil, but also have a major global effect that has yet to be foreseen.   Source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/feds-kaplan-too-soon-to-know-how-saudi-tensions-could-affect-economy-1539982056?fbclid=IwAR2DFC0hQxZYtTuXTfrh8F-atdPsCvpnyWZpxMlZrdzuBypiD48_aRoIDeM

data.post_content: Arya Sanghavi 10/20/2018 After recently reading the article “ Dow Falls More Than 300 Points Amid Concerns Over Global Growth”, I was taken aback as too see so many world markets come crashing down from a political standpoint. As the title of the article suggests, the Dow Jones Industrial Average tumbled more than 300 points after Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said he wouldn’t participate in an investment conference in Saudi Arabia. Immediately after, Blue chip stocks such as Apple and Netflix suffered huge declines in their stock value. Investors were trying to predict the severity of this storm as it not only affected the American stock market but was causing ripples in the European and Asia pacific region. The Stoxx Europe 600 fell 0.5% and the Shanghai Composite fell 2.9% to reach its lowest closing value since November 2014. Furthermore, with the tensions with Saudi Arabia there lies the risk of a change in oil prices launching a worldwide economic crisis.   It’s clear that finance is so much more than numbers and handling money. To truly understand the field it’s important to consider the economic, political and social issues that envelop us. Confined to solely stock markets and share prices I limited myself to reading the wall street journal, oblivious to the world dilemmas by turning a blind eye to the general newspaper. It’s imperative to be fully aware of what’s going on in our neighborhoods and across the world. It’s important not to sever relations with other countries as it clearly jeopardizes the financial state of more than just one country. Read and read everything.   Source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/european-stocks-shrug-off-weakness-in-asia-1539848879

Marie-Elise Milius 10/20/2018
On Monday October 15, 2018, the 132-year old store Sears has filed for bankruptcy in New York. Sears has been having issues for years since shoppers favor have gone to online shopping and their rivals Walmart and Home Depot. There also recent store closings and cutting cost have made a damaging effect on the store. Dumping the Craftsman brand, as well as Lands End, continued to put fuel in the fire. Debt increased significantly, and Sear’s market value has fallen below $100 million. As of now the company is closing 188 stores country wide.
 
The Sears bankruptcy goes to show that the managerial authorities should have been changed or taken up by an individual that would lead them far from debt. The internal conflicts due to the competitions from the management, took a toll on the company. The slash in advertisement spending was a severe and disastrous action taken. The steps that they have taken to relieve debt, only hurt them more. I feel the only way to save this store-chain is to be bought by a large company. Sears being around since post- World War II, may have also run its course and may have to shut down, such as ToysRus and RadioShack.

Snapchat (SNAP) a relatively new social media that was the biggest IPO since Twitter went public in early 2017. The core audience contains young adults and teens. About 57% percent of this body registered to vote. Partnering with a nonpartisan, Democracy Works, a portal was created within the app allowing users who were 18 and older to register to vote. Filters were also created to get the word about registration. Snapchat estimates it may have helped over 418,000 users register to vote.
With the unhealthy division between in the country due to race, and injustice controversies and conflicts, the aid Snapchat provided for young adults to register to vote was need. It is our job, as the next generation to be apart of society by any means. The controversial presidential election of 2016 was the spark of this new voting urge. Continuing to the midterm elections, many of the public’s hope is their vote will help lead the Democrats to controlling the House. These midterm elections, just as the presidential election has high stakes and will greatly predict the rest of President Trump’s term.

It’s been seen before with huge companies like Amazon taking over Whole Foods. In order to be successful, it’s pivotal to move out of your comfort space and have a vision that incorporates more than just the hackneyed business fundamentals. Thoma is one of the many individuals that embodies the true entrepreneurial vision. data.post_content: Arya Sanghavi 10/29/2018 The only thing that’s constant is change. Like world climates and fast food menus, stocks and markets are always fluctuating. Recently, the so-called fundamental long-short equity hedge funds tracked by Goldman dropped 1.44% on Wednesday, according to the client report, which was reviewed by The Wall Street Journal. Hedge funds are trusted with their ability to perform during periods of market stress. However, that hasn’t been the case for the month of October. Stocks that use algorithms to drive stock piling is what’s fueling this decline in stock prices. Goldman who is one of the largest prime brokers for hedge funds that helps them place bets and finance trades said, “It was the deepest one-day drop since the bank began tracking the data in January 2012. These funds are down 8.68% this month through Wednesday, bringing returns to minus-6.21% for the year.” Furthermore, the S&P 500 is down 8.8% this month through Wednesday and off about 0.65% this year and the technology-stock-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index is down about 12% this month. In the stock market nothing is predictable. Even professionals’ at large firms like Goldman can be caught off guard with the lows and highs of the market. Some stocks are better to invest in others such as technological stocks, though they’re losing money too. In order to keep up with the stock market and keep your money safe, one must try to trace the volatility of it. Source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/goldman-stock-picking-hedge-funds-just-had-their-worst-day-in-six-years-1540491863

data.post_content: Deanna Pisacreta 10/29/2018 Last week we covered the financial implications, should Saudi Arabia be found responsible for the recent dismemberment of Jamal Khashoggi, a contributor to the Washington Post. This week, the Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman denied he had anything to do with the murder at the Saudi embassy in Turkey. Republican and Democratic lawmakers are reluctant to believe his story and are urging Trump to hold Saudi Arabia responsible. President Trump is reluctant to take action because America’s arms dealing with the Saudis brings in a lot of revenue for the U.S. However, lawmakers are arguing we don’t deal in arms for the revenue; we do it to maintain international allegiance. A murder of an American overseas would be a breach of that allegiance and appropriate action should be taken. Saudi Arabia is one of America’s greatest allies against Iran. However, with the attack at the Saudi embassy, can we really trust them to continue to be an ally? The cover story put out by the crown price makes no sense, and President Trump believing it despite the evidence would be the greatest show of weakness in his presidency. Something quite out of character for him. The global consequences of this attack could be vast. Bob Corker, the chair of the Senate foreign relations committee, argued that this could get the U.S., U.K., France, and Germany working with other countries to respond to Saudi Arabia. data.post_content: Daniella Benyamini 10/29/2018 This article discusses a dilemma that Netflix is currently facing: the company has been spending faster than it has been taking in cash — and expects to keep doing so for years. Investors should be wary of this because their personal cash is at stake. David Wells, the company's chief financial officer (CFO), is not worried. He believes that after a few years the company will break-even and Netflix will not need to borrow money to pay its bills because its profit will grow. Others, however, are not so convinced. Aswath Damodaran, a New York University finance professor, believes that “Netflix’s fundamental business model seems unsustainable” and “he doesn’t see how it's going to work out”. Personally, I think that Netflix should not be so confident with its model. Using the discounted cash flow approach (DCF), it was revealed that the company’s shares are only worth 177 dollars but Netflix has been trading its shares for approximately 300 dollars. Investors are worrisome so the company should aim to make a change to their financial approach.   Source: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/26/business/netflix-audience-stock-debt.html?rref=collection%2Fsectioncollection%2Fbusiness&action=click&contentCollection=business&region=stream&module=stream_unit&version=latest&contentPlacement=7&pgtype=sectionfront

In these last few years, Amazon has gained itself a reputation of a somewhat heartbreaker with their various business ventures and their effects on other companies. This e-commerce business has known to be the cause of several deteriorations in businesses with their entrances into selling clothing, electronics, grocery, books, and etc. online. This step has hit revenues of known established stores such as Nordstrom, Macy's, JCPenney, Best Buy, many US grocery stores, and Barnes and Nobles, down with heavy competitions from Amazon’s part. However, even within the midst of so many of their wins, there is a company that has flourished when all the others were hit hard-Five Below. Five Below is a chain “which sells everything from Spalding basketballs to Bluetooth headphones and yoga mats for $5 or less”. They bring in products from suppliers from around the world, similar to Amazon, to sell at many physical locations filled with a certain charm of its own that Amazon hasn't implemented ever before.

Five Below stores often containing small floor plans, are “grouped around eight categories: sports, technology, party, candy, style, create, room and now". Its core customers, preteens and teenagers, are encouraged to take full advantage of the store's layout by dribbling the basketballs, “test-driving radio-controlled cars and participating in slime-making contests”. Beside highly attracting the younger crowd, Five Below makes sure to look out for their older buyers too through the sell of yoga materials, skin care routines, vintage candy, and etc. The whole experience to Five Below is to have fun, explore, go on toy adventures, and take care of yourself through a shopping haul. All this is still done while saving a fortune on cost by buying everything under $5. “A study last year by KeyBanc Capital Markets Inc. found that a basket of 67 items was 52.6% less expensive at Five Below than on Amazon.com”. Founded in 2002, this chain has survived 16 years flourishing even when so many other retailers have greatly deteriorated under the influential ventures of Amazon. Nevertheless, here we are with this company that even after almost a decade, has resisted Amazon’s charm and may continue to do so for many more years to come.

Sources: https://www.wsj.com/articles/five-below-becomes-the-amazon-proof-store-1541151001?mod=hp_lead_pos9 https://www.businessinsider.com/amazon-is-killing-these-7-companies-2017-7#healthcare-companies-8

Elie Levine 11/04/18
Our morning routines might be at stake. So many Americans start off their day with a nice bowl of cereal and milk, usually Kelloggs, but due to increased prices, that number might start dropping. The entire food industry is facing a dilemma with higher commodity and shipping costs. Even though consumer goods are facing drops in sales, Kelloggs is still trying to find ways to remain on top. They recently transitioned to a cheaper distribution system which will eliminate a lot of the unnecessary costs of shipping. In the last quarter, shares dropped 8% in morning trading. Their CEO, Steven Cahillane, attributed these depressions to increased advertisements and increased shipments of single-serve snacks, which have higher production costs than bulk goods. Expect cereal prices to raise in order to accommodate the higher costs.
Breakfast is an American staple. Waking up late on a Saturday morning and watching cartoons with a bowl of cereal in hand is a memory that so many of us can reminisce about our childhood. However, with the increased productions costs leading to increased prices, our memories are at stake. The breakfast cereal companies understand how much a role they play in families’ lives, and they, especially Kelloggs, are trying to ensure we do not miss out on such a crucial time.
Source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/kellogg-leaves-bitter-taste-1541007928

Eric Li 11/04/18   Every interested student quickly realizes that the internship cycle for finance is particularly brutal. Students need to start preparing in winter for the summer internships of the following year. Then, the cycle wraps up just as the school year begins. This is extremely accelerated compared to other sectors like technology, where applications open up in the fall and closes up in the spring. Furthermore, as everyone knows, internship experience is valuable for securing future internships for larger more prestigious firms which only increases the pressure. Firms are also feeling this pressure as they are afraid of rival firms snatching away the best talent. Now, Goldman Sachs and JP Morgan has decided to end this internship arms race. They won’t interview sophomores and give them a return offer. Rather, the firms will wait until junior year to recruit interns. The two firms also state that this has the added benefit of allowing students to explore what they’re interested in, before jumping into the career.   Source: https://www.wsj.com/articles/goldman-jpmorgan-hit-pause-on-intern-recruiting-madness-1540819063

Aaron Puthan 11/04/18 Economists have always admired Uber for its innovativeness and competitive nature. Harvard’s Oliver Hart noted, Uber does not deal with many externalities and its competition with taxis enhances welfare for the general population. According to research done at the University of Chicago, “each $1 spent on Uberx rides generated a “consumer surplus” of $1.60. That surplus is estimated to be $6.8bn a year, across America.” There are also benefits for the drivers. The average hourly wage for an American Uber driver is $16, which is higher than the federal minimum wage. While Uber has several benefits, there are also costs to weigh. Bruce Schaller, a transport consultant, estimates that the ride-hailing app adds 2.8 vehicle miles in American cities for every mile that is subtracted. There is also increase in car registration and petrol consumption, which augments congestion in already populated cities. Data from the federal transport department reveals that the increase in number of cars correlates to a 3.5% rise in fatal car accidents. In order to mitigate the problems that Uber poses, I believe that the company should charge drivers for entering congested areas during peak hours. This will reduce the congestion of vehicles in cities such as New York, London and Stockholm by discouraging drivers from picking up riders in those areas. Likewise, adjusting ride fares to encourage carpooling, implemented using Uberpool, will also decrease the overcrowding of Uber vehicles. I am against New York City’s vote in August to have a cap for the number of ride-hailing cars that can be on the streets. This was enforced to protect Taxi drivers and regulate the industry. However, this barrier is reminiscent of the days when the taxi market was difficult to enter and competition for it was low. Uber’s competitiveness against the NYC Taxi and Limousine Commision (TLC) allows for the greatest aggregate welfare for consumers in need of a means of commute that is efficient and affordable. Source: https://www.economist.com/finance-and-economics/2018/11/03/the-social-costs-of-ride-hailing-may-be-larger-than-previously-thought

On October 27th, 2018, the International Business Machines (IBM) announced the company has bought Red Hat for $34 billion. IBM offered $190 a share in cash, which is more than 60% over Red Hat’s closing price last week Friday, which was  $116.68 a share. Red Hat is a is a software development for cloud computing. Red Hat’s Linux is a popular open-source operating system that sparked the acquisition of the company. The IBM cloud strategy is to supply both hardware and software for companies to build their on private clouds, and it also had a third-party public cloud offering. The boards of both companies approved the deal, and the sale is expected to close in the second half of next year.
I like that IBM bought Red Hat because if the want to excel in cloud computing, the Red Hat is great for that. The acquisition allows both parties to grow financially. IBM being a big international company, can now promote Red Hat’s work in countries that are not familiar with the brand’s work. With this addition I feel it is possible for IBM’s stock to rise in the next several months.
  Source: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/28/business/ibm-red-hat-cloud-computing.html

At Amazon It's More Complicated," addresses the similarities and differences between Sears and Amazon, along with a detailed analysis of Amazon's recent stop at giving stocks to employees. Ultimately, Sears and Amazon are similar in how they both transformed the way people shop, except Sears' 'heyday' is over, and Amazon's is still rising. With the decline of Sears, also came the decline in the amount of rewards corporate America shares with their employees. As Schwartz and Corkery note, American businesses are ridding of the 'winner-take-some' concept and replacing it with 'winner-take-most' or even all. What does this mean for the futures of these employees? Amazon thought that lifting its minimum hourly wage to fifteen dollars per hour would make up for the fact that they no longer are giving stock to employees. However, many argue that they'd take the stock, rather than the extra dollar. Before bankruptcy, Sears had an egalitarian, profit-sharing program in place where employees were given contributions based on seniority, instead of rank. Not to say that Amazon's previous program wasn't as generous, but Sears provided its employees with much more than Amazon ever did. Furthermore, this halt in providing two shares per year to warehouse employees not only isolates lower-paid workers from directly participating in increasing their wealth, but also makes them feel standardized to a working class they are trying to reach out of. Despite claims that this change will benefit employees, the matter of fact is when decisions are made, Amazon either gives money to shareholders or employees. Contrasting to how Sears employees left their jobs with comfortable pensions, the futures of Amazon employees feel uncomfortable. They are being left in the dark as the company continues to state that they are trying to increase opportunities for mobility. Decisions like these are usually based around business ethics. In this case, Amazon must decide between what's good for their reputation and what's good for the long-term success of the company. Whether or not they made the right decision is unknown, but time will tell. Source: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/23/business/economy/amazon-workers-sears-bankruptcy- filing.html

Just this week Facebook released their Portal device used for video messaging that gives a sense of reality to its user communicating miles away. Portal is a smart tablet type of device with a 12-megapixel camera on the front, and a large HD screen to help communication between two different ends. Facebook claims this device to be different then any other video messaging apps ever to be thought of before, but the release of this device has been met with uncertain reaction especially given their recent history. Facebook since this past year has been under major scrutiny due to a scandal with Cambridge Analytica revolving around Cambridge Analytica using the  “personal data of 50 million Facebook profiles... to map out voter behavior in 2016 for both the Brexit campaign and the US presidential election”. The personal data was provided to them through an app called “thisisyourdigitallife” where the builder of this app, Aleksandr Kogan, made a personality quiz that utilized people's personal information from their Facebook profiles. This incident came to light after a whistleblower within the Cambridge Analytica came out with "we exploited Facebook to harvest millions of people's profiles” and described this situation as "it is a full-service propaganda machine”.
 Facebook claimed that this was not a data breach since Kogan was within his legal rights to obtain that data however they claim that he for sure misused that data when he sold it to Cambridge Analytica and violated Facebook’s rules. This scandal initially came to light on March 16 through a story covered by The Guardian which had a tragic effect on Facebook stocks. Before March 16 Facebook was trading at around $185 but the day after the release of that news. stocks fell to near $150.
Given all these past negative incidents of Facebook, it is not a surprise that there are various mixed feelings on the Facebook new release of the Portal. Author Joanna Stern from WSJ describes her relationship to this new device as unwilling and skeptical. Portal's target audience is “families, and particularly those with young children and grandparents who live hundreds of miles apart.” With a “140-degree field of view” camera, the Portal has this ability that when it “recognizes a human in the frame, it crops the image and zooms in, and it does so smoothly as a skilled cinematographer would” without even the person’s permission. It is not surprising that Joanna Stern is hesitant to place this device in her home life from a company that has a history storing customer details and behavior and releasing them to outside parties for marketing purposes.
